flavor:
"In the drowsy dark cave of the mind, dreams build their nest with fragments dropped from day's caravan."
—Rabindranath Tagore

"In the Tarkir I once knew, the Abzan revered their ancestor trees. Now, as Dromoka, they cut their finest groves to make weapons."
—Sarkhan Vol
Martyred for worshipping her ancestors, she now walks among them.
The mage awakened the statue in hopes of learning the lost lore of her clan, but the statue was interested only in war.

"Why eat now what could one day grow into a feast?"
—Ojutai, translated from Draconic
"When I have meditated on all outcomes, my opponent has no recourse."
"I would gladly give my life if it would inspire my clan to victory."
Dromoka dragons foster trust among their subjects, while the other clans must spend their time quelling rebellion.
He scorns the heavy winter garb of lesser warriors, trusting his anger to keep him warm.
Atarka is worshipped and fed by her subjects at Ayagor, the Dragon's Bowl.
It exemplifies the ideals of the Dromoka: strength, unity, and honor.
The aven are admired, for they are able to fly with the dragons.

"There is elegance in all the Ojutai do—even their killing."
—Kirada, Silumgar enforcer

"Atarka's people starve while she feasts upon the bounty of their hunts. They must conquer ever more lands just for the sake of their own subsistence."
—Arel, Unseen Whisperer
"We are as brutal as our dragonlord. We strike like wild lightning and feast on human flesh."
Kolaghan blades rarely stay clean for long.
When battling the Kolaghan, consider yourself lucky if lightning strikes the same place only twice.
The Crave made Kneecleaver think she was bigger than the dragon.
"The blood of Dromoka and the blood of my veins are the same."
They whisper of an ancient hero who saved the dragons of their world.
Their lust for battle was so great that they didn't care their enemies wore their own faces.

"Every Silumgar blade carries the blessing of our dragonlord."
—Xathi the Infallible
Many can stand where one would fall.
The colossodon's hard outer shell stops many predators, but with a gentle flip from a dragon, it quickly becomes a meal in a bowl.
Atarka conquered Qadat, the Fire Rim, long ago, winning over its efreet with a promise to spread the glory of fire to all the world.
Atarka's presence thaws the glaciers of Qal Sisma, forcing its elementals to migrate or adapt.
Those who question Ojutai may not like the answers they receive.
Sidisi hated to limit her options.

"That which is beautiful in form can also be deadly."
—Ishai, Ojutai dragonspeaker
Silumgar delights in repurposing the treasures of other clans to serve his own ravenous greed.

"Silumgar's mind is a dark labyrinth, full of grim secrets and subtle traps."
—Siara, the Dragon's Mouth
The Ojutai believe in the Great Wheel: those who best serve the dragonlord are destined to be reborn as dragons.

"Seclusion is only an option for the strong."
—Sorin Markov

"I am a dragonslayer for Lord Silumgar. There is no dragon save him whom I fear."
—Xathi the Infallible

"Wars are decided one life at a time."
—Gvar Barzeel, Kolaghan warrior
Dragons emerge from tempests fully formed and terribly hungry.
Atarka goblins meet their demise as readily as their Temur counterparts did, but usually under big, winged shadows.
"Dromoka has taught me the secrets of her kind, that I might use them in her service."
Even the humblest guard of Ojutai's strongholds ponders the puzzles of the Great Teacher's lessons.
Bears are a delicacy for the Atarka. The few that remain are the toughest of their species.
The idols were forged during the time of the Khanfall, when the dragons came to rule Tarkir and its people aligned themselves with the five dragonlords.
Dromoka's followers forsake blood ties so that they may join a greater family.
Silumgar never passes up an opportunity to add to his opulence.
Atarka serving-goblins coat themselves with grease imbued with noxious herbs, hoping to discourage their ravenous masters from adding them to the meal.
"We fight not out of fear, but for honor."
"The dragonlords rule the tempests of the skies. Here in the wastes, the storms are mine to command."
Dromoka rules her clan from the Great Aerie atop Arashin, the central city of the Shifting Wastes.
Dromoka has regard for the humans who serve under her. In return for her protection, they obey with steadfast loyalty, acting as weapons for her and her scalelords against the other clans.
The simplest gift from a dragon can be a revered accolade for a human warrior.
Sarkhan was eager to take vengeance on Zurgo until he saw how lowly his old foe had become.
The dragon who eats the last head in the basket is entitled to the servant's.
Even after Anafenza was executed, many secretly maintained their beliefs in the old ways.

"Learn to see an obstacle from a new perspective. Underneath, for example."
—Chanyi, Ojutai monk
Only the sun that beats down upon Arashin's walls could shine more brightly.

"My dragonlord is immortal. Most dragons are not."
—Kadri, Dromoka warrior
No matter the timeline, some legends will endure.
The land is ever resilient. Should it die, it will be reborn.
Despite the flames and devastation of the dragons, Tarkir continued to thrive.
When Sarkhan saved Ugin in Tarkir's past, it changed Tarkir's future. The Sultai no longer exist, having been supplanted by the dragonlord Silumgar and his clan.
Like their dragonlord, the Kolaghan take no trophies. They find true fulfillment only in the battle itself, in clash of steel and thunder of hooves.
The cycle of life and death is rarely pretty.
Foul-Tongue shamans draw their powers from a dark twisting of the Draconic language.
Rakshasa waste no opportunity to display their wealth and power, even in the midst of a sorcerous duel.

"Can you catch a snowflake on the edge of your blade? Her sword has snagged an entire blizzard."
—Zogye, Ojutai mystic

"Lord Silumgar has given you a second chance to please him."
—Siara, the Dragon's Mouth
The small are mostly ignored by dragons.
Silumgar trains those whom he favors in his magic, granting them the ability to spread his disdain across the land.
An Atarka dragon's exhale cooks what its inhale consumes.

"Just let him loose and follow the charge."
—Yikaro, Atarka warrior
The trumpeters of Arashin are ever alert in their watch over the Great Aerie.

"If their ears are to the ground, we will make them bleed!"
—Taklai, Kolaghan warrior

"It sees all, but it reveals what it sees only to a chosen few."
—Taigam, Ojutai master

"It is most honorable to use every part of the animals we kill . . . especially if we use them to annihilate our enemies."
—Surrak, the Hunt Caller
She answers the call of the Crave, the desire for battle sated only by bloodshed.
Kolaghan has no lasting home, but her disciples leave relics to mark her conquests.
Kolaghan's army rushes from kill to kill, desperate to avoid the dragon's wrath.

"I've been told my whole life that the great Ojutai holds all knowledge, but I wonder what our forebears knew."
—Narset

"The greatest gift Dromoka gives is the ability to fly without wings."
—Urdnan, Dromoka warrior
A lifetime of discipline forsaken in a moment of rage.
Once it has your scent, it will hunt you from the Gurmag Swamp to Ayagor.

"Our shamans assert their mastery over the land, thwarting the lesser clans' attempts to stand in the way of our dragonlord."
—Allek, Atarka hunter
The gurgling of the Marang conceals both footsteps and screams.
Now vengeance is his sole purpose.

"The Ojutai are my favorite victims. They have so much knowledge to lose."
—Asmala, Silumgar sorcerer
Draconic words need not be shouted. A whisper will suffice.
Who you are constantly runs toward who you will be.
It heralded Sarkhan's return to Tarkir's present.

"Still the mind and quiet the heart. Only then will you hear the Multiverse's great truths."
—Narset
The remains of ancient civilizations litter the run-down land.

"You cannot be an Ojutai monk. They prize wisdom and skill, and you have neither."
—Siara, the Dragon's Mouth
"Though I may soar, I could never fly as high as the dragons."
Ojutai spends time at all his strongholds, but he most favors Cori Stronghold for his meditation.

"If I fight, I might step on a butterfly. That would be sad."
—Krowg of Qal Sisma

"The most profound secrets lie in the darkest places of the world. It can be prudent to make use of another set of eyes."
—Sidisi, Silumgar vizier

"Even paradise is not without tragedies."
—Sarkhan Vol

"Show your enemies as much mercy as they would show you."
—Surrak, the Hunt Caller
The elite of Ojutai's brood, the skywise see their enemies as puzzles to be solved.

"It hunts grand game for Atarka, and when the time comes, it will become a mighty feast."
—Surrak, the Hunt Caller
Dying for the greater good still hurts.
The Shifting Wastes are Dromoka's domain. She will not tolerate intruders.
Debts to rakshasa linger beyond death.
A dragon learns humility only in the moments before its death.
The sky offers few hiding places.

"If the scalelords are the brains of Dromoka's army, the supply caravans are its beating heart."
—Baihir, Dromoka mage

"The sands obscure the vision of others, but clarify ours."
—Faiso, Dromoka commander

"Intruders in the lands of Atarka have but two choices: be consumed by fire, or be consumed by maw."
—Ulnok, Atarka shaman

"Bring forth the dead, their skull-grins and rattle-bones. We will feast upon their wailing ghosts."
—Silumgar, translated from Draconic
With heat, sand can form a delicate work of art; with pressure, an impenetrable bulwark.
"Sad what passes for a dragon among the Silumgar."

"May our foes choke upon its horns!"
—Urdnan, Dromoka warrior
The people of Tarkir speak of an ancient legend, of the dragon-man called Sarkhan who was greatest of all khans.
Sarkhan gazed on the world around him, the dragons sweeping through its skies, and joy kindled like a fire in his soul.

"Your bravery honors us all."
—Dromoka, translated from Draconic
For hundreds of years Ugin slept, encased in the cocoon of stone and magic Sarkhan had created using a shard of a Zendikari hedron. As Ugin lay dormant, his spectral guardians kept vigil.
"My dragonlord's lightning will dance upon your bones!"

"The Shifting Wastes provide our clan eternal protection. It is our duty to return the favor."
—Kadri, Dromoka warrior
The list of things a krotiq eats is as long as the krotiq itself.
The shaman opened the earth beneath their feet, trapping the survivors within the crevices of Ayagor for Atarka to devour at her leisure.

"Worse than watching the cruelest deed is watching it done by your own hand."
—Baihir, Dromoka mage

"The Kolaghan send them at us. We kill and raise them. They fight the next wave the Kolaghan send. It's a neat little cycle."
—Asmala, Silumgar sorcerer

"Dragons in flight seldom expect company."
—Kadri, Dromoka warrior
Dromoka's scalelords patrol the skies over Arashin, offering her people safety from the harsh world.

"I almost envy them. They can't get frostbite."
—Kirada, Silumgar enforcer
"I tire of your prattle, and your face."

"The Silumgar creep around our borders and infiltrate our aeries. We must remain ever watchful."
—Golran, Dromoka captain
Better scarves than scars.
Silumgar takes pride in the diversity of his sibsig.
Silumgar dominates his clan from a fortress on the Marang River, where he rests upon piles of treasure.
Ojutai's words must be translated from Draconic before his students can benefit from their wisdom.
"Dragons are our betters, but we will fight them if our dragonlord orders it."
The Atarka use them not just for food, but also to clear away snow, trees, and enemy forces.
The storms of Tarkir awaken more than dragons.

"His companions are wise to follow him, for his foes dare not stand in his way."
—Zhiada, Dirgur protector
"Human enlightenment is a firefly that sparks in the night. Dragon enlightenment is a beacon that disperses all darkness."

"Do you not hunt the yetis of the high peaks, stripling? Their meat is as tender as a bear's and their blood as warming as fire. They are prey that will please Atarka."
—Surrak, the Hunt Caller

"We trust in the scalelords, bringers of justice that none can escape."
—Urdnan, Dromoka warrior
Though she stood alone, she struck with the force of an army.
"The greatest honor is to feed Atarka."

"Kneel before a dragon and you will be spared when it turns to leave."
—Yikaro, Atarka warrior

"Abzan, Jeskai, Sultai, Mardu, Temur—names lost to history, yet worthy of further study."
—Narset

"Such lesser creatures must be purged from the sky. What use do they have but to help channel the lightning of our mighty dragonlord?"
—Gvar Barzeel, Kolaghan warrior
Attracting a dragon's attention may be the last mistake you make.
A mocking laughter echoed in Ugin's mind. How many centuries had he slumbered, stricken, while Nicol Bolas moved unchallenged among the planes?

"Boasting impenetrable defenses only draws the most tenacious of attackers."
—Yikaro, Atarka warrior
Kolaghan archers are trained in Dakla, the way of the bow. They utilize their dragonlord's lightning to strike their target, no matter how small, how fast, or how far away.

"The Silumgar hide behind the deadly wildlife of their swamps. They'd rather scheme in their jungle palaces than face us."
—Khibat, Kolaghan warrior

"The realization that one is dying is far more terrifying than death itself."
—Sidisi, Silumgar vizier

"It slips through the smallest cracks in the mountain, emerging whole and unfettered. There is nowhere it cannot go, for what can hold back the air itself?"
—Chanyi, Ojutai monk

"As we have learned from Kolaghan, to ruin is to rule."
—Shensu, Kolaghan rider
Designed by an ancient artificer, the vials are strong enough to hold the very breath of a dragon—until it's needed.

"This pestilence robs us of glorious death in battle. We starve to death with full bellies and drown trying to slake our unnatural thirst."
—Kerai Hatesinger, Kolaghan warrior

"The bravest warriors take the shortest path to victory, whatever that path may be."
—Sakta, Atarka hunter

The crumbling temples on the tortoise's back are monuments to the decadence of the ancient Sultai. Though it harkens back to the era of the khans, Silumgar allows it to walk his territory as a warning to those who would oppose him.

"Too dumb, and you end up a sibsig. Too smart, and you end up a meal. Mediocrity is the key to a long life."
—Mogai, Silumgar noble

"Ojutai's rule has allowed Tarkir's monks to learn from the truly enlightened."
—Sarkhan Vol

"Don't try to hit your enemies. Concentrate on the space between them, and fill the air with doom."
—Spear-Tribe teaching
The mysterious purpose of two of the rings had eluded Esper mages—until now.
When an order for griffin barding comes in, blacksmiths prepare their forges for months of exacting work. They know griffins always detect imperfections and never haggle.

"This is how wars are won—not with armies of soldiers but with a single knife blade, artfully placed."
—Yurin, royal assassin
Kill a gnarlid with your first blow, or it'll cheerfully show you how it's done.
"In memories, we can find our deepest reserves of strength."
The ground erupted in time with the hedron's thrum, a dirge of the last days.
Its beak rends flesh and bone, exposing the tender marrow of dream.

"Kill the weak so they can't drag the strong down to their level. This is true compassion."
—Benzir, archdruid of Temple Might
Whether trained, ridden, or eaten, few goblin military innovations have rivaled the bug.
"From in here, everything looks like dinner."
In abandoned corners of Ravnica, nature has begun to reclaim what it once owned.
Hunters lure the stripling boar into the open, hoping to trap greater prey.
The mouth must be pried open before rigor mortis sets in. Otherwise the returning soul can find no ingress.
"What you are attempting is not against the law. It is, however, extremely foolish."

"We thought the clouds had moved from the night sky. Then the night sky moved, and the horizon grew wings."
—Josuri
"The treasure in my mind is greater than any worldly glory."
All seeds share a common bond, calling to each other across infinity.
He combs the streets looking for the lost light, the discarded enigmas of the city.
Swarms thrive in its nest, feeding on leathery bits of discarded wing.
"Don't mistake my creations for mere vegetation. They are my children, loyal and fierce."
The Sunbriar druids believe that every life begins in its heart and ends under its hooves.
A match for any army—even its own.

"It was a strange morning. When we awoke, we found our trees transformed. We didn't know whether to water them or polish them."
—Pulan, Bant orchardist
It turns the adversity of the moment into the knowledge of a lifetime.
The Boros legionnaire saw a noble sacrifice, the Rakdos thug a blazing suicide, and the Izzet alchemist an experiment gone awry.
Jund feasts on the unprepared.
About halfway to the target, Snukk vowed that he had been tricked for the last time.
The Thran learned to capture mana, but power inevitably escapes its bonds.
As the shards merged into the Maelstrom, their mana energies fused into new monstrosities.

"May the memory of our fallen heroes ensnare the violent hearts of lesser men."
—Great Threshold of Monserkat inscription
Those who displease Oona soon learn the extent of the armies she commands.
On Jund, everything eventually ends up in something else's stomach.
It lingers near the outposts of the Makindi Trenches, inadvertently granting another layer of defense.
Just when you thought you'd be safe, in the middle of an open field with no Eldrazi around for miles.
A killing machine from birth.
Viashino thrashes keep iguanars as hunting companions, giving them wounded captives as playthings.

"Yes, she is made of pure belief—but I hardly see why that makes her unique."
—Reith, master illusionist
The murk of the Wanderbrine concealed unseemly rituals designed to bring out the worst in merrowkind.
She reaches beyond the physical realm, touching the ideals from which all creatures draw their power.
Krond, the personification of the dawn's light, lives to exact justice on his nemesis Vela.

"The finest minions know what I need without me ever saying a thing."
—Liliana Vess
Animated by geists fused in its oak, it hungers for more life to add to its core.
The flame of anger is hard to douse once lit.

"What say you, my most trusted advisors? . . . Advisors?"
—Edra, merfolk sovereign
The oil sloshes against his skull as he nears his destination: the Frogtosser Games and the lighting of the Flaming Boggart.
It nurtures its masters' glorious future.
Noggles live purely by what they can scavenge. There is not a single thing a noggle eats, wears, or uses that did not once belong to another.
"Our unity unmasks your deceit."
Some druids nurture gardens. Others nurture continents.
Nature doesn't walk.
When it snared a passing cockatrice, its own soul darkly doubled.
That the Tolarian mists parted for the drakes was warning enough to stay away.
Tocasia brushed the gears and cogs from the table. There, before two wide-eyed brothers, she began a lesson on raw elemental magic.

"Artifice has always stood upon nature's shoulders. Let us watch nature take a turn."
—Freyalise
They could agree on one thing only: one of them must die.
The passing of the sai presages the end of the old clan and the ascent of the new.
Ancient lore locked in a mind driven mad is just as safe as when it was locked deep underground.

"This is the price of being last in the food chain. We must keep our places of beauty hidden away instead of displayed for all to see."
—Hildin, priest of Avacyn
When Asha left Bant, she ensured that the world would have protection and order in her absence.
Street folk call them "spire mice," but behind the mockery is an unspoken envy of the ledgewalkers' skill at avoiding harm.

"This palace will be our fire-spit, and roasted prince our victory meal. Send in the torch-pigs!"
—Ghut Rak, Gruul guildmage
The shield of unimpeachable purity is as strong as any wrought on the anvil.

"I don't concern myself with my enemy's hopes. Hopes follow the tides. They will retreat soon enough."
—Ambassador Laquatus
The golems of the ancient Thran still draw power in ways that baffle the artificers of today.

"Choose one to heal, one to harm, and one to grant you the prudence to use them."
—Miotri, auratouched mage
Viashino thrashes are led by elders who have survived countless challenges.
Those who raged most bitterly at the world in life are cursed to roam the nether realms in death.
Jund's thallids tried to disguise their deliciousness by covering themselves in spines harvested from the tukatongue tree.
Vela snuffs out every trace of Krond's reign, leaving pure nightfall in her wake.
In the autumn, she casts her seeds across the streets below, and come spring, her children rise in service to the Conclave.
Each flower identical, every leaf and petal disturbingly exact.

"I welcome it. The pasture is cleared of weeds and the wolves are frozen solid."
—Lumi, goatherd
"Listen to the roar! Feel the thunder! The Immersturm shouts its approval with every bolt of lightning!"
Such cloaks are in high demand both by assassins and by those who fear them.
Merrows skulk the silty bogs around the Wanderbrine, their very thoughts stained with evil.

"Why enchant feathers to make them sturdy when we can enchant shields to make them fly?"
—Braenna, cobblesmith

"None will concede a place for us in this world. If it is not for us, neither shall it be for them. We rest not until they choke in its cold ashes."
—Illulia of Nighthearth
After his hands had crumbled away, leaving only wickedly sharp points, he decided his only purpose was war.
Cinders carry an ancestral grudge that makes them slow to trust and quick to retaliate.
Moonstones grant limited foresight but unlimited advantages.
A kithkin's worst enemy is solitude.

"Boggarts are easy to get around. Just toss some mutton in another direction. Giants are a little harder. You have to be quick to avoid their steps. Cinders are the difficult ones, but even they have fears to be exploited."
His dreams are filled with noxious powders and clinking vials.
Those who hear her go mad with inspiration.
A chain of lies as strong as steel.
Its scars cut deeper than its blade.
Any kithkin smith would love to catch a dieflyn for her kiln, relieving her of ever having to gather fuel again.
Boggarts divide the world into two categories: things you can eat, and things you have to chase down and pummel before you can eat.
Cinder mages enjoy seeing their victims in the throes of bloodlust—and seeing the regret that inevitably follows.

The boar leads its rider to victory in battle, but it doesn't know how close it is to becoming the victory feast.

"We're going to need a bigger gate."
—Bowen, Barrenton guardcaptain

A clique can cause far more mischief than one faerie on its own.

"'Tis a strange creature indeed that chooses the vanquished over the victor."
—Awylla, elvish safewright

"If you see ghostly lights by the river, eat three twigs of marshroot to ward off kelpies."
—Kithkin superstition

"Dreams are fleeting. Reality even more so."
—Oona, queen of the fae
Guttering cinders stoke their dying flames by snuffing out the lights of others.
There are things beneath the murk for whom the bog is a stew, a thin broth in need of meat.
Seven wives made seven pies from seven apples, each plucked from its branches. Now bare and bitter, it comes to exact its price: one apple, one bone.
Each night that his bowl fills, a village mourns.
The whispers are incomprehensible, yet cinders always hear a message of urgency.
They envy the life-giving heat so much that they tear it from those who still possess it.
"Your seared flesh will be the first step in your journey to dark enlightenment."
The giant's real punishment was the fleeting moment when he was allowed to stand before being dragged down to his knees again.
"Of all the things that can be stolen, opportunity is the most valuable."
Dawnglove bloom is a potent nostrum, but the dawnglow brewed from its sap is nothing less than life itself.
Do not disturb.
The rivers can no longer provide safe passage for travelers and commerce. They serve only as highways for raiders and channels for blood and woe.

"His laugh, a bellowing, deathly din, slices through the heavens, making them bleed."
—The Seer's Parables

"He bears the marks of ages upon his skin, memories of dreams long dead and best left buried."
—The Seer's Parables
"Mana lurks in all things, even in the depths of one's own heart."
Vengeance in stampede form.
Some things aren't worth waiting for.
Awylla tried hard to forget the horrors she had seen, but someone else had developed a keen interest in them.
"The light of beauty protects our journeys through darkness."

They spawn from shadow, wreaking chaos until shadow claims them again.
One night Oona bottled the sky. The next night she aligned the stars and released it.
"All manner of curses, blights, and luckspoils infect Shadowmoor. We stalk them, one perilous quest at a time."

"Terrible wind. It whipped sparks into our skin, then stoked them even hotter!"
—Bowen, Barrenton guardcaptain
In the reflection, she saw the rough shell of the world sloughing away, revealing the truth shining underneath.
When night fell, the plane itself was scarred.
The line between dream and death is gauzy and fragile. She leads those too near it from one side to the other.
Untouched by the Aurora, Oona's faeries greeted the night like any other day.
"Verdant bloom does exist. It merely hides for its own safety."

"The cinders find strength in suffering, the elves in beauty. But if you make an elf suffer, he gets weaker. I wonder what happens if you make a cinder beautiful?"
—Hrugash, leech bonder

Gyara Spearhurler would have been renowned for her deadly accuracy, if it weren't for her deadly accuracy.
Many horrors take the bait of brave elf volunteers walking alone, only to fall to the blades of rescuers lurking nearby.

"Beware the merrows, whose envy and covetousness surpasses even that of the ravenous whirlpools where they dwell."

"Some secrets want to be revealed. They burst through the soil of their own accord."
—Dindun of Kulrath Mine

"The brethren shall blaze with unnatural fire, and the flame shall consume and purify our rage."
—Treefolk catastrophe myth

"Unsafe Terrain Ahead—Turn Back"
—Sign near the former location of Pyrtagh Cairn

"He is a ghost that has never known life."
—The Seer's Parables

Those who displease Oona soon learn the extent of the armies she commands.
Death stings the victim only once, but those left behind feel the pain of loss with every passing memory.

Each night, gloomwidows cull fresh prey for their ravenous hatchlings.

—Mowagh the Gwyllion

"What she saw crawling upon this world repulsed her. Yet she could not tear her gaze away."
—The Seer's Parables
Ordinary moths follow it, drawn to its light.

"Their sharp scales would make good armor, if they'd just stay dead."
—Taeryn, cinder armorkeep

Beware a scarecrow bearing gifts—especially sloshing vessels of acid.

Dreams of dark nights to come are said to stir in the minds of scheming hollowsages.

The murderous horrors of Raven's Run are legendary, but even that haunted place goes quiet when the night wolves howl.

Death is no excuse to stop working.
It is the harbinger of disease, not the carrier.
With heavy heart, Urza doused one world's light to rekindle another's.

"Our Mother! The sky was Her hair; the sun, Her face. She danced on the grass and in the hills."
—Song of All, canto 23

Do not judge a lizard by its size.
—Ghitu proverb

Who harnesses fire controls the world.
—Ghitu proverb
"Wonderful! You got a lion on your first try. Now put it back."

"My people are bound by masters centuries dead. Each artifact we destroy is another link broken in that chain."
—Barb Tail, viashino heretic
Hatred outlives the hateful.
"Left, right, left, right . . . hmm. Okay—left, left, left, left, . . ."
Not every cage is made of bars.
The goblins revered it; the viashino defended it. Only Urza understood it.
Junk heaps have rats, but scrapheaps have goblins.
The greatest gift is the opportunity to right one's wrongs.
To strike down the phoenix is to slash at the flame.
The Phyrexians' only interest in organic life is discerning its weakness.
Sometimes it's possible to pull a meal out of thin air.
These monkeys mean business.
Vark decided to lie down and think of a good excuse to quit working.
Good riddance.
Kerrick's corrupt domain swelled like a blister on Tolaria's skin.

"The harder you push, the stronger we become."
—Radiant, to Urza
It bites the hand that leads it.
Guarding the ship is the Thornwinds' first concern. Getting along with the locals ranks fourth or fifth at best.

"Every device in the rig is evidence of Thran enlightenment. All mana was the same to them, whether from rock or water, growth or decay. Can you imagine such unity of vision?"
—Urza, journal

"I wonder how it feels to be bored."
—Jhoira, artificer
"I would weep, but my tears have been stolen; I would shout, but my voice has been taken. Thus, I write."

"You cannot possibly know the toll your alliances will exact from you."
—Barrin, to Urza
Urza's wards fell from him like autumn leaves as he entered the dreaming grove. He awoke imprisoned in living wood.
From concept to paper to reality.

When the bey runs, match his stride.
—Viashino saying

"You guys go on ahead. I'll catch up with ya."
—Vark, goblin scout, last words
"The past is buried for good reason."
Awake and awing in the blink of an eye.
Not only does it catch fish, it cleans them too.
"My grandmother once told me the future of our world was inside the Weatherseed. When I touched it, I knew she was right."
Two days after the forge was completed, the faeries were immune to its flames.
"I'd like to buy a bowel."

"Argoth's doom rained from a clear sky. Yavimaya will not share that fate."
—Multani, maro-sorcerer
Each time the saw blade bit, the tree spat it out.
When the gorilla playfully grabbed the wurm's tail, the wurm doubled back and playfully ate the gorilla's head.
Some smiles show cheer; some merely show teeth.

"You can't get there from here. Well, you can—it just won't be fun."
—Ertai, wizard adept

"An innocent man died because of my anger. That knowledge will haunt me for all eternity."
—Karn, silver golem
As insubstantial, and as powerful, as the wind that carries it.

". . . The magician drew a ring off his finger . . . , saying: 'It is a talisman against all evil, so long as you obey me.'"
—The Arabian Nights,
Junior Classics trans.

"Not all minotaurs are tribal. Some are freelance."
—Eron the Relentless

"The shamans? Ha! They are craven cows not capable of true magic."
—Irini Sengir

"When you have been bitten with fangs of granite, you start to long for the ivory sabers of tigers."
—Norin the Wary

"My mother once told me angels sing their swords' names with each strike."
—Sisay, Captain of the Weatherlight
Some fight for honor and some for gold, but the militia fight for hearth and home.
Asked how it survived a run-in with a bog imp, the pegasus just shook its mane and burped.

"What you call decay, I call ripening. You'll gain no sustenance from this harvest."
—Kaervek
The Brothers' War scarred the land, but Ashnod left her mark in the bloodlines of those she tortured.

"Barbarian raids were a concern to those living in the northwest provinces, but the skyknights never dealt with the problem in a systematic way. They thought of the Balduvians as an ‘amusing model' of their forebears' culture."
—Kjeldor: Ice Civilization
Fire never dies alone.
"You are wrong," Volrath said. "I do not hate the living. They often prove quite useful to me." And then he laughed.
Don't be fooled by their looks. Think of them as little knives with wings.
Their stench was vile and strong enough, but not nearly as powerful as their hunger.
It moved through the troops leaving no footprints, save on their souls.

"The fishers will throw out their nets and draw them back filled with dust."
—Oracle en-Vec
A lie always returns; be careful how you catch it.

"Once great literature—now great litter."
—Jaya Ballard, task mage
Thinking of dinner made Squee realize that the forest was probably thinking the same thing.

"Hang out our banners on the outward walls; / The cry is still, ‘They come'; our castle's strength / Will laugh a siege to scorn."
—William Shakespeare, Macbeth
These stealthy felines have survived so many battles that some believe they must possess many lives.

"Temper, temper."
—Ertai, wizard adept

A rhino's bargain
—Femeref expression meaning
"a situation with no choices"

"Why do we trade with those despicable elves? You don't live in forests, you burn them!"
—Avram Garrisson,
Leader of the Knights of Stromgald

"Mold could catch you."
—Suq'Ata insult

"Dragonfire forged me a warrior."
—Rashida Scalebane

Pass me from soul to soul, / soldier to herder, herder to beast, beast to soil / until I am everywhere. / Then pass me those souls.
—Totem inscription (translated)
Avenant's archers are also trained as poets, so that each arrow is guided by a fragment of verse.
Bobbing merrily from opponent to opponent, the scimitar began adding playful little flourishes to its strokes; it even turned a couple of somersaults.

"And the flamingos said, ‘Get out of our nest—we can't be seen with the likes of you!' So, the griffin ate them."
—Azeworai, "The Ugly Bird"
In front of every great wizard is a doomed apprentice.

Up and down,
over and through,
back around—
the joke's on you.

"Big plants not only good for hidin', but full o' tasty bugs, too."
—Squee, goblin cabin hand

"Strength it has, but at the cost of a continuous supply of energy. Such failure can bear only one result."
—Execution order of Endrek Sahr,
master breeder
First the insult, then the injury.
Glory surged through her and radiance surrounded her. All things were possible with the blessing of the Divine.

"How is it the legged engines seem so much more alive than their wheeled counterparts? Simply, they were born, not made."
—Mishra

"With no further options, I was forced to don the mask."
—Rashida Scalebane

"These moonless, foreign skies keep me in thrall. Dark whispers echo in the night, and I cannot resist."
—Selenia, dark angel

Dreams' riches are easily spent.
—Suq'Ata adage

"The dead make good soldiers. They can't disobey orders, they never surrender, and they don't stop fighting when a random body part falls off."
—Nevinyrral, Necromancer's Handbook

"Wherever water is lacking, all things suffer."
—Autumn Willow

"Tonight we'll eat a farewell feast. Cold corn porridge is not enough. / Let's peel papayas, pineapples, and mangoes, drink coconut milk, / and bake bananas."
—"Love Song of Night and Day"

"My goat was a small price to pay for the chance to see the hunting griffin dive and seize it."
—Suq'Ata trader

"Did clouds dance in his eyes,
did thorns play at his fingertips?"
—Shesul Fass, faerie bard
Elves know where to harvest the best of the forest, for they planted it there themselves.

Sometimes it is better to be swift of foot than strong of swordarm.
—Elven proverb
"I tell you, there was so many arrows flying about you couldn't hardly see the sun. So I says to young Angus, ‘Well, at least now we're fighting in the shade!'"

"If it is weak, either kill it or ignore it. Anything else honors it."
—Kaervek

"I do not teach. I simply reveal."
—Daudi, Femeref tutor

"If I have learned anything as a wizard it is this: never fight your own battles."
—Waffa, sorcerer of Nyomba
The highway of fear is the shortest route to defeat.
"Angels are simply extensions of truth upon the fabric of life—and there is far more dark than light." —Baron Sengir

". . . and when the farmer awoke the next morning, all the seeds from his field were once again in their sacks."
—Afari, Tales

"I'd rather fight on foreign soil. That way, if I lose I can blame it on the terrain."
—Gerrard of the Weatherlight

"What is crueler? To let a wound of the heart fester, or to simply cut it out?"
—Crovax

"Could there be a fouler act? No doubt the baron knows of one."
—Autumn Willow

"They say a Zhalfirin archer can split the eye of a griffin. Nonsense, of course; they have no faith to guide their darts."
—Nuru, Femeref archer
Not all shadows are cast by light—some are cast by darkness.

"If your blood doesn't run hot, I will make it run in the sands!"
—Maraxus of Keld

Want all, lose all.
—Zhalfirin aphorism

Fire elementals are ruthless infernos, annihilating and consuming their foes in a frenzied holocaust. Crackling and blazing, they sear swift, terrible paths, leaving the land charred and scorched in their wake.

"Magic's only part of it, my friend. Diet does the rest."
—Suq'Ata trader

"Anger is fleeting; remorse is eternal."
—Karn, silver golem

"The spirit of the flame is the spirit of change."
—Lovisa Coldeyes,
Balduvian chieftain

"I've seen fog so thick you could cut it, but none that could cut me."
—Tahngarth of the Weatherlight

"I've been insulted by drunks in a hundred inns, but never as skillfully or annoyingly as by those blasted brownies."
—General Jarkeld, the Arctic Fox

"Do we know what we're doing? Yes—the will of Freyalise."
—Laina of the Elvish Council
It's not far into the trap, as the crow flies.

"O! it is excellent / To have a giant's strength, but it is tyrannous / To use it like a giant."
—William Shakespeare,
Measure for Measure

"Huge walls of ice block further travel. We can't believe they are natural."
—Disa the Restless, journal entry

"From down here we can make the whole wall collapse!"
"Uh, yeah, boss, but how do we get out?"

"When you're a goblin, you don't have to step forward to be a hero—everyone else just has to step back!"
—Biggum Flodrot, goblin veteran

"Next!"
"Goblins bred underground, their numbers hidden from the enemy until it was too late." —Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV

"In the soil of leadership sprout the seeds of immortality."
—Kaysa, Elder Druid of the Juniper
A full coffin is like a full coffer—both are attractive to thieves.

"There is no calamity greater than lavish desires. There is no greater guilt than discontentment. And there is no greater disaster than greed."
—Lao Tsu, Tao Te Ching, (trans. Chan)

Don't try to outrun one of Dominaria's grizzlies; it'll catch you, knock you down, and eat you. Of course, you could run up a tree. In that case you'll get a nice view before it knocks the tree down and eats you.

"One moment I was walking along the beach, and the next I was high in the air, staring into a hideous smiling face."
—Tarub, Suq'Ata sailor

"Archers, ballistae—you can't even get near the island of Avenant."
—Gerrard of the Weatherlight

"Destiny, chance, fate, fortune—they're all just ways of claiming your successes without claiming your failures."
—Gerrard of the Weatherlight

"So like men are they: a hardened shell with fragile flesh beneath."
—Selenia, dark angel
Anyone can get around a cyclops, but few can stand in its way.

"The true dishonor for a soldier is surviving the war."
—Telim'Tor

"But I signed nothing!"
—Taraneh, Suq'Ata mage
"Some have said there is no subtlety to destruction. You know what? They're dead." —Jaya Ballard, task mage

"We can fight with you or against you. After my day, I'd prefer the former."
—Gerrard of the Weatherlight

"Madness and genius are separated only by degrees of success."
—Sidar Jabari

"The raging waters had swept away trees, bridges, and even houses. My healers had much work to do."
—Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran priest

"Make people wait for what they want, and you have power over them. This is as true for merchants and militia as it is for cooks and couples."
—Gwendlyn Di Corci

"They shall drink sorrow's dregs. They shall kill those whom once they loved."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer

Honorable in battle, generous in death.
—Motto of the Kjeldoran Royal Guard
Slow and heavy swings the club.

"Bind me to thee, my soul to thine. I am your servant and your slave. Blood for blood, flesh for flesh, Leshrac, my lord."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer

"I do not miss sunlight. The very memory of it burns my eyes."
—Volrath

"Those who fear the darkness have never seen what the light can do."
—Selenia, dark angel

—Llanowar penalty for trespassing

"If it bears wings, I will pin it to the skies over Tefemburu."
—Roya, Zhalfirin archer

No two see the same Maro.
When the mighty sleep, the lowly prowl.

"Um . . . oh . . . what was I saying?"
—Reveka, wizard savant

"The faith of Serra is borne on wings of hope."
—Gulsen, abbey matron

The hardest of wizards can have the softest of minds.

"The past is a ghost that haunts you from the moment it exists until the moment you don't."
—Gerrard of the Weatherlight
Only the heroic and the mad follow mountain goat trails.

"To the tutors, a ‘poem of sand' was of little account, a ‘poem of ivory,' priceless."

Spring follows winter
—Elvish expression meaning
"all things pass"
As the poisoned land spreads, so does the nightmare's rage and terrifying strength.

"The foot stone is connected to the ankle stone, the ankle stone is connected to the leg stone . . . ."
—"Song of the Artificer"

A blazing light to drive out the shadows.

"It has been my honor to improve on the Thran's original design. Perhaps history will remember me in some small part for my work."
—Urza, in his apprenticeship

"It is terrible how one brief action can live forever in memory."
—Jolrael

"They knew Bantau was lost when, to hide the pearl he had found on the beach, he swallowed it—and soon grew wings."
—Hakim, Loreweaver

"There will come a time when the voices of soil and seedling will sing only laments."

"The secrets of Phyrexia are expensive. You will pay in brass and bone, steel and sinew."

"Ahh! Opposable digits!"

"A mysterious people indeed. Their origins are as secret as their traditions."
—Lord Magnus of Llanowar
Occasionally members of the Institute of Arcane Study acquire a taste for worldly pleasures. Seldom do they have trouble finding employment.

"Wealth is a good thing, compared to poverty—your food is better, your robes are softer, and your companions have bathed more recently."

"The memory of your existence will fade like the final stars of morning."
—Kaervek

"Hi!ni!ya! Behold the man of flint, that's me! / Four lightnings zigzag from me, strike and return."
—Navajo war chant

Rath forces plants from its surface as one presses whey from cheese.

"Men and rats both hunger: we for our playthings; they, for us."
—Crovax

Unicorns don't care if you believe in them any more than you care if they believe in you.

"Barrin taught me that the hardest lessons to grasp are the ones you've already learned."
—Ertai, wizard adept

"Flog and Squee / Up the tree / See the army / Flee, flee, flee."
—Goblin nursery rhyme/war cry

"These things will protect you while I'm gone, remind you of my love for you."
—"Love Song of Night and Day"

"The meek shall fight as one, and they shall overcome even the greatest of foes."
—Halvor Arenson, Kjeldoran priest

"My soldiers fought without hesitation, died without doubt."
—Sidar Jabari

"But no one heard the snake's gentle hiss for peace over the elephant's trumpeting of war."
—Afari, Tales

"I've dreamt of a second harvest but fear I will not see it."
—Asmira, holy avenger

"I fear anything with teeth measured in handspans!"
—Norin the Wary

Healers ultimately acquire the divine gifts of spiritual and physical wholeness. The most devout are also granted the ability to pass physical wholeness on to others.

"Flourishing during the Ice Age, these wurms were the bane of all Kjeldorans. Their great size and ferocity made them the subject of countless nightmares—they embodied the worst of the Ice Age."
—Kjeldor: Ice Civilization

"They groaned, they stirred, they all uprose,
Nor spake, nor moved their eyes;
It had been strange, even in a dream,
To have seen those dead men rise."
—Samuel Coleridge,
"The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"
Water is life. Or perhaps it is just something to wash it down with.

"Leviathan, too! Can you catch him with a fish-hook or run a line round his tongue?"
—The Bible, Job 41:1

"Just think of me as the storm before the calm."
—Gerrard of the Weatherlight

"I have seen your strength imbued in angels' wings, and I have felt your sorrow rain down on the ruins brought by the Lord of the Wastes."
—Hanna, Weatherlight navigator

Chains of leaping fire and sizzling lightning laid waste the artificers' handiwork, sparing not a single device.

Lightning tethers souls to the world.
—Kor saying

"What manner of fiend would design such a sadistic device?"
—Sorine Relicbane, Soldevi heretic

"Uh, does anyone have a flute?"
—Rana, Suq'Ata market fool

"To hide the truth is more than folly—it is fatal."
—Sorine Relicbane, Soldevi heretic
Call it the thinking mage's version of brute force.
It prefers its meals cooked.

"There are times solid ground gives precious little comfort."
—Talibah, embermage
In the Jamuraan jungles, there is often no separating beauty from danger.
The less you have, the harder you fight for it.

"Hold your position! Leave doubt for the dying!"
—Tahngarth of the Weatherlight

Storm crow descending, winter unending.
Storm crow departing, summer is starting.

"I have seen the night torn into thin darkling strips and woven into shapes too bleak for dreams."
—Crovax
When the alliance between Balduvia and Kjeldor deprived Stromgald of easy victories, its agents were forced to fuel their rituals with their own flesh.

There are medicines for all afflictions but idleness.
—Suq'Ata saying
Summer sends its kiss with warmth and blooming life.

"There is no sweeter music than the wails of a dying dragon."
—Rashida Scalebane

Don't insult a Talruum unless your mount is swift.
—Suq'Ata saying
Mouths and wings beyond numbering, but a single mind to guide them.
Moss-covered statues littered the area, a macabre monument to the basilisk's terrible power.

"It is nature that gives us our boundaries and nature that enforces them."
—Eladamri, Lord of Leaves
These are its last days. Better to grow broad and heavy. Better that the enemy is crushed beneath its carcass.

"Where do you run when the earth becomes your enemy?"
—Naimag, Femeref philosopher
I heard their eerie howling, the wolves calling their kindred across the frozen plains.

"Is it true that the apes wear furs of gold when they marry?"
—Rana, Suq'Ata market fool

"To pass through the jungle: silence, courtesy, ferocity, as the occasion demands."
—Kamau, "Proper Passage"
The griffin's shadow gives courage to the righteous and dread to the idle.

"I write upon clean white parchment with a sharp quill and the blood of my students, divining their secrets."
—Shauku, Endbringer
His presence brings not only a strong arm but also renewed hope.
Some say magic was first practiced by women, who have always felt strong ties to the land.

"I saw the wizard gesturing, but I didn't guess his plan until my aesthir cried out and went into a dive."
—Arna Kennerüd, skyknight

"When traveling the Great Desert avoid wearing the scales of lizards, for the Viashino rule the sands and look poorly on the skinning of their cousins."
—Zhalfirin Guide to the Desert

"After waking to the magic of Llanowar, no dreams can compare."
—Mirri of the Weatherlight

"Vodalian rank is displayed by the colors and patterns of their skin. Beware the color red; that is the badge of the empress's favor."
—Corbio, pearl diver
Speed and fire are always a deadly combination.

My thunder comes before the lightning; my lightning comes before the clouds; my rain dries all the land it touches. What am I?
—Femeref riddle
The trees have ears, eyes, and teeth.

When no falcons fly, beware the sky.
—Femeref aphorism

"Struggle, and you will only fan the flames."
—Talibah, embermage
Sharper than wind, lighter than air.
You'll never miss what you never had.

"Flame grows gentle with but a little distance."
—Orim, Samite healer

"Too much work—it takes a long time to break them in, and more than a few recruits."
—Grebog, goblin swine-rider

"No bird soars too high, if he soars with his own wings."
—William Blake,
The Marriage of Heaven and Hell

" . . . When the trees bow down their heads,

—Christina Rossetti,
"Who Has Seen the Wind?"

"Aselbo soon had the rhino eating from his palm and the snake waiting at his heels."
—Afari, Tales

"When one wolf calls, others follow. Who wants to fight creatures that eat scorpions?"
—Maimun al-Wyluli, diary
He controlled the zombies even before his own death; now nothing can make them betray him.

"Rage courses in every heart, yearning to betray its rational prison."
—Sarkhan Vol
Such loyalty can only be made.
"The universe is my instrument, and the song I play upon it is one you are forbidden to hear."

"We hold sacred the powers of light and life. Truth and honor are our greatest weapons."
—Alabaster creed
She lures victims with promises of flesh, captures them in a net of deceit, and destroys them in the embrace of the sea.

"The amphin have long built their society in secret. While surface dwellers squabbled over trivial borders, they patiently expanded, building their ammonite temple-caves. Now amphin priests eye the shore, and amphin hunters gird for war."
—Gor Muldrak, Cryptohistories
The angel represents divine perfection; even the smallest feather is imbued with beauty and benevolence.
Angels appear before both the blessed and the cursed, though most don't know which they are until they feel either the angel's kiss or her sword.
There are few things as satisfying as a good, healthy thunk.
In dark times, Truth bears a blade.

"When we of the Northern Verge claim a mount, no peasant's nag will do. It must be as strong as our virtue, and must join us of its own will."
—Sarlena, paladin of the Northern Verge

"Griffins do not serve. They give freely to those they trust."
—Amira, skycaptain of Thune
"In memories, we can find our deepest reserves of strength."
The rustling of leaves and a passing shadow are a dryad's only trace.

"It was too fast, even for our veteran archers. They might as well have been blowing it kisses."
—Vulok, elvish archer

"We draw our power from the infinite ocean of the mind, where all manner of things can be conceived."
—Azure creed
"One day I will rest and join my comrades in the afterlife, but not while scum like you still sully this world."

"The gods used their feathers to paint all the colors of the world."
—Yare-Tiva, warden of Gramur forest
A drop now is all he needs to find you later.
The most genteel facades hide the most abominable desires.
One thing's for sure—his fists are harder than your skull.

"When we fail to see the beauty in every tree, we are no better than humans."
—Saelia, elvish scout

"Tell the cooks to prepare the fires. Tonight we feast!"
—Tolar Wolfbrother, Krosan tracker

"When you find yourself teetering on the edge of oblivion, mine will be the hands taking pleasure in giving you the final push."
—Liliana Vess
History has buried its treasures deep.

"A world without evil? Boring. Give me vile fiends to smite and banish any day."
—Sarlena, paladin of the Northern Verge
Every grave cradles a recruit.
Chandra never believed in using her "inside voice."

"Once he's got you, hold on. Fall from a drake and you'll suffer much worse than a bruise."
—Garl, drake trainer
Sins that would be too gruesome in the light of day are made more pleasing in the dark of night.

"Which do you think is a better deterrent: a moat of water or one of fire?"
—Chandra Nalaar

"You clerics brag about your strength of spirit, yet I take away the tiniest fragment, and you crumple like a rag doll."
—Sorin Markov

"We wield the fires of rage. War is our blood and destruction our birthright."
—Crimson creed

"With this crown, assert your authority."
—Crown inscription
When he began to curse what he held holy, his strength grew unrivaled.

"Let the final vision of doom be etched upon their unblinking eyes."
—Zul Ashur, lich lord
Its curve mimics the twists of life and death.
Behind every mage is a trail of shattered lies.
Their arrival is heralded by the deafening hum of ten thousand wings. Their departure is marked by the silence of the dead.
The wise always keep an ear open to the whispers of power.

"Stop complaining. You can rest when you're dead. Oh—sorry."
—Liliana Vess
"Of course I'm sure I've gone mad. The little man who crawled out of my eye was quite clear on this."
