"The hypocrisy of these elves is thicker than steel—destroying ‘unnatural metal' with their own enchanted swords."
—Kara Vrist, Neurok agent
Lost to time is the artificer's art of trapping light from a distant star in a ring of purest gold.

"Birth and death are both reversible."
—Nicol Bolas
It's the only water source in miles of desert, but the local tribes avoid it at all costs.

"Some think its immunity to countermagic evolved because of the constant mage attacks on Naya. I think it just ate a bunch of wizards."
—Broka, drumhunter
No one has properly answered her favorite riddle: "Why should I spare your life?"
Disaster stalks with gaping jaws across unready lands.
Knowledge brings the sting of disillusionment, but the pain teaches perspective.
The vast network of predation on Jund has actually caused some strange creatures to adapt to being eaten.
Something roams the killing places, sniffing the guilt of the slayers, stalking them on iron paws.
Ever since the disaster, the city's survivors viewed the star-strewn sky with dread.
"Plans evolved within the tent decide a victory 1,000 li away."
The assassin sees only throats and hears only heartbeats.
In the Skyfang Mountains, one misstep can mean the end of an entire clan.
Enlightenment is not gained by striking the bell or hearing its toll. It's found in the silence that follows.
Those who bring nothing to the temple take nothing away.
It lives in the mountaintops, feeds at the mountains' feet, and kills anything it finds on the path between.

"Etherium is limited. Innovation is not."
—Tezzeret
Guarding the ship is the Thornwinds' first concern. Getting along with the locals ranks fourth or fifth at best.
Paradoxically, to tilt the massive jug for a sip, you'd need the energy of the giant's tonic.
His name means "he who paints the earth red."
Jort the Thunder-Mad spent his life perfecting a way to harness the power of the heavens.

"Do not speak the name of the sea, for if it should hear you and rise up, no fortress in the world could hide you."
—Gimara of Halimar
The scullers beneath Esper keep strixes as trained pets, and set them loose when a fare refuses to pay.

"You deify nature as female—kind and gentle—yet you cringe at what is natural."
—Mirri of the Weatherlight

"Esper, like any work of art, can be truly appreciated only from a distance."
—Tezzeret
The ur-golem etchings begin by celebrating Mirrodin's creator, a golem of almost limitless power. They end by cursing its protector, a being called Memnarch.

"It's a difficult task to quarantine a plague that moves with the clouds."
—Esara, healer adept
Once you've been dragged down the currents of time, you'll never quite trust your own permanence again.

"Though their ideals are leagues apart, Urza's and Mishra's creations have a surprising harmony with one another."
—Tocasia, journal entry
In matters of life and death, he trusts his gut.
"This may hurt a lot."
"I could see in the other mage's eyes that he'd thought of it too. Then it became a race to exploit the knowledge first."
In the autumn, she casts her seeds across the streets below, and come spring, her children rise in service to the Conclave.
The lives of elves are long, but their memories are longer. Even after death, they do not desert their homes.
The rhythm isn't a call to arms, but a signal that the goblins have made a new enemy.
"Listen to the roar! Feel the thunder! The Immersturm shouts its approval with every bolt of lightning!"

"It's not the darkness I fear but dull and numbing shades of gray."
—Sydri, galvanic genius
It is the forest beyond the horizon, the mountain waiting to be climbed, the new land across the endless sea.
Some say the knowledge lost during the Ritual of Rebuking is returned through the well's waters.

"Never subtle nor cryptic is the reckoning of the mighty."
—Mayael the Anima

"How thin is the veneer of civilization! A modest measure of panic will wash it off completely."
—Guard Erdrud of An Karras
Even the lost and undead need a protector.

"May your day never match your expectations."
—Scriptus Fleen, flectomancer
The nacatl called this new species "vetli," their word for poison arrows.
The accusations spread like hungry flames.

"The awestruck birds gazed at Wonder. Slowly, timidly, they rose into the air."
—Scroll of Beginnings

"It remains unclear whether the akki shamans could in fact create storms or simply predicted them."
—The History of Kamigawa
Akki were very territorial, attacking and destroying any settlements that came too close to their mountain homes. The more successful their raids, the bolder they became.
There was a dull thunder at the vanguard, then shocked cries in the midst of the column. Moments later, Takada, last of the rearguard, faced the kami alone.

"The two youths argued and tempers flared. One youth opened his mouth to utter a vile curse, but what he spat out instead was a kami of poison and filth."
—Sensei Golden-Tail

"The soratami scoff at the perils of Jukai, calling the forest an ‘unruly garden.' Perhaps we should send them a rose such as this."
—Dokai, Weaver of Life

"As the war progressed, the destruction the kami caused became more widespread and less predictable."
—Observations of the Kami War

"Rise like the sun, stand like the mountain, charge like the lion, die as a hero."
—General Takeno
"Crease the folds, bend the paper, turn the spirits, shield the soul."

"The race is run in the mind before the first step is taken."
—Dosan the Falling Leaf

"The clashing warriors turned to face O-Kagachi, the greatest kami, and their sigh of awe was their last breath."
—Great Battles of Kamigawa

"We searched their bodies for signs of the blades that had killed them, but found nothing more than scorched flesh."
—Tender-Hand, kitsune healer
Many ogres extracted blood oaths from the oni they summoned. Others simply extracted blood.
"Such a small thing, a drop of water . . . And yet enough of them together can flood a field, cleanse a mire, or choke a forest."
Mountain ogres allowed blizzards to sheathe them in ice, both to reinforce their armor and to hide their pungent musk from potential prey.
Its bite will take off more than a toe.

"On the fifty-seventh day of the Battle of Silk, the bell again tolled in hopes of summoning mortal aid. This time, a new breed of kami rose to answer its call."
—Great Battles of Kamigawa
Akki shells provided good protection when downhill charging became headlong tumbling.
Listen at its walls and you will hear the whispers of gods.
card: Gods' Eye, Gate to the Reikai

flavor:
"There is a shining in the mortal heart that even the kami cannot reach."
—Sensei Golden-Tail
Hidetsugu held over a dozen oni in blood oath. At his touch, rocks scorched. At his word, cities burned.
"Once, I looked to the mists for wisdom. Now I wish only for understanding."

"What will it say on our graves, Lord Konda? Will it say we led our world to conquer immortal forces or that we were crushed by our own arrogance? At each defeat, I wonder."
—Sensei Hisoka, letter to Lord Konda

"In desperation, Konda sent warriors to parley with the ogre-magi. No one knows whether they were slaughtered at Shinka or if they even reached its bloodstained walls."
—Observations of the Kami War
"Forgive me, Saburo. I could not save you. But your blade will not rest in my hand."

"Thunder broke the brittle silence over the Araba. A surge of raw energy lifted the soldier's body into the air and briefly, in the heart of the flash, he saw the face of a god."
—Great Battles of Kamigawa

"I do not care if he claims no allegiance in this war. Find him, Takeno."
—Lord Konda

"Here fell Ishi-Ishi, King of the Flaming Pebbles, Scourge of the Mountain Kami, Lover of Goats. May his shell never burn."
—Cave inscription
The bolt struck with a flash and there was a terrible sound, as of glass shattering, but the creature was unharmed.
When it's finished, all that's left of you is a ripple on a still pond.

"Across the rift of battle, a bridge of gossamer. And for one moment, it holds."
—Snow-Fur, kitsune poet
It remembered all the shadows lantern-cast upon its paper wings, and sometimes those silhouettes played across its shape again, acting out silent tragedies.
"The bonds of bushido will draw the dishonored back someday, and I will be there waiting."
Each spell is an intricate tapestry, and Kira is the great unraveler.
"Who am I to judge who is deserving and who is not? That is a question for lords, not healers."

"Kyoki, Eater of Minds, Corrupter of Thoughts, Bringer of Madness, Lord of Fear. Return, by our blood, and walk again."
—Ogre chant

"Walk the world and you'll find your soul; search your soul and you'll discover the world."
—Diary of Azusa

"The husk splits like a madman's smile
And mystery steps forth."
—Snow-Fur, kitsune poet

"You know its mood by the plants that spring up around it. When it is placid, fields of lilies flow in its wake; when it is angry, every stem has a thorn."
—Isao, Enlightened Bushi

"Early in his reign, Konda fell ill. His head burned with fever, and he saw visions of his future. In them, he saw a spirit-child, and, in that child's eyes, a way to make his empire last forever."
—The History of Kamigawa

"As more oni walked Kamigawa, more darkness infested its inhabitants' souls."
—The History of Kamigawa

"I can staunch their blood, mend their flesh, and knit their bones. But I cannot restore their hope."
—Tender-Hand, kitsune healer
Woven from threads of the spirit world, the mistcloak rendered its wearer invisible, but quickly fell to tatters.
Like storm water through the segments of bamboo, the spell followed the links of magic. Then it destroyed them.
Only in mirrors do heroes find their equal.

"The Okiba Gang! Night-cursed thieves and assassins! I've had enough of their meddling! Triple the guard!"
—Marrow-Gnawer
Once freed, the oni demanded more and more sacrifices to appease them. The ogres happily obliged.

"Those ogres who did not embrace oni worship were cast out, cursed, and forced into hermitage, waiting for the day the oni would come for them."
—The History of Kamigawa

"Behind the eyelids, a flickering flame.
Beneath the dream, a flickering sorrow.
Can peace find you in this sleep
When all the world is tossed by war?"
—Snow-Fur, kitsune poet
Masako was privy to a great many of Konda's deepest secrets, and her hair was always perfect.
Her angry call split the sky. From that rift descended her champions.
Many kami could fly, which put some warriors at a distinct disadvantage. The mages of Minamo took it upon themselves to correct that imbalance.

"The wizards of Takenuma Swamp faced the horrors of humanity every day. It's no wonder they fared so well against the kami."
—Observations of the Kami War

"This world is a dream. We cling to our toys like children, but sooner or later we must learn to live without them."
—Sensei Hisoka

"If wisdom is a river, then we cup our hands, reach in, and drink from it in sips. The kami, however, are like fish, swimming, breathing, surrounded in its presence."
—Dosan the Falling Leaf

"Say, what rhymes with ‘run for your lives'?"
—Ku-Ku, akki poet

"Where a once-proud human city stood, only the ruins of Numai remain, deep amid rotting bamboo and plagued by oni."
—The History of Kamigawa
A child's whisper could crack its shell, but not even an oni's scream could penetrate it.

"Understanding is not a virtue of the ogre. Do not seek to reason your way into Shinka Keep."
—Kiku, Night's Flower

"One scratch on a wall meant safe passage, two that the target had already been raided, and three warned of a trap."
—Weaponry of Kamigawa
"I wish there were no use for those with my talents. I wish that I could walk Kamigawa forgotten and unneeded, with no war wounds to heal and no broken bones to mend."

"Your lungs may not draw breath, but while your hands can grip a sword, you will be useful to me."
—Nighteyes, nezumi necromancer

"All things return to their beginnings. The waters that spill across the Kamitaki Falls flow to sea, only to be returned to her as the rain that joins the mighty river."
—Dosan the Falling Leaf
At night he perfected his aim, shooting spiderwebs by starlight.
"I prefer to weave my magic through oni blood, but yours will do in a pinch."
Isolated on its little candlewick, the kami never heard of the crime that drove its comrades to war.

"Do not fall into the trap of thinking you understand the kami. Cannot a drop of water be dew on the meadow, a glacier's thaw, or the tear of a child?"
—Sensei Hisoka

"The jeweler, the potter, the smith . . . They all imbue a bit of their souls into their creations. The kami destroy that crafted mortal shell and absorb the soul within."
—Noboru, master kitemaker
It was as though the sky opened its eyes and found what it saw displeasing.

"This god held prisoner in human hands has put all humanity in the hands of angry gods."
—Masako the Humorless

"Over time, Konda grew ever more suspicious, fearing even his most loyal allies were being manipulated by unseen hands."
—The History of Kamigawa

"As the kami passed over the village of Mita, the inhabitants relived their three most grievous tragedies. Some cried. Some raged. Some were driven to madness. But the next morning, none possessed the will to fight."
—Observations of the Kami War

"The war sent Kamigawa into turmoil. Here it was spring and there winter. For some, time stood still, while for others, moments flashed past like minnows in a pond."
—Observations of the Kami War

"That energy was once granted to growing things. Now the kami keep it for themselves, releasing it in sudden floods that overwhelm flesh and foliage alike."
—Sakiko, Mother of Summer

"We arrived at the battlefield too late. Again. Another error on your part, and you will have to answer to me personally."
—General Takeno, letter to the imperial mapmaker
Reluctant to strike at the kami directly, some kitsune trained in more passive fighting techniques.

"As I died, I rejoiced. I would see my family again. But then I woke up back on the battlefield. Back in Kamigawa. Back in hell."
—Kenzo the Hardhearted

It took ninety-nine monks to weave the spell that trapped Yukora. Upon the death of the ninety-nine, the spell was broken, and the demon returned to the mortal world seeking vengeance for its imprisonment.

"Learn not only from the failures of the past, but also from its triumphs."
—Isperia
"You can come back once you've learned some manners—and figured out how to reconstitute your physical forms."
"Oathbreaker, I cast you out!"

"You were defeated the moment you declared your aggression."
—Gideon Jura

"Nature was slowly heading in the right direction, but we know how to achieve faster results."
—Vorel of the Hull Clade
"The Boros fight for justice. The Azorius fight for law. I hold the line between, and make sure the people are given both."

"The people of Akros must learn from our leonin adversaries. If we match their staunch ferocity with our superior faith, we cannot fail."
—Cymede, queen of Akros

"In our war Heliod gave mortals some favor, yet other times he withheld aid. Are we still no more than game pieces to him?"
—Polyxene the Doubter
Without the interfering hands of civilization, nature will always shape itself to its own needs.

"I will never run out of new oceans to explore or new sea-dwellers to embrace as my own."
—Kiora
Torching Krosa would be pointless. It grows faster than it burns.

"Don't be fooled. If it were as docile as it looks, it would've died off long ago."
—Yon Basrel, Oran-Rief survivalist
Banking steeply, the aven streaked toward the ground—and vanished.

"Our death-arrows flew in high arcs towards the aven. And then . . . nothing."
—Coliseum guard
Entire platoons have mysteriously vanished from battle, leaving enemy weapons to slice through empty air.
They're trained in the art of pressing their luck.

"Into its maw went the seventh sea, never to be seen again while the world remains."
—Esper fable
"If a boggart even dares breathe near one of my kin, I'll know. And I'll not be happy."
"She may call herself Kiora but I believe she is Thassa, the embodiment of the sea and empress of the depths."
"Sometimes I snare the unexpected, but I know its purpose will be revealed in time."

"The enlightenment I never found in etherium I have found traced in the coatl's scales."
—Ranalus, vedalken heretic

"On every plane I've encountered loxodons, I've found stalwart and loyal friends."
—Elspeth

"Beauty to the eye does not always translate to the touch."
—Naimah, Femeref philosopher

"The southern fortress taken by invaders? Heh, sure . . . when elephants fly."
—Brezard Skeinbow, captain of the guard

"Such deeds should be common fare for such as us."
—Anax, king of Akros
She will not touch a weapon, yet she is the greatest protector her people have ever known.
It's not the two heads you should fear. It's the four fangs.
It is an expert at culling individuals who stray too far from the herd.
The Simic soon discovered that the sky offered as few constraints on size as the sea.
Her prophecies amaze her even as she speaks them.
"Soulless demon, you are bound to me. Now we will both dwell in oblivion."

"Everything serves a purpose. Even you."
—Vorel of the Hull Clade
"In troubled times, we all need someone to watch our back."
Like blinking or breathing, responding to an alarm is an involuntary reflex.

"We've bred out the shortcomings of the species' natural form and replaced them with assets of our own design."
—Momir Vig

"I was called to this world of steel, and it will be my steel that answers."
—Elspeth

"Bant sentries were called the Angel Line. They never faltered, and they were ready to die defending their position."
—Elspeth

"It's easy for the innocent to speak of justice. They seldom feel its terrible power."
—Orim, Samite inquisitor
Surrakar grab things they don't want.

"When gods become apathetic, the people will worship anyone who answers their pleas."
—Kiora
As the Simic released more of their krasis experiments, they required new habitats, always at the expense of the locals.
"Courage is a proud and gleaming shield. It does not bend or hide from sight. To fight with courage, we must forge in steel."
"Truth is a straight, keen edge. There are no soft angles or rounded edges. To fight for truth, we must forge in steel."

"I can see why this appeals to Thassa."
—Kiora
"Many must die for the one who should not have perished."
Izzet mages often acquire their magic reagents from dubious sources, so the potency of their spells is never predictable.
There is always a greater power.

"Leshrac, my liege, grant me the power I am due."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer
"We could no more abandon the forest than the stars could abandon the night sky."
Over such beauty, wars are fought. With such power, wars are won.
As the green sun crowned, Phyrexian prophecies glowed on the Tree of Tales.
The priests plead for your anguish and pray for your despair.
"You call it luck. I call it preparation."
When a werewolf changes for the first time, that first howl is said to echo through the wilds till moonset.
The smallest seed of regret can bloom into redemption.
Urza's metathran children were conceived, birthed, and nurtured by an integrated system of machines.
His marvels of artifice pale in comparison to the developing machinery of his mind.
Each flower identical, every leaf and petal disturbingly exact.
To gaze under its hood is to invite death.

"Rage courses in every heart, yearning to betray its rational prison."
—Sarkhan Vol

"The East Wind, an interloper in the dominions of Westerly Weather, is an impassive-faced tyrant with a sharp poniard held behind his back for a treacherous stab."
—Joseph Conrad, The Mirror of the Sea
His soul snared by an angel's curse, Crovax twisted heroism into its purest shadow.
For Sarkhan Vol, the dragon is the purest expression of life's savage splendor.

"Before armor, there was bark. Before blades, there were thorns."
—Molimo, maro-sorcerer
Boggarts divide the world into two categories: things you can eat, and things you have to chase down and pummel before you can eat.
Early Jamuraan hunters devised a weapon that would return to its source. Tolarian Æthermancers developed a spell that skipped the weapon entirely.
"If the whole world burns, I'll never grow cold."
"These alleys are not safe. Come, I can guide you back to the market square."
The delicate sprites carry messages for Saprazzans, but they refuse to land in Mercadia City's filthy markets.
A banner for bonds of blood or belief.
They envy the life-giving heat so much that they tear it from those who still possess it.

"From the sea came all life, and to the sea it will return. The sooner the better."
—Emperor Aboshan
Its curve mimics the twists of life and death.
According to merfolk legend, a denizen of the deep swallows the horizon at the end of each day, bringing on the cold blanket of night.
Though no longer attached to the hand, it still holds its adversary in its grasp.
"The light of beauty protects our journeys through darkness."

"The dead make good soldiers. They can't disobey orders, never surrender, and don't stop fighting when a random body part falls off."
—Nevinyrral, Necromancer's Handbook
Imps are just intelligent enough to have an understanding of cruelty.

Earth elementals have the eternal strength of stone and the endurance of mountains. Primordially connected to the land they inhabit, they take a long-term view of things, scorning the impetuous haste of short-lived mortal creatures.
"Wirewood cannot hide great size. Only with speed and skill can we survive here."

"For what are leaves but countless blades
To fight a countless foe on high."
—Elvish hymn
"No matter how adept our artistic skill, our effigies can never hope to capture the vibrant beauty of a living elf. Perhaps that is truly why we mourn."
The faultless and immaculate castes form the lower tiers of elvish society, with the exquisite caste above them. At the pinnacle is the perfect, a consummate blend of aristocrat and predator.
Before any major undertaking, a Cylian elf seeks the guidance of a visionary to learn the will of the gargantuan ancients.
As graceful as a deer leaping a stream and as deadly as the wolf waiting in ambush on the other side, elvish warriors are the eyes of the forest as well as its unsheathed claws.
The barbarians call it "touching the soul of the dragon."

"The elves are right: Death inevitably leads to life. But the truly powerful don't just experience this cycle. They control it."
—Crovax, ascendant evincar
Some wizards compete not to summon the most interesting creatures, but to create the most interesting aftereffects when a summons goes awry.

"Once I supply the breeze, you'll see your warriors for the smoke they truly are."
—Alexi, zephyr mage

"Those without beauty are Lorwyn's greatest tumor. The winnowers have an unpleasant duty, but a necessary one."
—Eidren, perfect of Lys Alana
The furnace awaits the next master who would stoke the fires of apocalypse.
"Gaea sings with the voice of nature rampant: a thousand howls, chitters, and cries, and none of them can be ignored."
The giant spider's silk naturally resists gravity, almost weaving itself as it blankets the forest canopy.
Once he'd worked out which end of the thing was sharp, he was promoted to guard duty.
The goblin word for "flying" is more accurately translated as "falling slowly."
The other tribes call them fanatics, but none deny that the Mul Daya elves have an iron-strong bond to some force greater than themselves.
Fortunately, hill giants have large blind spots in which a human can easily hide. Unfortunately, these blind spots are beneath the bottoms of their feet.
The murderous horrors of Raven's Run are legendary, but even that haunted place goes quiet when the night wolves howl.
Elves of the immaculate class weave flora into living creatures—sometimes to endorse an elite warrior, sometimes to create a breathing work of art.
In a culture of beauty, the most beautiful are worshipped as gods.

"Yes, I think ‘toast' is an appropriate description."
—Jaya Ballard, task mage
In times when freedom seems lost, great souls arise to reclaim it.
Bright as a mirror, dark as the sea.

"A flash of the lightning, a break of the wave,
He passes from life to his rest in the grave."
—William Knox, "Mortality"
From the highest tiers of Dawn's Light Palace to the deepest shade of Wren's Run, the silver notes of the horn shimmer through the air, and all who hear it feel its pull.
Of royal blood among the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.

"It's a vicious circle. Stress breeds pain. Pain breeds stress. It's simply beautiful, wouldn't you agree?"
—Vradeen, vampire nocturnus

"Why fight the body when you can dominate the mind that rules it?"
—Jace Beleren

"The beauty of mental attacks is that your victims never remember them."
—Volrath
Dark thoughts hatch and twist within the mind, straining to take wing.
Fragments of thought refract and multiply, surging in a geyser of dizzying insight.
Winnowers live to eliminate eyeblights, creatures the elves deem too ugly to exist.

"Jewels cannot be eaten nor gold drunk. What civilization trades, nature simply provides."
—Molimo, maro-sorcerer
If you want to destroy something lifeless, make it live.
Like nature, the fern spirals back on itself, eternally seeking its own center.
Masters of the arcane savor a delicious irony. Their study of deep and complex arcana leads to such a simple end: the ability to say merely yes or no.

"The construction of a defense is not accomplished by adding bricks."
—Jace Beleren
"What am I looking at? Ashes, dead man."
Vengeance is a dish best served twice.
Nature grows solutions to its problems.
Nothing is sacred to rats. Everything is simply another meal.
Bears aren't always as strong and as mean as you imagine. Some are even stronger and meaner.
Empires rise and fall, but evil is eternal.
No one in Aphetto answers a knock at the door after sundown.
The undisputed master of the mountains of Shiv.

"Once I saw a goblin shouting at a thunderstorm. He lost the argument pretty quickly."
—Wandering mage
Foul-tempered, poorly trained, and mule-stubborn, the drake is the perfect test of the master's will.
Its spines act like the teeth of a saw, scoring distinctive marks in the vegetation of its territory.
Other birds collect twigs for their nests. Magpies collect jewels for theirs.
Armodons are trained to step on things. Enemy things.

"In the drowsy dark cave of the mind, dreams build their nest with fragments dropped from day's caravan."
—Rabindranath Tagore

"Born under the moon, the second child will stumble on temptation and seek power in the dark places of the heart."
—Codex of the Constellari
Mages routinely summon creatures from the Æther. It's only fair that they occasionally throw one back.
Left to itself, nature overflows any container, overthrows any restriction, and overreaches any boundary.

"A stick is your friend. A pointed stick is your good friend. An army of pointed sticks is your best friend."
—Onean sergeant
Orcish lumberjacks spent the night sharpening their blades and resting for a day of labor. They awoke to find that the forest had been making its own preparations.
A wurm knows nothing of deception. If it opens its mouth, it plans to eat you.

"Through the haze of battle I saw the glint of sun on golden mane, the sheen of glory clad in mail, and I dropped my sword and wept at the idiocy of war."
—Dravin, Gruul deserter
The scrape of shovels and the tumble of cold dirt soon muffled their pleas.
Those who forget the horrors of the past are doomed to re-meet them.

"Don't worry. I'm not going to deprive you of all your secrets. Just your most precious one."
—Liliana Vess
A grave is the safest place to store ill-gotten treasures.

"Death—an outmoded concept. We sleep, and we change."
—Sitrik, birth priest
If the presence of evil were obvious, it wouldn't be nearly as dangerous.

"Into its maw went the seventh sea, never to be seen again while the world remains."
—Esper fable

"You will learn to earn death."
—Volrath
The Patriarch dreams of vile plague.
No one has properly answered her favorite riddle: "Why should I spare your life?"
Left to itself, nature overflows any container, overthrows any restriction, and overreaches any boundary.
The nomads' funeral pyres are more practical than ceremonial.

"Course he ran! I wouldn't want to stare down that barrel, either!"
—Alaborn soldier
The mysterious purpose of two of the rings had eluded Esper mages—until now.
Boggarts divide the world into two categories: things you can eat, and things you have to chase down and pummel before you can eat.
In the erupting heart of Bogardan, it's hard to tell hurtling volcanic rocks from pouncing volcanic beasts.
"Kills and cooks your food in one easy stroke."

"The smell of roasted flesh hung over the valley for hours."
—Onean sergeant
"Swords may sunder. Shields may fail. My will is stronger than steel, and my flesh and bone far more deadly."
Goblins journey to the sacrificial peaks in pairs so that the rare survivor might be able to relate the details of the other's grisly demise.
Though no longer attached to the hand, it still holds its adversary in its grasp.
"We speak the dragons' language of flame and rage. They speak our language of fury and honor. Together we shall weave a tale of destruction without equal."
"At harvest are seeds of next year sown."
Jund feasts on the unprepared.

"My ears say it hisses. My fingers say it burns."
—Auntie Wort
Only those gifted with the eye of Ugin, the spirit dragon, can see his fiery breath.
Even when fate is already written, there's always time to change the names.
Like so many Thran relics, the wurm engine kept operating long after its creators were gone.

"You helped save my people from a Phyrexian fate. Did you think I wouldn't return the favor?"

"The eerie, wailing Hymn caused insanity even in hardened warriors."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II

"Tourach's power was such that his followers deified him after his death."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II
Knowing the Hymn's power, the followers of Leitbur carefully guarded their pillaged transcriptions.
Members of the Order often played the Hymn on instruments made from their victims' bones.
The Icatian army easily repelled early surprise attacks by the Orcs on border towns like Montford.
Although they had long been concerned about the Order of the Ebon Hand, the Icatians faced an even greater threat from Goblin and Orcish raiders.

"Valiant Icatia was the last of the Sarpadian empires to fall. Its faithful soldiers defended their cities to the very end."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. VI

"Never Surrender"
—Motto carved into a fragment of an Icatian wall
To become an officer, an Icatian Soldier had to pass a series of tests. These evaluated not only fighting and leadership skills, but also integrity, honor, and moral strength.

Even after the wall was breached in half a dozen places, the Phalanxes fought on, standing solidly against the onrushing raiders. Disciplined and dedicated, they held their ranks to the end, even in the face of tremendous losses.

"May you be strong and valiant, to defeat the enemies of the pure."
—"Leitbur's Prayer"

"Because the Orc hordes attacked along the entire border, Scouts were essential to Icatia's defense."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. VI

"Let it be known that Ailis Connaut acted with honor and bravery in the defense of the town of Montford, risking her life to scout the enemy's position . . . ."
—Proclamation granting knighthood

"Of course I'm not a spy The enemy has spies. I am a Scout."
—Ailis Connaut

"Scouting is the art of balancing the need to go undiscovered with the need to get all the information you can. It's only by Leitbur's good grace that I'm still alive today."
—Ailis Connaut, Diary
Skirmishers engaged raiders before they could reach the towns. Although these units typically suffered huge losses, they never lacked volunteers.
Icatia's once peaceful towns faced increasing attacks from Orcs and Goblins as the climate cooled. By the time the empire fell, they were little more than armed camps.
Relics of the Order of the Ebon Hand, the bowl and dagger bespeak the hideous cruelty of its rituals.
Ebon leaders soon realized that non-human races often had special talents that could be exploited.

"Many Initiates sacrificed a hand to become full members of the Order."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II

"We are no longer Nature's children, but her masters . . . ."
—Oath of the Ebon Hand
Necrites killed Jherana Rure, ending the counter-insurgency.
"Ever see a wall drop dead of fright, kid? It ain't pretty." —Cpl. Dobbs
Was it the sight, smell, or aura of the Necrite that killed so effectively?
Some said killing the Thallids only encouraged them.
The Elves gathered huge piles of rot to grow fungus. Out of imitation or forethought, the Thallids did the same.

"There were often more Thallids after a battle than before."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III
There's a chance to win every battle.

"Yeah, they're ugly, they desert in droves, and their personal habits are enough to make you sick. But I'll say this for Orcs: they make great spies."
—Ivra Jursdotter

"Orcish armies often employed the smaller, swifter, and less intelligent Goblins as spies."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I

"You idiot Never let the spies mingle with the Orcish regulars after completing a mission. Now we'll never get them to fight"
—General Khurzog
Orcs are not exactly known for their valor—although most Orcs have seen countless battles, only a handful have actually fought in them.

"Orcs often greeted promotions to Icatian battle with anguished wails and pleas for mercy."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. VI
Unsuccessful in their early battle for Montford, the Orcs quickly tempered their bloodlust with cowardice.
Although models of courage for Orcs, the Veterans quickly learned to fear the swift justice of their Icatian enemies.
Followers of Tourach regarded all other religions equally: with open contempt. Not so the followers of Leitbur, who made it their mission to eradicate the Order of the Ebon Hand.

"The powers of the corrupt will fade before the fury of the pure."
—Bethan Leitbur, "The Way"

"Trained to battle the followers of Tourach, the Order of Leitbur was not as successful in later conflicts with Orcish and Goblin raiders."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I
A true follower of Tourach took pride in achievement to the exclusion of other concerns.

"There are intriguing similarities between the Order and Icatia's Leitbur religion, suggesting the two had a common origin."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. VI
Dedicated to the principles of Tourach, members of the Order of the Ebon Hand demonstrated their devotion with grisly rituals.
It's bigger than it thinks.
In the feudal days of Icatia, finding the Rainbow Vale was often the goal of Knights' quests.
To the uninitiated, the Ring of Renewal is merely an oddity. For those fluent in the wielding of magic, however, it is a source of great knowledge.

"Dwelling in icy mountain streams near Goblin and Orcish foes, the River Merfolk were known for their stoicism."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V
At times, survival must outweigh all other considerations.

"Early Vodalians worshipped Svyelun, goddess of the Pearl Moon. Later she became a more abstract figure."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V

"The magic at the heart of all living things can bear awe-inspiring fruit."
—Kolevi of Havenwood, Elder Druid

"As the climate worsened, some Thelonites turned to fertilizing with fresh blood in an attempt to keep Havenwood alive and growing."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III

"The danger in cultivating massive plants caught the elves by surprise."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III

"The cooling climate forced the Elves to experiment with new food sources."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. I

"I don't know which is worse, getting hit with those darts or having to watch them grow back."
—Orcish Soldier

"Scholars still debate whether the Thallids were truly sentient."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. III

"Those idiots should never have bred Thrulls for combat!"
—Jherana Rure

"Until the Rebellion, Thrulls served their masters faithfully—even at the cost of their own lives."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II

"In crafting intelligent Thrulls to assist in sacrifices, Sahr inadvertantly set the stage for the Thrull Rebellion."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. II
Fear the Knight leaping from the water into the air, weapon ready.

"Vodalian Mages are remarkable. Their merchants bring them arcane lore and devices from across the seas."
—Lydia Wynforth, Mayor of Trokair

"Come back, cowards! Everyone knows Merfolk can't wield magic!"
—Pashadar Dirf, Goblin Flotilla Commander, last words
Vodalian Mages were invaluable in magical combat. Unfortunately, the Homarids raided with strength, numbers, and very little magic.

"Vodalian Soldiers had some unique advantages. Often they would ride into battle on war machines rumored to have come from the far northern oceans."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V

"You think you know everything there is to know about battle? You know Orc droppings Underwater combat is three dimensional. Those thrice-damned Vodalians don't attack in ranks; they attack in schools."
—Ivra Jursdotter

"Stalwart Soldiers, you stand against the Homarids for Vodalia and for honor. Your homeland cries out for protection, and the moment has come. Now let your valor shine, and sound the cry to battle. Victory to Vodalia"
—Marshall Volnikov

"The cooling climate introduced a new threat to Vodalia: the Homarids. Once a minor nuisance, they thrived in the changing environment. Their ceaseless attacks strained Vodalia's defenses to their limit, eventually overwhelming the empire."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. V
No sheath shall hold what finds its home in flesh.
Once a welcoming hub for explorers, Affa became a place of guarded tongues and quick defenses.

"If you're in Akoum and you glimpse a shadow overhead, the worst thing you can do is duck."
—Chadir the Navigator

"The emergence of the Eldrazi isn't necessarily a bad thing, as long as you've already lived a fulfilling and complete life without regrets."
—Javad Nasrin, Ondu relic hunter
It holds a whisper from Iona: "Persevere."
"I would rather take my own head than be thwarted by a presumptuous wretch with a shield and a dream."

"Although armor and auras can be similar, the brains required to use them are worlds apart."
—Zilan, Makindi auramancer
Kill a gnarlid with your first blow, or it'll cheerfully show you how it's done.
The ground erupted in time with the hedron's thrum, a dirge of the last days.
Fast and lethal, with a penchant for the weak and infirm.
"Ah, again it does not bode well for you."

"I will build no sanctuaries. The safety you seek can be won only by the sword."
—Yannash, outpost builder
The shaman rattles not to inspire a battle fury but to drown out the shrieks of those fleeing the Eldrazi.

"The brood lineages unfolded across the world, each patterned after one of three progenitors, each a study in mindless consumption."
—The Invokers' Tales
Some humans willingly offered up their blood, hoping it would grant the vampire families the strength to stave off the Eldrazi.
"From in here, everything looks like dinner."
A bramblesnap is formed by grafting together thirteen different plants that already hunger for meat.

"The least of gods shall tower over the mightiest of mortals, and death shall reign over all."
—Crypt of Agadeem inscription
The mouth must be pried open before rigor mortis sets in. Otherwise the returning soul can find no ingress.

"'Fraid of heights? Ride a horse. 'Fraid of missing out? Rein up a drake."
—Trinda, Hada spy patrol
It speaks no commands but is always obeyed.

"Why does it destroy? It does, and to talk of reasons wastes time and breath."
—Nirthu, lone missionary

"The Na Plateau is lost. Do not ask what happened, and never return there."
—Nirthu, lone missionary

"We must all push through the pain to heal our world."
—Ayli, Kamsa cleric

"Petrifying gaze, deadly fangs, knifelike dorsal spines, venomous saliva . . . Am I missing anything? . . . Toxic bones? Seriously?"
—Samila, Murasa Expeditionary House

"What we knew as Emeria, Ula, and Cosi were not divine beings at all, but a cruel trick, and a grave error."
—The Invokers' Tales
Death inevitably seduces all who study it.

"I should have died that day, but I suffered not a scratch. I awoke in a lake of blood, none of it apparently my own."
—The War Diaries

"Morality is just shorthand for the constraints of being powerless."
—Ob Nixilis
The Singing City was silent, the pathway stones were still, and the winds of the Howling Spire ceased.

"That would have brought shame to you as a mage. Tell you what—I'll keep your secret."
—Noyan Dar, Tazeem lullmage
Things born in magma are always angry.
"If our former masters would have us kneel again, they shall feel our defiance slashed across their membranes."
Each Eldrazi ancient spawned a lineage of horrors in unfathomable shapes.
Only the Eldrazi mind thinks in the warped paths required to open the hedrons and tap the power within.
The barest taste of Eldrazi power shatters both realms and identities.
Each temple is a door to a horrible future.
Wordlessly it leads its abhorrent brood.
Golems conjured from the debris of Enatu Temple provided a sturdy but expendable first line of defense against the Eldrazi.
Left masterless by Kozilek, it wandered the wilds, raving in its ceaseless hunger.
Eldrazi grow wherever something else dies.
Every world is an organism, able to grow new lands. Some just do it faster than others.

"Something down there has an appetite for what we're standing on. Let's hope it doesn't want seconds."
—Samila, Murasa Expeditionary House
After millennia asleep, the Eldrazi had forgotten about Zendikar's fiery temper and dislike of strangers.

"To distract an archmage would take incredible power. But for a simpleton, something sparkly will do."
—Noyan Dar, Tazeem lullmage

"Play no favorites. Everybody dies."
—Sparkmage saying

"We thought Zendikar's rage was kindled by its explorers and plunderers. But the world had sensed the stirrings of the Eldrazi."
—The Invokers' Tales
Even as the world was left cracked and gory by the marauding Eldrazi, new life began to drip from its wounds.
"All life is driven by an indomitable will to survive. I simply turn that into something more . . . tangible."
Scavengers both mundane and magical follow in its wake, feeding on the scraps of flesh and spirit it leaves behind.
"There's no contract to sign, no oath to swear. The enlistment procedure is to unsheathe your sword and point it at the enemy."
With great power comes great risk of getting yourself killed.

"You never know what's going to be in goblin tunnels. Even in the best case, there will still be goblins."
—Sachir, Akoum Expeditionary House
As they awakened, the Eldrazi reasserted their mastery over all of Zendikar's natural forces.
Storms spread throughout Oran-Rief, ripping the skies with wind and rain. Airborne creatures sought shelter where they could.

"I don't think he's bringing in the mail . . . ."
—Nundari, Sea Gate militia captain
"I was told these were standard issue. Do I look standard to you?"
It lingers near the outposts of the Makindi Trenches, inadvertently granting another layer of defense.

"I believed in a beautiful god. But this is the true face of the divine."
—Ayli, Kamsa cleric
After encasing it in a paralyzing beam of light, the angel studied the Eldrazi as a child would study a bug, curiously and without fear.
Its breath leaves its prey too drowsy to struggle.

"There was clearly a scream. I'm not sure if there was a mouth."
—Sachir, Akoum Expeditionary House
The hedrons awoke along with the Eldrazi, forming superstructures that radiated overwhelming magic.
Just when you thought you'd be safe, in the middle of an open field with no Eldrazi around for miles.
All the angel saw was her doom.
You will scream out your innermost secrets just to make it stop.
The baloth's instincts boiled, its muscles pulled taut, and its razor-spines bristled, as it turned to face—a runt meepling.
Your pleas for death shall go unheard.
Nature's arms encircle all who are willing to draw close.

"Yeah, they've got a lot of meat. The only downside to eating 'em is that you often find human bones and body parts inside."
—Jaby, Silundi Sea nomad
As it spins, dead voices shriek in an ever-increasing cacophony, rending the mind asunder.

"In ages past, bargains were struck and promises were made. Now we must collect on our debt. Begin the hymns."
—Moruul, Khalni druid
It traps an explosion within its stony skin.

"I tried to tell her to stay behind, that this fight was too dangerous. I spent the next hour tied to the rafters."
—Zahr Gada, Halimar expedition leader
She reaches beyond the physical realm, touching the ideals from which all creatures draw their power.
It's difficult to outwit something that doesn't speak, strategize, or even think.

Tracing their ancestry back to Zendikar's earliest forms of life, lagac lizards have seen the comings and goings of planeswalkers and the Eldrazi, and the rise of the vampire clans, none of which has changed them one bit.

"Romanticize it, glamorize it, call it what you will. To me, it will always be carnal, bloody murder."
—Ayli, Kamsa cleric

"Then the ancient masters themselves, towers of rapacity, rose and began their calamitous feast."
—The Invokers' Tales

"It's good to learn from your failures, but I prefer to learn from the failures of others."
—Jace Beleren

"Those who think the trees shall remain bystanders throughout this conflict shall be sorely mistaken."
—Sutina, Speaker of the Tajuru
If you want to kill a lot of goblins, just make sure your defenses look like fun.
Those who seek to disturb the harmony of life will see their instruments taken from them.
"That our enemies are great only brings us greater hope."
His mission has become a grim pilgrimage, a tour of the Eldrazi-stricken outposts across Zendikar. But he marches on alone, stubborn as the daily dawn.

"If destiny's champions have arisen to fight the Ancient Ones, then let me, too, do my part."
—Ravuel of Graypelt

"The purpose of existence is simple: everything is fuel for the magmaw."
—Jaji, magmaw worshipper
As the hedrons began to coalesce into colossal Eldrazi superstructures, the griffins were forced to seek new territory lest their aeries be crushed between the massive stone monoliths.
"The structure gets bigger every hour, with hedrons coalescing even deep under the surface. If I could only get inside . . . ."
"Emeria is a pleasant lie, a figment to hide Emrakul's hideous face. I can only hope to uncover a truth that lies deeper still."
The Joraga elves never need ask a troll to leave their territory. They merely grant it their combined strength, and it can't resist embarking on a merry rampage.

"I'd build an entire fortress of them if I could."
—Mzali, Lighthouse archmage
It wasn't long until the elves had developed a use for every part of the Eldrazi.
To the soldier, war is famine; to the scavenger, a feast.

"It's so cute when it's sleeping, isn't it? Actually, it's still as abhorrent as ever, but at least it's not trying to kill us."
—Noyan Dar, Tazeem lullmage

"The scholars wept when we destroyed the hedron. I had no such pity. What would this world be like had we done so sooner?"
—The War Diaries
Lands ravaged, cities in ruins, so many lives sacrificed, and yet there was no other word for it but victory.
In one gargantuan bite, it will swallow not only you but also the riverbank you were standing on.
It nurtures its masters' glorious future.

"To evade the brood lineages, one must be made dark to all the senses."
—Traga, Zulaport runner
Hate is an everlasting wellspring from which it is eternally sustained.

"You have to appreciate the genius of it. Why bother building defenses when you can just fill the pass with angry ogres?"
—Javad Nasrin, Ondu relic hunter
She adopted the weapon of the slave-lord Kazuul, and with it, all his cruelty.
Some druids nurture gardens. Others nurture continents.

"‘Invincible' is just a word."
—Gideon Jura

"Our enemy is nothing less than the end of all life. We shall not want for allies."
—The War Diaries
No thought but hunger. No strategy but destruction.
It eats what it wants to eat—which is anything that moves.
Draped with the pennon of a fallen outpost, the sword came to symbolize the peoples of Zendikar becoming one.
It removed only one idea from her mind: defiance.
"I have schemed too long to be supplanted by dead gods. If I cannot have this world, no one can."
Create an illusion so strong that it becomes another's reality, and you can become the master of all.
"The explorer who found it got a bad deal when he sold it. He merely got rich."

"The vampires knew what was coming. I know it. And they did nothing. They deserve to feel the same agony they've caused all of us."
—Anitan, Ondu cleric
The settlement knew there was something strange about the cloud when the old priest Mandli suddenly grabbed an axe and ran screaming into the hills.
Goblins in the first wave of a fire raid always bemoan the aim of everyone else.
From the moment the first Eldrazi spawn squirmed free, everything on Zendikar took on an adjusted meaning, a new slant toward or away from the waking giants.

"Never look too deep, where the waters turn dark. What the sea has hidden there may not stay down forever."
—Jaby, Silundi Sea nomad
Built of wood and iron. Held together by hope and prayer.
To truly know a creature, slither a mile in its tentacles.
Sorin has gathered grudges for centuries, patiently awaiting the day he can exact the perfect vengeance.
A boon to those who cannot see in the dark. A bane to those who live in it.
Scholars had puzzled for centuries over the ruins at Tal Terig. Its secrets had always lived within one rune-carved head.
"The secret entrance should be near."
Ancient lore locked in a mind driven mad is just as safe as when it was locked deep underground.
Riches must be divided, but real wealth can be shared.

"Have you ever killed insects nibbling at your crops? I think that's what the Eldrazi believe they're doing to us."
—Sheyda, Ondu gamekeeper
Necromancers are judged by the most powerful undead they've ever created. There are those who have animated just a single being, yet are considered the pinnacle of their dark craft.

"The brood spread far faster than we could kill it. I fear the worst is yet to come."
—The War Diaries

"The mighty rely solely on their strength. They are shocked when we do the same."
—Tars Olan, kor world-gift
In truth, her own faith was gone, trodden in Ulamog's wake. She pantomimed the blessing in the hope that it would inspire others to continue to struggle.
The kor's most righteous dead are given the greatest reward: an eternity tied to the land they so cherish.
It draws its strength from those around it, but the pleasure of destruction is all its own.
Death by death, Kozilek's lineage spread.
"A riddle is nothing more than a trap for small minds, baited with the promise of understanding."
Its host's final curse lies captured within.
"I know just the person for that job."

"They don't move much, but then again, if you get caught in its web, it has all the time in the world to get to you."
—Saidah, Joraga hunter

"Hold fast the line! Either we stop them here or we wake up in their guts!"
—Tala Vertan, Makindi shieldmate

"This one is only a yearling, but it would be wise to move away before we provide it with excellent hunting practice."
—Samila, Murasa Expeditionary House
Ulamog's tentacles, their touch like burning ice, rummaged through his soul and stung his memories one by one.
"No more blood shall be spilled to satisfy another's deluded lust for power."
No one spoke. There was no need. The threat of the Eldrazi presented a simple choice: lay down your weapons and die for nothing, or hold them fast and die for something.
The kor track hartebeests in hopes of finding magic to help fight the Eldrazi.
Under the master's eye, skills are honed sharper and spells cut deeper.
The horror lurched about like a puppet from a madman's nightmare, squeezing the life from its own kind.
Remade by Eldrazi magic, Tuktuk inspired an entire clan of misguided goblins.

"Whatever the Eldrazi's purpose is, it has nothing to do with something so insignificant as us."
—Nirthu, lone missionary
"I have found the courage to face death—twice, if I must."

"We're glad to be of service—to be an audience to your failure."
—Maizah Shere, Tazeem lullmage

"Just move very slowly, and for the love of Ula, do not get it mad."
—Chadir the Navigator

"Consider my debt to your kin paid in full."
—Idrol, Guul Draz assassin
"The unfathomable is upon us, students. I have no doubt you will rise to the occasion."
Leave but a shred of root and it will return, bursting with vigor.

"Zendikar fortifies itself against the Great Threat, making sentries of sky, sea, and stone."
—The War Diaries

"I search for a vision of Zendikar that does not include the Eldrazi."
—Expedition journal entry
The best defense is a good offense.

"Life as we know it dangles on the brink of extinction. We must show the strength they would steal from us."
—The Invokers' Tales

"Our pyromancer's flames may not have killed them, but they bought us the time we needed."
—The War Diaries
It haunts the remnants of the Helix of Zof, leeching strength from the vast Eldrazi ruin.
"What would you say is my greatest attribute? Is it my gluttonous lust for power?"
card: A Display of My Dark Power

flavor:
"Release that which was never caged."
—Spellbomb inscription
Life's circle has become inverted in Grixis. The same energy is endlessly recycled and becomes more stagnant with each pass.
"Take a moment. Ponder the depths of your insignificance."
"It's my goal to find the melting point of every substance."
card: All Shall Smolder in My Wake

flavor: "It's a dragon-infested lavascape of notorious peril. Make yourselves at home."
This secret society of mages manipulates the beliefs and opinions of others.
Such is the power of Rakdos that even his shadow takes on a cruel life of its own.
The maze-like design embodies the core of Azorius law—strict structure designed to test wills and stall change.
Their skeletons can be found all over Skirk Ridge, tangled in each other's horns.
A vertical scream pierces the night air and echoes doom through the clouds.
"I'd call that a successful first test. Golem! Rearm the Doom Citadel!"
The world is the body. The mana is the blood. The witch is the surgeon.

"Lightning lives in everything, in living flesh and growing things. It must be set free."
—Rakka Mar
Every grave cradles a recruit.

"Her mind is an incredible mix of emotion and power. Even if I could grasp it, I couldn't hold it for long."
—Jace Beleren, on Chandra Nalaar
"It seems the fate of the world rests on your shoulders, feeble child."

"Never corner a barbarian. You become the path of least resistance."
—Sarkhan Vol
An emblem of a secret guild, the Dimir insignia is seen only by its own members—and the doomed.
Goblins journey to the sacrificial peaks in pairs so that the rare survivor might be able to relate the details of the other's grisly demise.
"We speak the dragons' language of flame and rage. They speak our language of fury and honor. Together we shall weave a tale of destruction without equal."
Only the Eldrazi mind thinks in the warped paths required to open the hedrons and tap the power within.
The undead of Grixis are fueled by their hatred of the living.
"My vision is for the good of everyone. Mostly me."
"Oh, I think I will get away with this."
"May bloodberries grow from your remains."
"The plants justify the means."
"Even you have a purpose. Your blood will oil the gears."
It shreds its prey as each head fights for the choicest bits.
In life, it was a fetid, disease-ridden thing. In death, not much changed.
Dragon lords of Jund rule by edicts of flame.

"I fear no army or beast, but only the morning fog. Our assault can survive everything else."
—Lord Hilneth
Its blood is life. Its body is growth.
Baby dragons can't figure out humans—if they didn't want to be killed, why were they made of meat and treasure?
Gruul territorial markings need not be legible. The blood, snot, and muck used to smear them are unmistakably Gruul.
"Words lie. People lie. The land tells the truth."

"You helped save my people from a Phyrexian fate. Did you think I wouldn't return the favor?"
—Eladamri, to Gerrard
"I can't imagine what you're feeling right now, but I'll try my best."
"Heroes innovate. Villains duplicate."
Shadowmoor's main crops are rot, slime, and despair.
Not once in the history of Grixis has anyone died of old age.
"Do you smell something burning?"

"This is why we don't go out in banewasp weather."
—Rannon, Vithian holdout
"You may even see them again. Full digestion takes three hundred years."
"Meet my newest minion. Come now, don't be shy—shake her pincer."
Built with neither a way to steer nor a way to stop, the juggernauts were simply aimed at an enemy's best defenses and told to charge.

"Rats and jackals feast in his swath, but even they will not walk with him."
—Mangara
"My mind has changed. My strength has not."
"Cranial explosions for everyone. Still planning to outthink my dragons?"
Eidren, perfect of Lys Alana, ordered hundreds of trees uprooted and rearranged into a pattern he deemed beautiful. Thus the Gilt-Leaf Wood was born.
Only leonin clerics who can survive the Razor Fields for one turning of the suns can stand in the Cave of Light.
After lightning struck the cliffs, the ore became iron, the iron became steel, and the steel became greaves. The lightning never left.

"Somehow it warps the Æther. It brings a strange weight, a blockade in the flow of spellcraft."
—Noyan Dar, Tazeem lullmage
"Today I take the reins of destiny itself. Today the Draconic Apocalypse is upon you."
"These benighted worlds are thick with ignorance. I will educate them. They will listen, or they will die."

"This vulgar mimicry will end now."
—Desmera, perfect of Wren's Run
"Wasted potential surrounds us. Lend me that bauble, and let me see what it can be made to be."
"This should halt the spread of your insolence."
In the blur between metal and flesh, Memnarch found madness.
"By the time I got there, the heart had stopped. Fortunately, I was able to replace it with something better."
"My mind is the spread of the canopy. My heart is the embrace of the roots. I am deathless Llanowar, its fury and its peace."
"I certainly would have accepted my offer of eternal life. But if you choose death instead, who am I to argue?"
"I can see . . . everything. The beginning and the end of time. The raw edges of reality. And now I see exactly how to kill you."
"Indulge me. Just one spell. One potentially fatal spell gone horribly awry."
It is a monument as austere, unyielding, and inscrutable as Esper itself.
"But nothing will end your regret."
"You are the grandest of all," said the archdruid to the trees. They became so proud of bark and branch that they suffered no creature to fly overhead or perch upon a bough.
Made of bone and boiled in blood, a Rakdos signet is not considered finished until it has been used as a murder weapon.
Hatred outlives the hateful.
"Look around you. All you behold is mine to rule. It's the natural way."

"You will learn to earn death."
—Volrath
Though you may see the same bones, you'll never see the same skeleton twice.
"I assure you, these are not the kind that thrive on sunlight and water."
"Don't come back until you've got brains in your teeth."

"You're just like me: ruthless, cunning, and ambitious. Obviously you're a threat."
—Basarios the Blade

"The people of Akros must learn from our leonin adversaries. If we match their staunch ferocity with our superior faith, we cannot fail."
—Cymede, queen of Akros

"The temple has been rededicated. It belongs to Mogis now."
—Rastos, disciple of Mogis
The awards and medals of polis-dwellers mean nothing to griffins, but they repay acts of generosity.
The defenders said not a word. Their shields, spears, and stances were warning enough.

"When fire is shackled to candle and torch, subjected to insignificance, it finds a way to lash out at its masters."
—Vala, disciple of Purphoros

"Stoke a fire hot enough and you'll never run out of things to burn."
—Xenagos, the Reveler
"You thought only the gods could stop you?"
The last thing to go through the cyclops's mind was a twelve-ton block of marble.
"When you threaten the sanctity of the polis, you insult Ephara herself. If she doesn't smite you, I will."
"You. Poet. Be sure to write this down."

"Are the gods angry at our discontent with what they give us, or jealous that we made a thing they cannot?"
—Kleon the Iron-Booted
The tale of her life was already written, but that didn't mean she could predict the ending.

—The Theriad
Nylea's sacred lynx guards those who honor the Nessian Wood and hunts those who don't.
Attending a satyr revel requires a high tolerance for pain.
Beware the gifts of an ill-tempered forge god.
"I see your future, mantled in ash."

"The gods gave us no wings to fly, but they gave us an even greater gift: imagination."
—Daxos of Meletis
More disturbing than the unknown is a distortion of the familiar.

"You dryfolk must take the air for granted. You constantly insist on wasting it."
—Kenessos, priest of Thassa
No foe is more hated than the former friend.
Honor the gods of Theros, and they will return the favor.
When the sea god Thassa wishes to speak with a mortal, she does not issue a summons or grant a vision requesting a visit. The sea simply brings her guest before her.
The histories speak of two feuding rulers whose deaths were celebrated and whose monuments symbolized the end of their wars. In truth they were peaceful lovers, their story lost to the ages.
All the world is Purphoros's anvil.
Destiny exalts a chosen few, but even heroes break.

"A grudge is a tattoo worn on the inside."
—Setessan warrior saying
A cyclops has two moods: angry and asleep.
Gold coin, battered helmet, broken wrist bone—all have the same value in the eyes of a harpy.
"The wilds are a garden tended by divine hands."
A warcaller merely brings the herd together. After that, the meat-hunger is all the encouragement they need.
"It used to be a lair. Now it's just a tunnel."
"The best lessons are not the ones I teach. They are the ones the pupils realize for themselves."

"No matter who their fickle hearts worship, all mortals belong to one god in the end."
—Iadorna, death priest of Erebos
In time, all things turn to dust. Some things just take less time.
Formerly oppressed by the polis of Meletis, leonin occasionally "mistake" their old enemies for game.

"The hand of Keranos can be seen in every rumbling storm cloud. Best not to stand where he points."
—Rakleia of Shrine Peak
Even those who leave the labyrinth never escape it, forever dreaming of their time trapped within.
The Returned have no memory of the Underworld or of their former lives. The golden masks they wear are the last gifts of the selves they left behind.
"Every object has an echo in the Æther beyond the world. Every idea has a shadow that can be brought to light."

"He outran arrows. He outran even the archers' insults."
—Bayma, storyteller of Lagonna Band

"Their only dreams are of full stomachs."
—Kleon the Iron-Booted

"It augments anamnesis. What is so confusing about that?"
—Perisophia the philosopher
It's not the two heads you should fear. It's the four fangs.

—The Theriad
Her prophecies amaze her even as she speaks them.
Purphoros once loved Nylea, the god of the hunt. His passion inspired his most astounding works of art.

"Early olive buds? A good omen. Flock of crows? Not so good. Mountain exploding? Bad. Very, very bad."
—Hira, street oracle

"The venom cleanses the sickness from your body, but it will not be pleasant, and you may not survive. Pharika's blessings are fickle."
—Solon, acolyte of Pharika
"The direst venom becomes a panacea under Pharika's guidance. I bring it to the worthy, clinging at the edge of the abyss."

—The Theriad
"Even my last breath will be a blow struck for Iroas."
"Time is fluid as a dance, and truth as fleeting."

"The youths prattle on about heroic deeds, but avoiding the noose is a feat more daring than their entire careers."

—Hira, street oracle

The dead know lessons the living haven't learned.
Driven away by his living kin, he wanders mourning through the wilderness, seeking the dead city of Asphodel.
They lived in different nations and fought in different eras, but as the Returned, they link arms as one.
"Any festival you can walk away from wasn't worth attending in the first place."

"When I asked my commander the reward for killing that prancing nuisance, he told me, ‘None! I want to kill him myself!'"
—Phrogas, soldier of Akros
A satyr is bound by nothing—not home, not family, not loyalty.

"I thought its back was turned!"
"A centaur has two backs!"

To members of the cult of Erebos, gold-infused tattoos symbolize the inevitable grasp of the god of death.

"What has neither mouth nor throat, yet swallows captain, crew, and boat?"
—Sphinx's riddle

Thakolides the Mighty
Slayer of minotaurs
Vanquisher of giants
Killed by a scorpion
—Inscription on an Akroan grave
When Athreos gathers the newly dead to be ferried across the Five Rivers That Ring the World, he sends skeletal griffins to fetch those who stray.
"Your god teaches you only how to kill. Karametra teaches me to defend what I hold dear. That is why I will prevail."
Most griffins must be caught and broken into the service of the polis. Not so in Setessa, where they volunteer.

"Enemies of the wood! Your presence here is a slap in Nylea's face. Do not be surprised if she slaps back."
—Telphe, druid of Nylea

—The Theriad
Conspirators poisoned the oracle not because her visions were wrong, but because they were right.
"I hear the gods' voices in my dreams each night, and I offer bloody trophies on their altars each day."

Legend speaks of the Sun Spear, the mighty weapon that can strike any point in Theros, even the depths of the Underworld.
Thaumaturges remain silent around chimeras, lest their words conjure even stranger beasts.
As soon as she faces a monster, she begins composing its epitaph.

When a god's will is against you, the day never ends well.

"The most enlightened mages create beauty from violence."

"Was this gift cast adrift for any to find, or did Thassa guide the currents to bring it to me alone?"

"Knowledge is such a burden. Release it. Release all your fears to me."
—Ashiok, Nightmare Weaver
There is no gift more precious or more perilous than fire.

"What we call magic is nothing more than hope crystallized into a destination."

—The Theriad
"Thassa has blessed me with power and insight. I am careful not to disappoint her."

—The Theriad
The left head keeps the right head starved as motivation to track new prey.

"Mists are carefree. They drift where they will, unencumbered by rocks and river beds."

"I could heal a snakebite. Looks like you got bitten by a constellation."
—Aescalos, healer of Pharika

"Let each challenge make you a better warrior."
—Anthousa of Setessa
"You can tell something's really valuable by the sound it makes when you slam your staff into it."

—The Theriad

"Every act of destruction has a repercussion."

"If you don't shut up," hissed Mirri, "you'll see a kidney and a spleeny."
"I'll take that. You won't need it when the revolution comes."

"My family sheltered in her light, the dark was content to wait."

Mirri: "After they're done trying to kill us, all right?"

—Karn, silver golem
"Mine."

"We know our place in the cycle of life—and it is not as flies."
—Eladamri, Lord of Leaves

"Hope shall be the blade that severs our bonds."

"While we fought, the il surrendered."

"One would think I would be accustomed to unexpected returns."

"Hup, two, three, four,
Dunno how to count no more."

"If there is such a thing as too much power, I have not discovered it."

"All dauthi are jackals, regardless of breed."

"There is nothing you can do that I cannot simply deny."

Within without.

"To think that some find sleep a restful state."

These are its last days. It is doomed to be remembered only until the hunters hunger again.

"I hear the roaring of a wave whose waters are red and whose mists are black."

—Tahngarth of the Weatherlight

"It's hard to hurt anyone when you're as transparent as your motives."
—Ertai, wizard adept

One mogg to aim the catapult, one mogg to steer the rock.

"Memory is a burden that wears at the soul as weather wears at stone."
—Crovax

Changing Rath's landscape is like tearing the scab from a wound.
To snare what lies between worlds takes the patient reach of trees.

Seeking the company of plants ensures that your wits will go to seed.

"One cannot cleanse the wounds of failure."
—Karn, silver golem
"Here."
Hunger is like the sea: deep, endless, and unforgiving.
Hope of deliverance is scorched by the fire of futility.
The true treasure no thief can touch.

"The fatal flaw in every plan is the assumption that you know more than your enemy."
—Volrath

"A skilled decoy can throw your enemies off your trail. A master decoy can survive to do it again."

—Tahngarth, aboard the Predator
"I got it! I got it! I—"

Stand clear if he gets an itch.
Hope is the one crop that can grow in any climate.
The air was filled with the cracks and snaps of flesh hardening as the new sliver joined the battle.

"My enemies' death yields threefold benefit: removal, reuse, and research."

The kor forsake roots for the winding of the path, forsake voices for the silence of the mind, forsake all else for the poverty of isolation.

"The silkworm spins itself a new existence. So the healer weaves the threads of life."

"They are convenient in having no souls, but less so in having no spirit."

Wrap the flame as twine,
Kingdoms will be thine.

"These creatures offer new challenges in the scrutiny of entrails."

"See how you like it."

"You will learn to earn death."

"Not again."

"Bitter water, vicious wave;
Shadow-cold shallows, root-made maze.
Home's angry embrace."
