www.MagicTheGathering.com
"Strike," the fumes hiss. "Raise an empire with your ambition."
There may exist powers even greater than Phyrexia.
Leonos had no second thoughts about the abolishment edict. He'd left skyrunes warning of the eviction, even though it was cloudy.
Those who enter the copse never leave. They find peace there and take root, becoming part of the ever-growing grove.

"Some call me a thief. I prefer to think of myself as a discreet borrower."
—Dack Fayden, Planeswalker
The best cure for a big ego is a little failure.
"Your life will set with the sun."
Funny how money and war travel so well together.

"Perhaps planning should become a higher priority for me."
—Dack Fayden
Loyal and passionate in battle, the Windseeker tribe roams the Green Lands near the Honeyed Sea.
"My commands shall echo forever in their dusty skulls."
These spirits of the air are winsome and wild, and cannot be truly contained. Only marginally intelligent, they often substitute whimsy for strategy, delighting in mischief and mayhem.
Benalia has a complex caste system that changes with the lunar year. No matter what the season, the only caste that cannot be attained by either heredity or money is that of the hero.
Battle doesn't need a purpose; the battle is its own purpose. You don't ask why a plague spreads or a field burns. Don't ask why I fight.

'Twas in the bogs of Cannelbrae
My mate did meet an early grave
'Twas nothing left for us to save
In the peat-filled bogs of Cannelbrae.

The most terrifying thing about the Craw Wurm is probably the horrible crashing sound it makes as it speeds through the forest. This noise is so loud it echoes through the trees and seems to come from all directions at once.
Created to destroy Dominia, Demons can sometimes be bent to a more focused purpose.

"O to be a dragon . . . of silkworm size or immense . . ."
—Marianne Moore, "O to Be a Dragon"
Bones scattered around us joined to form misshapen bodies. We struck at them repeatedly—they fell, but soon formed again, with the same mocking look on their faceless skulls.
Foolishly, Najib retreated to his castle at El-Abar; the next morning he was dead. In just one night, the dwarven forces had reduced the mighty walls to mere rubble.

Earth Elementals have the eternal strength of stone and the endurance of mountains. Primordially connected to the land they inhabit, they take a long-term view of things, scorning the impetuous haste of short-lived mortal creatures.
I tell you, there was so many arrows flying about you couldn't hardly see the sun. So I says to young Angus, "Well, at least now we're fighting in the shade!"

Fire Elementals are ruthless infernos, annihilating and consuming their foes in a frenzied holocaust. Crackling and blazing, they sear swift, terrible paths, leaving the land charred and scorched in their wake.

"And topples round the dreary west
A looming bastion fringed with fire."
—Alfred, Lord Tennyson, "In Memoriam"

"There are some qualities—some incorporate things,/ That have a double life, which thus is made/ A type of twin entity which springs/ From matter and light, evinced in solid and shade."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "Silence"
Rather than sheltering her young, the female Fungusaur often injures her own offspring, thereby ensuring their rapid growth.
While it possesses potent venom, the Giant Spider often chooses not to paralyze its victims. Perhaps the creature enjoys the gentle rocking motion caused by its captives' struggles to escape its web.
"From up here we can drop rocks and arrows and more rocks!" "Uh, yeah boss, but how do we get down?"
To become king of the Goblins, one must assassinate the previous king. Thus, only the most foolish seek positions of leadership.

"While most overworlders fortunately don't realize this, Gargoyles can be most delicious, providing you have the appropriate tools to carve them."
—The Underworld Cookbook, by Asmoranomardicadaistinaculdacar

The Ogre philosopher Gnerdel believed the purpose of life was to live as high on the food chain as possible. She refused to eat vegetarians, and preferred to live entirely on creatures that preyed on sentient beings.

Don't try to outrun one of Dominia's Grizzlies; it'll catch you, knock you down, and eat you. Of course, you could run up a tree. In that case you'll get a nice view before it knocks the tree down and eats you.
Fortunately, Hill Giants have large blind spots in which a human can easily hide. Unfortunately, these blind spots are beneath the bottoms of their feet.

The Minotaurs of the Hurloon Mountains are known for their love of battle. They are also known for their hymns to the dead, sung for friend and foe alike. These hymns can last for days, filling the mountain valleys with their low, haunting sounds.

"...There was no trace/ Of aught on that illumined face..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Phantom"
Generations of genetic weeding have given rise to the deviously cowardly Ironclaw clan. To say that Orcs in general are vicious, depraved, and ignoble does not do justice to the Ironclaw.

The mating habits of Treefolk, particularly the stalwart Ironroot Treefolk, are truly absurd. Molasses comes to mind. It's amazing the species can survive at all given such protracted periods of mate selection, conjugation, and gestation.
"Some of the other guys dared me to touch it, but I knew it weren't no ordinary hunk o' rock." —Norin the Wary
We had taken refuge in a small cave, thinking the entrance was too narrow for it to follow. To our horror, its gigantic head smashed into the mountainside, ripping itself a new entrance.
After years of training, the Druid becomes one with nature, drawing power from the land and returning it when needed.

Some fiendish mage had created a horrifying wall of living flesh, patched together from a jumble of still-recognizable body parts. As we sought to hew our way through it, some unknown power healed the gaping wounds we cut, denying us passage.
Whenever the Llanowar Elves gather the fruits of their forest, they leave one plant of each type untouched, considering that nature's portion.
A master of tactics, the Lord of Atlantis makes his people bold in battle merely by arriving to lead them.
Of royal blood among the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti Djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.

Most human scholars believe that Merfolk are the survivors of sunken Atlantis, humans adapted to the water. Merfolk, however, believe that humans sprang forth from Merfolk who adapted themselves in order to explore their last frontier.

Before a woman marries in the village of Sursi, she must visit the land of the Mesa Pegasus. Legend has it that if the woman is pure of heart and her love is true, a Mesa Pegasus will appear, blessing her family with long life and good fortune.

The intricate dynamics of Rundvelt Goblin affairs are often confused with anarchy. The chaos, however, is the chaos of a thundercloud, and direction will sporadically and violently appear. Pashalik Mons and his raiders are the thunderhead that leads in the storm.
The Nightmare arises from its lair in the swamps. As the poisoned land spreads, so does the Nightmare's rage and terrifying strength.

"Look to the north; there you will find aid and comfort."
—The Book of Tal

"The foot stone is connected to the ankle stone, the ankle stone is connected to the leg stone..."
—Song of the Artificer
In a rare display of ingenuity, the Orcs invented an incredibly destructive weapon. Most Orcish artillerists are those who dared criticize its effectiveness.

"‘Do you know, I always thought Unicorns were fabulous monsters, too? I never saw one alive before!' ‘Well, now that we have seen each other,' said the Unicorn, ‘if you'll believe in me, I'll believe in you.'" —Lewis Carroll
These beings embody the essence of true heroes long dead. Summoned from the dreamrealms, they rise to meet their enemies.

"While, like a ghastly rapid river,
Through the pale door,
A hideous throng rush out forever,
And laugh—but smile no more."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "The Haunted Palace"

"Should you a Rat to madness tease
Why ev'n a Rat may plague you..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Recantation"
Occasionally a member of the Institute of Arcane Study acquires a taste for worldly pleasures. Seldom do they have trouble finding employment.

We encountered a valley topped with immense boulders and eerie rock formations. Suddenly one of these boulders toppled from its perch and sprouted gargantuan wings, casting a shadow of darkness and sending us fleeing in terror.
Trained in the arts of stealth, the royal assassins choose their victims carefully, relying on timing and precision rather than brute force.
Healers ultimately acquire the divine gifts of spiritual and physical wholeness. The most devout are also granted the ability to pass physical wholeness on to others.

The traditional kings of the jungle command a healthy respect in other climates as well. Relying mainly on their stealth and speed, Savannah Lions can take a victim by surprise, even in the endless flat plains of their homeland.

"They groaned, they stirred, they all uprose,/ Nor spake, nor moved their eyes;/ It had been strange, even in a dream,/ To have seen those dead men rise."/ —Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"
The only sound was the gentle clicking of the Faeries' wings. Then those intruders who were still standing turned and fled. One thing was certain: they didn't think the Scryb were very funny anymore.
Legend has it that Serpents used to be bigger, but how could that be?

The stench in the hovel was overpowering; something loathsome was cooking. Occasionally something surfaced in the thick paste, but my host would casually push it down before I could make out what it was.
Born with wings of light and a sword of faith, this heavenly incarnation embodies both fury and purity.
Moving without sound, swift figures pass through branches and undergrowth completely unhindered. One with the trees around them, the Dryads of Shanodin Forest are seen only when they wish to be.

While it's true most Dragons are cruel, the Shivan Dragon seems to take particular glee in the misery of others, often tormenting its victims much like a cat plays with a mouse before delivering the final blow.
What goes up, must come down.
Moss-covered statues littered the area, a macabre monument to the Basilisk's power.
Though many think of Wolves as solitary predators, they are actually extremely social animals. During a hunt they often call to each other, which can be quite unsettling for their prey.
None know if this Giant is the result of aberrant magics, Siamese twins, or a mentalist's schizophrenia.

"Oi oi oi, me gotta hurt in 'ere,
Oi oi oi, me smell a ting is near,
Gonna bosh 'n gonna nosh 'n da
hurt'll disappear."
—Traditional
Some say magic was first practiced by women, who have always felt strong ties to the land.
Good bodyguards are hard to find, mainly because they don't live long.
"This ‘standing windstorm' can hold us off indefinitely? Ridiculous!" Saying nothing, she put a pinch of salt on the table. With a bang she clapped her hands, and the salt disappeared, blown away.
The Wall of Bone is said to be an aspect of the Great Wall in Hel, where the bones of all sinners wait for Ragnarok, when Hela will call them forth for the final battle.

"What else, when chaos draws all forces inward to shape a single leaf."
 —Conrad Aiken
Conjured from the bowels of hell, the fiery wall forms an impassable barrier, searing the soul of any creature attempting to pass through its terrible bursts of flame.
"And through the drifts the snowy cliffs/ Did send a dismal sheen:/ Nor shapes of men nor beasts we ken—/ The ice was all between."/—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"

The Earth herself lends her strength to these walls of living stone, which possess the stability of ancient mountains. These mighty bulwarks thwart ground-based troops, providing welcome relief for weary warriors who defend the land.

Just as the evil ones approached to slay Justina, she cast a great spell, imbuing her weapons with her own life force. Thus she fulfilled the prophecy: "In the death of your savior will you find salvation."
A deafening roar arose as the fury of an enormous vertical river supplanted our serenity. Eddies turned into whirling geysers, leveling everything in their path.
Everybody knows that to ward off trouble, you knock on wood. But usually it's better to make a wall out of the wood and let trouble do the knocking.
I didn't think Mammoths could ever hold a candle to a well-trained battle horse. Then one day I turned my back on a drunken soldier. His blow never landed; Mi'cha flung the brute over ten meters.

Unpredictable as the sea itself, Water Elementals shift without warning from tranquility to tempest. Capricious and fickle, they flow restlessly from one shape to another, expressing their moods with their physical forms.
Out of the blackness and stench of the engulfing swamp emerged a shimmering figure. Only the splattered armor and ichor-stained sword hinted at the unfathomable evil the knight had just laid waste.

"About, about in reel and rout
The death-fires danced at night;
The water, like a witch's oils,
Burnt green, and blue and white."
—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"
They say the Zombie Master controlled these foul creatures even before his own death, but now that he is one of them, nothing can make them betray him.

There is no glory to be gained in the kingdom of the dead.
—Vec tomb inscription
Spring is the most beautiful season in the grove, when the new leaves open from their ember-buds in a race of leaping flames.
If it can't be had here, it can't be had on any world.
Both forge and pyre.

"Yawgmoth's corpse is a wound in the universe. His foul blood seeps out, infecting the land with his final curse."
—Lord Windgrace
It is everywhere you've ever been.
When defeat is near and guidance is scarce, all eyes look in one direction.
First the insult, then the injury.
Swarms thrive in its nest, feeding on leathery bits of discarded wing.
"I am not at liberty to reveal my sources, but I can assure you, the price on your head is high."
"I'll have my revenge if I have to call on every force from above and below."
"Ideas drift like petals on the wind. I have only to lift my face to the breeze."
Even after a false god tore the magic from Dominaria, power still radiated from the Mirari sword that slew her.
Friends teach what you want to know. Enemies teach what you need to know.
Vela snuffs out every trace of Krond's reign, leaving pure nightfall in her wake.
She learned a tragic lesson that day: even the purest can be corrupted when the heart's emotions are twisted.
Drakes can swerve to avoid a single arrow, but they can't dodge the whole sky.
He ensures escape attempts are just that—attempts.
A weapon best suited for those with good aim and steady hands.
It contains the totality of Alhammarret's notes, theories, and ponderings.
"It's all a game. You shouldn't get too attached to the pieces."
"Faith can quicken the stones themselves with life."—Writings of Mikaeus
"Arise. You have been anointed by the light. Go forth and fight without fear, for you shall be victorious."
The artificers of Kaladesh strive ceaselessly for perfection, progress, and the ultimate expression of elegance.
"In memories, we can find our deepest reserves of strength."
Waste follows want.
When the shadow of the aven falls across the battlefield, hope rises in the hearts of the soldiers.
As the price of wood and coal rose, smiths found creative ways to keep their forges burning.
It tears the flesh from your bones and then swallows the ash with its fiery maw.
Not all heroes die in armor.
"Your flesh is unprepared for my gifts."
"The bloodlust shall not control me, for my oath is my greatest compulsion."
He has the biggest bashing stick, so it's a safe bet he's the leader.
Loyal to a fault, it heeds its master's every command.
"I can think of worse ways to go. On second thought, maybe not."—Ludevic, necro-alchemist
Unpredictable as a storm and destructive as a tidal wave.
"The entire murder scene was covered in dripping, oozing slime. No need for a soothsayer to solve that one."—Pel Javya, Wojek investigator
"The rare and beautiful butterflies inspire the design of our thopters. The larvae, however, are a different story entirely."—Kiran Nalaar, Ghirapur inventor
"You were defeated the moment you declared your aggression."—Gideon Jura
"They started it."
In the moment before her execution, she realized what it meant to be a pyromancer, to be alive, to be Chandra.
Four claws, two wings, one beak, no fear.
The foundries of Kaladesh run like clockwork under the supervision of their formidable overseers.
"I am the first line of defense. You will not encounter the second."
Alhammarret rose to his feet, and the full force of his mind hit Jace like a storm front.
Six feet of earth muffled his cries.
War after war, a healer's enemy is always the same—death itself.
Ravnica's most ancient streets take on a life of their own. A few have decided to move to nicer neighborhoods.
"Your swords and wards have no power here."
On Innistrad, Liliana embraced necromancy, honing her powers by practicing on scores of undead—and sometimes the living.
Ending her life won't end the infestation.
After stripping the sunken ships, it rises to the surface for another helping.
Nothing of nature nor of mortals can stand forever.
Rats and vultures devour. It desecrates.
It's pointless to hold on when you have nothing to hold on with.
The sea respects no boundaries, least of all the coast.
"Guilty."
Goblins journey to the sacrificial peaks in pairs so that the rare survivor might be able to relate the details of the other's grisly demise.
Stray into the Morkrut and it may rise to claim you.
"Come, my beautiful brothers and sisters. Let us hunt."—Dwynen, Gilt-Leaf daen
"This is our land. We will not allow eyeblights to poison its beauty."

"Even from miles away, I could see our eagles circling. That's when I knew we were needed at home."
—Kanlos, Akroan captain
"I want to help Zendikar. Show me the way."—Nissa Revane
"From a tiny sprout, the greatest trees grow and flourish. May the seeds of your mind be equally fruitful."
"I do not reject the gods. I reject their authority, their pettiness, and their arrogance."
True faith is letting the blade fall without parry. True cunning is using that moment to strike a deadly blow.
If you stare at the sun for too long, you'll lose your ability to see clearly.
The essence of nature is change.
Without the interfering hands of civilization, nature will always shape itself to its own needs.
Chandra's gift set her apart and others aflame.
"Boggart blood disgusts me almost as much as the foul creatures themselves."
"I've already seen so much evil, so much darkness. Why do you insist on adding more?"—Nissa Revane, to Dwynen
One faerie distracts the judge while a second steals the law.
The Boros legionnaire saw a noble sacrifice, the Rakdos thug a blazing suicide, and the Izzet alchemist an experiment gone awry.

"I had hoped to instill in it the loyalty of a guard dog, but with fire's power comes its unpredictability."
—Maggath, Sardian elementalist
"Well, this got out of hand."

"Another day. Another avenging angel. Another clump of feathers to toss in the trash."
—Liliana Vess
Grixis is a world where the only things found in abundance are death and decay. Corpses, whole or in part, are the standard currency among necromancers and demons.
All around the foundry, automatons unhitched themselves from their mounts and pivoted to face Chandra.
The city of Ghirapur is a living thing, and living things defend themselves.
The metal must be pure. The hand must be steady. The product must be perfect.
Blessed by the gods. Coveted by mortals. Beholden to neither.
"There is power in abandon, but far more in control."—Warden Hixus, to Kytheon
The wealthy in the city of Ghirapur outfit their lives with grand machines, entrusting even their children to filigree and gears.
The histories speak of two feuding rulers whose deaths were celebrated and whose monuments symbolized the end of their wars. In truth they were peaceful lovers, their story lost to the ages.
Creatures of darkness instinctively hide from the light.
The ethereal touch brings relief. The physical touch brings peace.
Doors, walls, skulls . . . it matters not. All barriers will be broken.
Its blessings are as numerous as the stars of Nyx.
The distinction of bearing the gods' banner is nothing compared to the glory of being closer to Nyx.
Not all spiders need webs to catch their prey.
"I don't need your mage-rings or your mana equations. I call, and the sea answers."—Keyta, rebel hydromancer
One who is marked by a demon in life is sure to be remembered as one in death.

"The cathars have their swords, the inquisitors their axes. I prefer the ‘diplomatic' approach."
—Terhold, archmage of Drunau
Accustomed to battling before an audience in the arena, Iroas's champions know how to put on a good show.
"People's thoughts just come to me. Sometimes I don't know if it's them or me thinking."
A true scribe devotes an entire lifetime to the creation of a single volume, a masterpiece as unique as its maker.
"Where's the fun in an escape if it's not at least a little daring?"
"A single tree does not a forest make. We are stronger when we stand together."—Numa, Joraga chieftain
"To be a knight, Gideon, is to be the shield for the meek against the cruel."
"I will be your most demanding master, Liliana. But I have great things in mind for you."
Kytheon and his irregulars worked outside the law to bring justice to the streets of Akros.
"Seal the gate. This is our fight now."
Life is such a fragile thing.
Eidren, perfect of Lys Alana, ordered hundreds of trees uprooted and rearranged into a pattern he deemed beautiful. Thus the Gilt-Leaf Wood was born.
The harpies descended without mercy upon Akros, only to find their attack put them within range of the javelineers.
"All dead move to the hollow rhythm of necromancy."—Savra
"Don't be rude, Beleren. We just want to enjoy the view with you."
Chief among the tenets of Purphoros is that one must destroy in order to create.
Of royal blood among the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.
Each cut stains his blade with fresh blood that he samples to increase his strength.
"Why does everything the Golgari touch end up sticky?"—Arrester Lavinia, Tenth Precinct
To stand as a guardian of the sea, one must possess the resolve of a mounting wave.
"And if I'm lying," he began . . .
The Joraga elves never need ask a troll to leave their territory. They merely grant it their combined strength, and it can't resist embarking on a merry rampage.
"The southern fortress taken by invaders? Heh, sure . . . when elephants fly."—Brezard Skeinbow, captain of the guard

"It saddens me to lose a source of inspiration. This one seemed especially promising."
—Ashiok
Energy surges in Izzet labs are opportunities for experimentation.
If you can't take the heat . . . well, that's going to be a problem.
"Every death has a web of consequences. Our job is to find the spider."
"The soul sheds light, and death is its shadow. When the light dims, life and death embrace."—Nantuko teaching
Masters of the arcane savor a delicious irony. Their study of deep and complex arcana leads to such a simple end: the ability to say merely yes or no.
The thunder of its hooves beats dreams into despair.
Ravnica would be safer if mere coin was all the Dimir could steal.
The evil inside the mountain pulsed at Nissa in a shock wave of madness.
One orb to guard the body, one to protect the mind, and one to shield the soul.
"Pick not the rotten fruit, but neither touch the best. Leave those as an offering for our unseen guests."—Radwick, farmer of Gatstaf
"Bant's most gallant knights wear my sigil, and for that I am humbled."

"Let nothing own the skies but the wind."
—Dejara, Giltwood druid
A stitcher's attempt at a skaab with a soul.
"Canyons in the Phoberos badlands are essentially gates to the Underworld."—Mirinthes, Akroan captain
Some will sacrifice everything for but a taste of power.
Wear it on your dominant hand and it will follow your lead.

"The desire for its magic horn inspires such bloodthirsty greed that all who see the unicorn will kill to possess it."
—Dionus, elvish archdruid
"I know what you're thinking," Jace whispered in the mage's mind. "It's not going to work."
"I hope to meet Jaya Ballard someday. I think we'd get along."—Chandra Nalaar
She haunts the streets, wings spread wide, with carrion on her breath and blood in her eyes.
As unstoppable as it is unsteerable.
In time, not even the fire monks could keep up with Chandra.
The dead know lessons the living haven't learned.
"I was not convinced you had a soul until I saw it for myself."—Liliana Vess
The wise pay as much attention to what they throw away as to what they keep.
Driven away by his living kin, he wanders mourning through the wilderness, seeking the dead city of Asphodel.
Born from the slaughter of an entire army, it bears the wrath of a hundred souls.
The owls learn of mana from the mages who know it best.
Rumors quickly spread among thieves about a labyrinth without walls and a prize beyond all measures of worth.
Scholars had puzzled for centuries over the ruins at Tal Terig. Its secrets had always lived within one rune-carved head.
"The cathars killed my skaabs down below. Let's see how high their swords can reach."—Ludevic, necro-alchemist
Its screeching is the sound of you losing your mind.
"Trying to stop it would be foolish. If you feel it coming—run!"—Sergeant Ryda
Empires rise and fall, but evil is eternal.
The portcullis is superfluous.
"As long as each side thinks it can win, the balance holds, and the mage-rings stand."—Alhammarret
Follow the light. In its absence, follow her.
To the elves, her spear is a compass; to the boggarts, a harbinger of doom.
Once he gets up and going, he will forever shamble on.
The undisputed master of the mountains of Shiv.
When Asha left Bant, she ensured that the world would have protection and order in her absence.
With each honor he earns, Gideon paves the path to his redemption.
Kruphix hid the most dire prophecies about humankind where humans would never find them and tritons wouldn't care to read them.
Three heads are better than one.
She will not be content until hers is the highest head in the sky.
The only thing more ill-tempered than a griffin in a web is the spider that must subdue it.
The giant Tarvik dreamed that trinkets and machines caused all the world's woe. When he awoke from his troubled sleep, he took the name Tarvik Relicsmasher.
He grants endless wishes, as long as you always wish for a blade.
"You've never considered the implications of dealing with another telepath, Jace."
When things get ugly above ground, goblins resort to alternate routes of passage.
"A master of hieromancy can see the advantage in any scenario."—Warden Hixus, to Kytheon
The blade glows only for Zendikar's chosen.
"Drink this, brother. It will bring you rest."—Liliana Vess
Sometimes violent earthquakes, hurtling boulders, and unseasonable dust storms are wrongly attributed to the Roil.
"I will not rest until the stench of eyeblights is eradicated from these woods."
Thunder doesn't always mean rain. Sometimes it means ruin.
Their strength is no mere numbers game. An intangible force augments the wolves when they run together.
The massive dominate through might. The tiny survive with guile. Beware the tiny who become massive.
"My scars are my sigils. I will wear them with pride long after you're gone."
"Not all nightmares can be escaped by waking."—Ashiok
It is hunted, but not for the kill. The magic within draws others to its presence.
Jenrik's tower is served by those who once sought to enter it uninvited.
The spear thrown by Kytheon's own hand was the weapon that felled his friends.
"Ribbit."
"Get up. You're not finished yet."—Liliana Vess
Liliana viewed the attention of the angels as a testament to her power. Even so, they were an annoyance.
They became a single entity, a phalanx in the Temple of Triumph standing against a host of enemies.

"A long and difficult incision revealed that all vital organs are housed in the head, save for a long chain of stomachs, forty in all, leading from its throat to the end of the tail."—Mulak Ffar, Vastwood Biodiversity
"I've broken three swords, eighteen lances, and countless shields, but this little blade has survived every battle, just like I have."
Nissa found that the vines of the marsh could ensnare just as well as forest vines could—maybe even better.
It moves through lava with the force of an erupting volcano.
It's the favored mount of military commanders as well as anyone with a flair for the dramatic.
The reverberations course through the warriors' veins, beat with their hearts, and pound with their footfalls as they charge into battle.
"When you are felled by my mace, you shall know it was divine fate."
"Beware an eddy where there should be none or a stretch that flows too fast or too slow."—Old Fishbones, Martyne river guide
Destiny is a flickering path among tangled possibilities.
Proud Alkmenos, who would not bow to Erebos in death, is now bowed by his own hubris for all eternity.
Nissa had only the space of a heartbeat to react, her instincts steering her blade.
"Master your mind, or I shall master it for you."
"Nature can't be stopped. It rips and tears at Ravnica's tallest buildings to claim its place in the sun."
It was in fields of grain, not fields of battle, that the Champion learned to bear the yoke of duty to the gods. She worked the land long before she was called on to defend it.—The Theriad
"Her people angered Zendikar, and they faced the land's wrath. That is why Nissa is the last of the animists."—Numa, Joraga chieftain
"I was wrong. Zendikar isn't after me. It isn't after any of us. It's not evil or vengeful. It's magnificent . . . but it's in pain."—Nissa Revane

"I fear to keep an open mind, for there are those who would use it as a door to my soul."
—Voka Schlak,
Mauzam Asylum inmate, diary
Its fickle form holds hints of a thousand former identities.
"You say that I am two-faced? Enough with the flattery. We have business to conduct."

"I feel in them a sense of duty and commitment, yet I can feel nothing else. It is as if their duty is to an empty void."
—Razia
It tracks its victims by the scent of their breath, preferring to dine on those who recently ate well.

"It's easy to see why those Gruul dirtbags follow him—the only orders he gives are ‘Crush them!' and ‘We eat!'"
—Teysa
Gruul shamans are bent on punishing the civilized. Any act more complex than rubbing sticks together or eating with utensils is met with the stinging burn of their magic.

"We have no need for military might. We wield two of the sharpest swords ever forged: Faith in our left hand, Wealth in our right."
—Vuliev of the Ghost Council

"Looking out the great windows of Vitu-Ghazi at the foundry stacks belching their smoke to the sky, I wonder when the sky will take its vengeance."
—Heruj, Selesnya initiate
Izzet brains and Izzet boilers: contents under pressure.
Orzhov faithful file past to have their minds purged of "impure" desires. There, the guiltwardens eliminate any thoughts of hope or self-sufficiency.

"The other guilds think they're untouchable. It's time we brought them back down to earth."
—Ghut Rak, Gruul guildmage
Cremation of the dead is not a religious ritual in Ravnica. It's a business designed to keep the Golgari from growing in numbers.

"Piece the tragic notes together and is it not a melody?"
—Teysa
"Surprise is a useless, untidy emotion—the plaything of goblins and fools."

"Who truly runs this city? Look to the sky on hallowed days, and see whose sigil is stamped clearly onto the heavens."
—Vuliev of the Ghost Council
The Simic use the claws as scalpels, while the Rakdos use them for tattooing and torture. The Gruul use them to pick their teeth after lunching on the rest of the carcass.
One moment, conscious only of a sense of repose. The next moment, hearing the trudge of his own footsteps. He sighed and squinted into the glare ahead.
Orzhov prisoners are steeped in a blackened brew that robs their souls of strength. Patriarchs drink that brew to extend their own lives.
" . . . and you must also apply for an application license, file documents 136(iv) and 22-C and -D in triplicate, pay all requisite fees, request a . . ."
Lurking below the current, she thirsts until others come to drink.
From Tin Street to the Outcast Mansions, she walks unbidden and unbound, her graceful silence never shaken by the riot of city life around her.
When it awoke, it spawned nameless thousands to herald its arrival.

"Some gardeners sing to plants. I tell them stories—stories of how they once ruled the world, of the mortals who destroyed their kind, and of revenge."
—Bougrat, druid of the Cult of Yore
The Izzet learn something from every lesson they teach.

"The first blow is the most important. It often negates the need for a second."
—Agrus Kos
He chanted over a pot of boiling blood and honey. His brain buzzed like a nest of hornets, and his muscles rippled with the might of the bear.
The chant was interrupted, the components cooked, and Zok worried that it was his brain he smelled smoking.
"Garb is for common folk. I prefer to wear insight and zeal, ambition and flame."

"Diametrically opposing energies in self-sealed plasmodermic bubbles make great pets!"
—Trivaz, Izzet mage
At mealtimes, the Gruul customarily omit such niceties as using forks or killing the entrée.
The snap of sinew. The crunch of bone. A cry for mercy. These are the music of the Gruul.

"I thought of fate as an iron lattice, intricate but rigidly unchangeable. That was until some force bent fate's bars to spare my life."
—Ilromov, traveling storyteller

"I watched its blade swing through me, but I was hollow, empty. I saw its face contort in rage but could not hear it snarl."
—Klattic, Boros legionnaire

"We respect all lifeforms, but this one we respect from a distance."
—Mandor, Selesnya ranger
When it awoke, it shook the plane with the thunder of its craving.
Rerouting magic through a goblin's brain is the surest way to throw it wildly off course.
Loyal in battle, hearty in stew.

Petting the nodorog
—Gruul expression meaning
"making a really big mistake"
The Gruul aren't satisfied with just smashing things. They continue smashing other things with the things they just smashed.
Gruul territorial markings need not be legible. The blood, snot, and muck used to smear them are unmistakably Gruul.

"Steering apparatus?! What for? Rip it out, sharpen it, and lash it to the front!"
—Ktank, Gruul plowmaster
The soldier moved with fluid poise, his awareness extending far beyond five senses.
Moon Market merchants sell a bottled scent to cutpurses and other criminals. Those doused in the liquid become "griffin bait."
So wondrous to behold, so delicate and finely crafted—and yet, such a pleasure to smash.
All that remains when the fog finishes are neat piles of polished bones, like acid-etched glass. Orzhov servants collect them to make altar chimes.
Zap on. Zap off.

"In secrecy is strength. None can oppose one who cannot be found."
—Szadek
When it awoke, the mirrors of the world reflected only darkness.
To those in tune with the Firemind, there is no difference between knowledge and flame.
He ensures not only whether but also when and where the lightning strikes twice.
The Izzet signet is redesigned often, each time becoming closer to a vanity portrait of Niv-Mizzet.
"Take the bridge, men! Victory! Victory is ou— Retreat! RETREAT!"
Where sovereignty and flesh converge.
Where storm and spellcraft converge.
Where renown and solitude converge.
Where strength and humility converge.
Where treachery and oblivion converge.
"Your signet is no symbol of power. It marks only your need for numbers to aid you. What do you do, guild-rat, now that you face my blade alone?"
Rakdos cultists hanged her for sport in the township square. Her ghost now stands vigil at what has become known as the Tree of Weeping.

"What is it? Um . . . what do you want it to be?"
—Juzba, Izzet tinker
The eyes let flow with tears, then blood, then the very soul—the whole wrung inside out, dripping down into the blackened puddle of the past.
During their ascent to spirithood, patriarchs of Orzhova shed both flesh and emotion. This earthly slag is collected and formed into thrulls.
Niv-Mizzet's genius and vanity reverberate throughout the mirrored halls of Nivix.
He's an oxymoron.
As stoic as the marble halls, as unblinking as the stars upon their shields.
The form of the sigil is just as important as the sigil itself. If it's carried on a medallion, its bearer is a master. If it's tattooed on the body, its bearer is a slave.
Unlike most churches, at Orzhova it's best to pray before you arrive.
Orzhov churches don't pass the plate for collection. They charge for admission.
"You can't have so many people living so close together, all practicing so much magic, and not expect some feedback."
It departs through the streets' fissures with a sound like gravel pouring into a pond.
Which is worse—the sleep which never ends or that which never comes?

"Look at her, once filled with innocence. Death has a way of wringing away such . . . deficiencies."
—Savra
Some claim it's a failed Simic experiment, others say a Golgari creation. Both guilds deny all responsibility, while secretly studying its strange virulence.
Instinct blood-tinted his world until he could see only one thing clearly: his prey.

"Look to the old tomes, those bound in hides and written in yarberry ink. They hold the spells that can free us of the clutter of modern magecraft."
—Dravash, dowsing shaman
A skilled Izzet chronarch can carry out an epic vendetta between the fall of one hourglass grain and the next.

"Your deed cannot be undone. You, however, can be."
—Agosto, Azorius imperator

"We mourn our dead. We shroud our dead. We bury our dead. Too often, it seems, we must kill our dead again."
—Grazda, veteran armorer
"The Golgari raise the bodies of their dead to serve. We raise the spirits of our dead to lead."
The Orzhov contract the Izzet to animate slum districts and banish them to the wastes. The Gruul adopt them and send them back to the city for vengeance.

"Ever try to count hyperactive schoolchildren while someone shouts random numbers in your ear? It's like that."
—Geetra, frustrated mage

"Our fealty to guilds dooms us. The old gods shall resurface. Our skins will wave upon the guild-masts over emptied streets, and our bones will clatter in the wind."
—Ilromov, traveling storyteller

"Nature is the ultimate mindless destroyer, capable of power and ferocity no army can match, and the Gruul follow its example."
—Trigori, Azorius senator
They inflict pain to forget their own and break foes to feel whole.

"I ran the experiment through the brain of a schizophrenic lab-goblin. My burners' flames fell asleep while the beakers jumped about and shattered. Success!"
—Myznar, Izzet psychomancer
Each small blaze she sets jogs her memory, letting her piece together the mystery of her own fiery end.
Shadow lances are crafted from harvested souls. The more wicked the sinner, the keener the blade.
Orzhov mage-sculptors bring their stone to life before they carve it. The shrieking begins as soon as the mouths are formed.
Street folk call them "spire mice," but behind the mockery is an unspoken envy of the ledgewalkers' skill at avoiding harm.
In light he finds both gift and weapon.
"Steel rusts. Arrows break. But righteousness is always strong, always sharp."

"This palace will be our fire-spit, and roasted prince our victory meal. Send in the torch-pigs!"
—Ghut Rak, Gruul guildmage

"The sky isn't falling—it's being thrown at us!"
—Otak, Tin Street shopkeep
Would you trade the world for such a pet?
"Of course I plan on going up. Kang here is the most trusted 'fin on the squad. Afraid? Me? No, I'm just . . . waiting for the right wind conditions."

"An entire order of mages who draw their power from Ravnica's smog? Yet another indicator of our world's decay."
—Dravash, dowsing shaman

"More horrible than their empty forms are their noble eyes. I dare not strike."
—Klattic, Boros legionnaire
His assistants calculate the amount of the tribute. He measures out the punishment for delinquency.

"No more wretched fate is there than to waste away. If you are slain, your ghost may at least avenge itself upon your killer. But what release is there for one slain by Time?"
—Ilromov, traveling storyteller
Like many Izzet creations, weirds are based on wild contradictions yet somehow manage to work.
Quyzl was told by his mentor to "make more time" for his studies.

"When you hear thunder on a cloudless day, take cover and brace for the coming of the storm herd."
—Skotov, Tin Street basket vendor
The "Days of Darkness" mark the stratozeppelids' annual migration, when for five days they blot out the sun and trumpet their passing.
The Orzhov run a construction unit whose only business is rebuilding the wreckage left in the wake of wurms. When business is slow, they pay Golgari carnomancers to lure the wurms to the surface.
The clouds grew thick, and then they grew teeth.
Tracing the horizon in a dance of wind and fire.
"Rauck-Chauv's like a holiday! Only it isn't on the calendars, and instead of dancing you knock people flat, and instead of giving gifts you break stuff."

"The call came, spell-borne through mortar and stone to the ear of every soldier. The call came, and the advantage was ours."
—Lodusz, captain of the watch

"Drakes? Bah! Things that breathe don't interest me. It breathes fire, you say? Well, that's a different story!"
—Zataz, Izzet clockwork artificer
"But then . . . oh, but . . . which means . . . which would lead to . . . exactly!"
"Fair? At what point in our negotiations did you convince yourself my goal was to be fair?"

"The blazekite is a simple concept, really—just a vehicular application of dragscoop ionics and electropropulsion magnetronics."
—Juzba, Izzet tinker
They are the voice of the wild, crying out with nature's fury and bringing forth its primeval might.
Two times the size, four times the smell.
When it awoke, it shattered the hillsides to make way for its passage.

"Defense is as much a part of war as offense, the shield as important a tool as the sword."
—Alovnek, Boros guildmage

"Crush them!"
—Borborygmos
Some use magic to spy through walls. Others use it to crush them.
When it awoke, the worms of the earth hissed in a chorus of beckoning.

"There are two ways for me to pass this gate. One involves you remaining conscious."
—Gerrard of the Weatherlight
To gaze under its hood is to invite death.
"Wrath is no vice when inflicted upon the deserving."
Every tear shed is a drop of immortality.
If taken, it cuts the hand that clutches it. If given, it heals the hand that holds it.

"Even in single combat, I am never alone."
—Rafiq of the Many
If only every message were as perfect as its bearer.

"My family sheltered in her light, the dark was content to wait."
—Crovax
Clash of sword and cry of beast fall mute when angels sound the call to prayer.

"In the game of conquest, who cares about the pawns if the king yet reigns?"
—Geth, keeper of the Vault
The thrulls bred at a terrifying pace. In the end, they overwhelmed the Order of the Ebon Hand.
Its laughter drives needles through your mind.
"Hope shall be the blade that severs our bonds."

"Your blood, your marrow, your spirit—all are mine."
—Mayvar, minion of Geth
There are things beneath the murk for whom the bog is a stew, a thin broth in need of meat.

"Choose your next words carefully. They will be your last."
—Phage the Untouchable
The Simic use the claws as scalpels, while the Rakdos use them for tattooing and torture. The Gruul use them to pick their teeth after lunching on the rest of the carcass.

"Ha, banishment? Be merciful, say ‘death,'
For exile hath more terror in his look,
Much more than death."
—William Shakespeare, Romeo and Juliet

"Leshrac, my liege, grant me the power I am due."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer
Its curve mimics the twists of life and death.
They knock 'em dead, with or without the punch line.
Liliana learned the secrets she sought, but at a price that was etched on her fate.
"Change your mind, or I'll change it for you."
Imps are just intelligent enough to have an understanding of cruelty.
"Why do you weep for the dead? I rejoice, for they have died for me."
The imp, unaware of its own odor, paused to catch its breath . . . and promptly died.
Grelden knelt and felt the cool, dry hand of the priest on his brow. Hours later, when his wits returned, he was covered in his enemies' blood on the field of victory.
"My summoning begins your debt, planeswalker."
"The spread of evil's destruction shall always be matched by the rise of the noble fallen."

"The landscape shimmered and I felt a chill breeze. When my vision cleared, I found myself alone among the corpses of my fallen friends."
—Journal found in Numai
Slow and steady may not always win the race, but at least it doesn't end up splattered on the walls.
Even those born to battle could only lay their blades at Akroma's feet.
"You have not died until I consent."

"Until the world unites in vengeful fury and Phage is destroyed, I will not stay my hand."
—Akroma, angelic avenger
An angel's blessing prepares a soldier for war better than a thousand military drills.
Her sword sings more beautifully than any choir.

"The light of an angel's glance is warm, but her fixed stare blinds and burns."
—Calexis, deacon of the New Order of Serra
The touch of Serra's angels bears hopes aloft and empowers noble causes.

"If one gets in your chimney, you're going to need a long wick and a barrel of bangstuff to get it out."
—Hob Heddil
Don't drink and thrive.
You may break her shield, but you'll never break her spirit.
Such power grows the body as it shrinks the soul.
Age wears the flesh but galvanizes the soul.
Four gray trees and a long, coiling snake. What am I? —Zhalfirin riddle

"As you breathe your last, understand why I accept such forbidden gifts."
—Purraj of Urborg
If you find yourself and a friend being chased by a king cheetah, you have but one chance: Trip your friend. —Suq'Ata wisdom

"Ah, I remember my first death."
—Zarkuu, necrosavant

"By the tongues of a thousand serpents, this time I do not lie."
—Ahmahz il Kin, Suq'Ata diplomat

"My pet will pick the ripe fruit from your tortured brain as if it were hanging from a vine."
—Kaervek

"Some believe sandstalkers to be illusions; those with scars know better."
—Zhalfirin Guide to the Desert

"The blood on my hands is merely proof of my ambition."
—Kaervek
These spirits of the air are winsome and wild and cannot be truly contained. Only marginally intelligent, they often substitute whimsy for strategy, delighting in mischief and mayhem.
Benalia has a complex caste system that changes with the lunar year. No matter what the season, the only caste that cannot be attained by either heredity or money is that of the hero.
Battle doesn't need a purpose; the battle is its own purpose. You don't ask why a plague spreads or a field burns. Don't ask why I fight.

'Twas in the bogs of Cannelbrae
My mate did meet an early grave
'Twas nothing left for us to save
In the peat-filled bogs of Cannelbrae.

The most terrifying thing about the Craw Wurm is probably the horrible crashing sound it makes as it speeds through the forest. This noise is so loud it echoes through the trees and seems to come from all directions at once.
Created to destroy Dominia, Demons can sometimes be bent to a more focused purpose.

"O to be a dragon . . . of silkworm size or immense . . ."
—Marianne Moore, "O to Be a Dragon"
Bones scattered around us joined to form misshapen bodies. We struck at them repeatedly—they fell, but soon formed again, with the same mocking look on their faceless skulls.
Foolishly, Najib retreated to his castle at El-Abar; the next morning he was dead. In just one night, the dwarven forces had reduced the mighty walls to mere rubble.

Earth Elementals have the eternal strength of stone and the endurance of mountains. Primordially connected to the land they inhabit, they take a long-term view of things, scorning the impetuous haste of short-lived mortal creatures.
I tell you, there was so many arrows flying about you couldn't hardly see the sun. So I says to young Angus, "Well, at least now we're fighting in the shade!"

Fire Elementals are ruthless infernos, annihilating and consuming their foes in a frenzied holocaust. Crackling and blazing, they sear swift, terrible paths, leaving the land charred and scorched in their wake.

"And topples round the dreary west
A looming bastion fringed with fire."
—Alfred, Lord Tennyson, "In Memoriam"

"There are some qualities—some incorporate things,/ That have a double life, which thus is made/ A type of twin entity which springs/ From matter and light, evinced in solid and shade."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "Silence"
Rather than sheltering her young, the female Fungusaur often injures her own offspring, thereby ensuring their rapid growth.
While it possesses potent venom, the Giant Spider often chooses not to paralyze its victims. Perhaps the creature enjoys the gentle rocking motion caused by its captives' struggles to escape its web.
"From up here we can drop rocks and arrows and more rocks!" "Uh, yeah boss, but how do we get down?"
To become king of the Goblins, one must assassinate the previous king. Thus, only the most foolish seek positions of leadership.

"While most overworlders fortunately don't realize this, Gargoyles can be most delicious, providing you have the appropriate tools to carve them."
—The Underworld Cookbook by Asmoranomardicadaistinaculdacar

The Ogre philosopher Gnerdel believed the purpose of life was to live as high on the food chain as possible. She refused to eat vegetarians, and preferred to live entirely on creatures that preyed on sentient beings.

Don't try to outrun one of Dominia's Grizzlies; it'll catch you, knock you down, and eat you. Of course, you could run up a tree. In that case you'll get a nice view before it knocks the tree down and eats you.
Fortunately, Hill Giants have large blind spots in which a human can easily hide. Unfortunately, these blind spots are beneath the bottoms of their feet.

The Minotaurs of the Hurloon Mountains are known for their love of battle. They are also known for their hymns to the dead, sung for friend and foe alike. These hymns can last for days, filling the mountain valleys with their low, haunting sounds.

"...There was no trace/ Of aught on that illumined face..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Phantom"
Generations of genetic weeding have given rise to the deviously cowardly Ironclaw clan. To say that Orcs in general are vicious, depraved, and ignoble does not do justice to the Ironclaw.

The mating habits of Treefolk, particularly the stalwart Ironroot Treefolk, are truly absurd. Molasses comes to mind. It's amazing the species can survive at all given such protracted periods of mate selection, conjugation, and gestation.

"Some of the other guys dared me to touch it, but I knew it weren't no ordinary hunk o' rock."
—Norin the Wary
We had taken refuge in a small cave, thinking the entrance was too narrow for it to follow. To our horror, its gigantic head smashed into the mountainside, ripping itself a new entrance.
After years of training, the Druid becomes one with nature, drawing power from the land and returning it when needed.

Some fiendish mage had created a horrifying wall of living flesh, patched together from a jumble of still-recognizable body parts. As we sought to hew our way through it, some unknown power healed the gaping wounds we cut, denying us passage.
Whenever the Llanowar Elves gather the fruits of their forest, they leave one plant of each type untouched, considering that nature's portion.
A master of tactics, the Lord of Atlantis makes his people bold in battle merely by arriving to lead them.
Of royal blood among the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti Djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.

Most human scholars believe that Merfolk are the survivors of sunken Atlantis, humans adapted to the water. Merfolk, however, believe that humans sprang forth from Merfolk who adapted themselves in order to explore their last frontier.

Before a woman marries in the village of Sursi, she must visit the land of the Mesa Pegasus. Legend has it that if the woman is pure of heart and her love is true, a Mesa Pegasus will appear, blessing her family with long life and good fortune.

The intricate dynamics of Rundvelt Goblin affairs are often confused with anarchy. The chaos, however, is the chaos of a thundercloud, and direction will sporadically and violently appear. Pashalik Mons and his raiders are the thunderhead that leads in the storm.
The Nightmare arises from its lair in the swamps. As the poisoned land spreads, so does the Nightmare's rage and terrifying strength.

"Look to the north; there you will find aid and comfort."
—The Book of Tal

"The foot stone is connected to the ankle stone, the ankle stone is connected to the leg stone . . ."
—Song of the Artificer
In a rare display of ingenuity, the Orcs invented an incredibly destructive weapon. Most Orcish artillerists are those who dared criticize its effectiveness.

"‘Do you know, I always thought Unicorns were fabulous monsters, too? I never saw one alive before!' ‘Well, now that we have seen each other,' said the Unicorn, ‘if you'll believe in me, I'll believe in you.'"
—Lewis Carroll
These beings embody the essence of true heroes long dead. Summoned from the dreamrealms, they rise to meet their enemies.

"While, like a ghastly rapid river,
Through the pale door,
A hideous throng rush out forever,
And laugh—but smile no more."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "The Haunted Palace"

"Should you a Rat to madness tease
Why ev'n a Rat may plague you..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Recantation"
Occasionally a member of the Institute of Arcane Study acquires a taste for worldly pleasures. Seldom do they have trouble finding employment.

We encountered a valley topped with immense boulders and eerie rock formations. Suddenly one of these boulders toppled from its perch and sprouted gargantuan wings, casting a shadow of darkness and sending us fleeing in terror.
Trained in the arts of stealth, the royal assassins choose their victims carefully, relying on timing and precision rather than brute force.
Healers ultimately acquire the divine gifts of spiritual and physical wholeness. The most devout are also granted the ability to pass physical wholeness on to others.

The traditional kings of the jungle command a healthy respect in other climates as well. Relying mainly on their stealth and speed, Savannah Lions can take a victim by surprise, even in the endless flat plains of their homeland.

"They groaned, they stirred, they all uprose,/ Nor spake, nor moved their eyes;/ It had been strange, even in a dream,/
To have seen those dead men rise."/
—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"
The only sound was the gentle clicking of the Faeries' wings. Then those intruders who were still standing turned and fled. One thing was certain: they didn't think the Scryb were very funny anymore.
Legend has it that Serpents used to be bigger, but how could that be?

The stench in the hovel was overpowering; something loathsome was cooking. Occasionally something surfaced in the thick paste, but my host would casually push it down before I could make out what it was.
Born with wings of light and a sword of faith, this heavenly incarnation embodies both fury and purity.
Moving without sound, swift figures pass through branches and undergrowth completely unhindered. One with the trees around them, the Dryads of Shanodin Forest are seen only when they wish to be.

While it's true most Dragons are cruel, the Shivan Dragon seems to take particular glee in the misery of others, often tormenting its victims much like a cat plays with a mouse before delivering the final blow.
What goes up, must come down.
Moss-covered statues littered the area, a macabre monument to the Basilisk's power.
Though many think of Wolves as solitary predators, they are actually extremely social animals. During a hunt they often call to each other, which can be quite unsettling for their prey.
None know if this Giant is the result of aberrant magics, Siamese twins, or a mentalist's schizophrenia.

"Oi oi oi, me gotta hurt in 'ere
Oi oi oi, me smell a ting is near,
Gonna bosh 'n gonna nosh 'n da
hurt'll disappear."
—Traditional
Some say magic was first practiced by women, who have always felt strong ties to the land.
Good bodyguards are hard to find, mainly because they don't live long.
"This 'standing windstorm' can hold us off indefinitely? Ridiculous!" Saying nothing, she put a pinch of salt on the table. With a bang she clapped her hands, and the salt disappeared, blown away.
The Wall of Bone is said to be an aspect of the Great Wall in Hel, where the bones of all sinners wait for Ragnarok, when Hela will call them forth for the final battle.

"What else, when chaos draws all forces inward to shape a single leaf."
—Conrad Aiken
Conjured from the bowels of hell, the fiery wall forms an impassable barrier, searing the soul of any creature attempting to pass through its terrible bursts of flame.

"And through the drifts the snowy cliffs/ Did send a dismal sheen:/ Nor shapes of men nor beasts we ken—/ The ice was all between."/
—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"

The Earth herself lends her strength to these walls of living stone, which possess the stability of ancient mountains. These mighty bulwarks thwart ground-based troops, providing welcome relief for weary warriors who defend the land.

Just as the evil ones approached to slay Justina, she cast a great spell, imbuing her weapons with her own life force. Thus she fulfilled the prophecy: "In the death of your savior will you find salvation."
A deafening roar arose as the fury of an enormous vertical river supplanted our serenity. Eddies turned into whirling geysers, leveling everything in their path.
Everybody knows that to ward off trouble, you knock on wood. But usually it's better to make a wall out of the wood and let trouble do the knocking.
I didn't think Mammoths could ever hold a candle to a well-trained battle horse. Then one day I turned my back on a drunken soldier. His blow never landed; Mi'cha flung the brute over ten meters.

Unpredictable as the sea itself, Water Elementals shift without warning from tranquility to tempest. Capricious and fickle, they flow restlessly from one shape to another, expressing their moods with their physical forms.
Out of the blackness and stench of the engulfing swamp emerged a shimmering figure. Only the splattered armor and ichor-stained sword hinted at the unfathomable evil the knight had just laid waste.

"About, about in reel and rout
The death-fires danced at night;
The water, like a witch's oils,
Burnt green, and blue and white."
—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"
They say the Zombie Master controlled these foul creatures even before his own death, but now that he is one of them, nothing can make them betray him.
The rising of the first full moon eliminated any doubt as to the horrible truth lurking within.
Being an alpha means proving it every full moon.

"This is the light of Avacyn. Even in her absence she offers us hope."
—Radulf, priest of Avacyn
"The price is paid. The power is mine!"
Those who know the alleys and sewers of the Erdwal can disappear like smoke.

"It may not look like much, but it's a good old door with strong wards. It'll hold."
—Olgard of the Skiltfolk
"Come, let me free you of the tyranny of thought."
Its last life is spent tormenting your dreams.
Succession is a matter of blood, and by blood it is often decided.

"I can think of worse ways to go. On second thought, maybe not."
—Ludevic, necro-alchemist

"The wolves turned on us and a chill swept over me. The pack had a new leader."
—Alena, trapper of Kessig

"Grab an axe and defend the gate! Your despair is an extravagance we can ill afford."
—Thalia, Knight-Cathar
Every now and then, a devil's prank can give you a good idea.
The bitter taste of life's only certainty.
The sweet taste of hope's promise.
The skifsang, seafarers of Nephalia, craft spells like other sailors craft nets—making them strong enough to snare even the deadliest catch.
"Wait . . . did you fellows hear something?"
"I have been found worthy by this great house . . ."
"Pathetic. Let me show you how it's done."

"Your veil's curse won't stop me, deathmage. I have taken down countless night hunters and this dark plane is not big enough for you to hide."
—Garruk Wildspeaker, to Liliana Vess
It is the demon's mark, an infernal claim on the flesh of the guilty.
