"We drive the dragons from our home. Why should we fear you?"
—Fire Eye, viashino bey

"How could you not hear it approach? It's a hippo!"
—Argivian commander
"It will be the goblin's first bath, and its last." —Fire Eye, viashino bey
Its windpipe is only the first to amplify its maddening laughter.
It's all fun and games until someone loses an eye.

"Without order comes errors, and errors kill on Tolaria."
—Barrin, master wizard
Radiant's eyes flashed. "Go, then," the angel spat at Serra, "and leave this world to those who truly care."
Instead of creating a tool that would be damaged by heat, the Thran built one that was charged by it.
The druids found a haven in the cool limestone tunnels beneath Argoth. The invaders found only tigers.
A snake in the grasp.
From deep in the caves beneath the forest, the hierophants planned the druids' raids against the enemy.
When the Brotherhood of Gix dug out the cave of Koilos they found their master's severed hand. They enshrined it, hoping that one day it would point the way to Phyrexia.

"All we could lose, we did. All we could keep, we do. And both are shrouded by mists."
—Barrin, master wizard

"I don't understand why he works so hard on a device to duplicate a sound so easily made with hand and armpit."
—Barrin, progress report

"In the gathering there is strength for all who founder, renewal for all who languish, love for all who sing."
—Song of All, canto 642
Start with eleven gnomes and a room of parts, and come morning you'll have ten and a monster the likes of which you've never seen.
It is not unusual for a single family of coral merfolk to spend centuries carefully guiding the growth of the reefs where they make their home.
Yawgmoth brushed Urza's mind, and Urza's world convulsed.

Mother, sleep / Dream our lives
Our roots your soul / Our leaves your bed.
They are Phyrexia's couriers; the messages they carry are inscribed on their slick hides.
Harbin's ornithopter had been trapped for two days within the currents of the storm. When the skies cleared, all he could see was a horizon of trees.
As Serra was to learn, the peace and sanctity of her realm were as fragile as glass.
". . . But I'm not tired!"

"From void evolved Phyrexia. Great Yawgmoth, Father of Machines, saw its perfection. Thus The Grand Evolution began."
—Phyrexian Scriptures

"Yawgmoth spent eons wrapping Phyrexians in human skin. They are the sleeper agents, and they are everywhere."
—Xantcha, to Urza

"Your enemies will pound upon the door of your defenses, but only you shall have the key, and it is the key of life."
—Song of All, canto 873
Red sky at night, dragon's delight.
Beauty is beyond law.
A religious order for religious order.

"Let Phyrexia breed evil in the darkness; my holy light will reveal its taint."
—Serra

"Then, just when the other guys were winnin', the sky threw up."
—Jula, goblin raider

"Teferi is a problem student. Always late for class. No appreciation for constructive use of time."
—Barrin, progress report
The academy's libraries were protected by fire-prevention spells. Even after the disaster, the books were intact—though forever sealed in time.
Fire in the blood, fire in the belly.
They say dromosaurs are frightened of dogs, even little ones. There are no dogs in Shiv. Not even little ones.

"We decide who is worthy of our works."
—Gix, Yawgmoth praetor

"Their fragile world. Their futile lives. They obstruct the Grand Evolution. In Yawgmoth's name, we shall excise them."
—Oath of the East
Shivan inhabitants are hardened to fire, so their predators have developed alternative weaponry.
Arrows fletched with the feathers of angels seldom miss their mark.
Before Urza and Mishra came to Argoth, the herders prevented their creatures from stampeding. During the war, they encouraged it.
Ages ago, a party of elves took cover to let one pass. They're still waiting.
The mage felt as though he'd been in the stasis suit for days. Upon his return, he found it was months.

"Death—an outmoded concept. We sleep, and we change."
—Sitrik, birth priest
The first explorers found Argoth a storehouse of natural wealth—towering forests grown over rich veins of ore.
The power of faith is quiet. It is the leaf unmoved by the hurricane.
Like a sleeping dragon, Shiv stirs and groans at times.

We live on the serpent's back.
—Viashino saying
Life is eternal. A lifetime is ephemeral.
The forest was too lush for the brothers to despoil—almost.
Visitors to Shiv fear the dragons, the goblins, or the viashino. Natives fear the ants.
Though the reaver is horrifyingly effective, its dorsal vents spit a highly corrosive cloud of filth.
Fiko summoned only atogs for three straight sessions. The tutor couldn't decide whether to punish his failure or praise his consistency.
The forest grew back so quickly that lumbering machines were suspended in the treetops.

"Here sprouted the first seedling of Argoth. Here the last tree will fall."
—Gamelen, Citanul elder
The forest rose to the battle, not to save the people but to save itself.
When you've got nothing, you might as well trade it for something else.
Buyer beware.
Once heard, the battle song of an angel becomes part of the listener forever.
"If you kids don't stop that racket, I'm turning this expedition around right now!"
All bark, someone else's bite.
There's always room for one more.
They certainly are.

"Take the sharp metal stick and make a lotta holes."
—Jula, goblin raider
He was proud to wear the lizard skin around his waist, just for the fun of annoying the enemy.

"It only short jump. You go first."
"AIIIEEEE!"
"Hmm . . . we go different way now."
The gorilla beat its chest and threw great handfuls of leaves into the air. It howled challenge and showed its teeth. The mechanical soldier, not understanding, simply killed it.

"Let go your mind. Mine is fitter."
—Gix, Yawgmoth praetor

"As a great whale dies, it flips onto its back. And so an island is born."
—Mariners' legend

"We have more sprouts than they have hands."
—Gamelen, Citanul elder
When the giant returned for the night, he found a dead merfolk on his pillow. Although he praised the little guma, he inwardly wondered where she had hid the head.
Each day at dusk the birds above the canopy grow silent.
A landslide of goblins poured toward the defenders—tumbling, rolling, and bouncing their way down the steep hillside.

"Xantcha is recovering. The medicine is slow, but my magic would have killed her."
—Serra, to Urza
It's not known whether the Thran built the device to forge their wonders or to defend them.

"Books can be replaced; a prize student cannot. Be patient."
—Urza, to Barrin
On its way to the cave, the armadillo brushed by a sapling. It awoke to find a full-grown tree blocking its path.
The only alert the invaders had was the rustling of leaves on a day without wind.
It wants only to dress you in silk.
A hollow dog is never empty. It is filled with thirst for the hunt.
Designed to carry equipment across rivers, the hopping automaton was soon pressed into service in the infantry.
In the final days before the disaster, all the crabs on Tolaria migrated from inlets, streams, and ponds back to the sea. No one took note.

"It is not your place to rule, Radiant. It may not even be mine."
—Serra
Urza thought it a crusade. Xantcha knew it was a robbery.
"It followed me home. Can I keep it?"
"We each have our own strengths, Radiant," Serra said with a sly smile. "If all of my people were like this one, who would carry your scrolls?"
The pungent smell of roasting flesh made both mages realize they'd rather break for dinner than fight.
Birds frozen in flight. Sea turned to glass. Tolaria hidden in a mirror.
The shade tracks victims by reverberations of the pipes, as a spider senses prey tangled in its trembling web.

"Ash is our air, darkness our flesh."
—Phyrexian Scriptures
Catastrophes happened so often at the mana rig that the viashino language had a special word to describe them.
The helix was the finest example of Mishra's campaign strategy: if he couldn't have Argoth, no one could.
"Belief is the strongest mortar."
"We plant the seeds of doubt to harvest the crop of wisdom."

"The soul? Here, we have no use for such frivolities."
—Sitrik, birth priest

"Do not presume to speak for yourself."
—Gix, to Xantcha

"Push one goblin into sight, an' run a lot. That's tactics."
—Jula, goblin raider

"Fight? I cannot. I do not care if I live or die, so long as I can rest."
—Urza, to Serra

"All bonds are parasitic. Only rulership is pure."
—Gix, Yawgmoth praetor
"It is not sad," Radiant chided the lesser angel. "It is right. Every society must have its outcasts."

"When the sword becomes a burden, let the warrior lay it aside that another with a truer heart might take it up."
—Radiant, archangel

"The clouds came alive and dove to the earth! Hooves flashed among the dark army, who fled before the spectacle of fury."
—Song of All, canto 211
The mages of Tolaria found strange ways to spend their free time. Occasionally they had contests to see whose kite was eaten last.
Devoured by the mists, Tolaria was stuck in time, trapped between two eternal heartbeats.
That the Tolarian mists parted for the drakes was warning enough to stay away.

"My finest warrior was lost to the Phyrexians. I pray that Lady Selenia died honorably."
—Radiant, archangel
Phyrexia wastes nothing. Its food chain is a spiraling cycle.
Living metal encasing dying flesh.
Yotian soldiers were designed to fight, not watch their feet.

"From womb of nothingness sprang this place of beauty, purity, and hope realized."
—Song of All, canto 3

"Planeswalking isn't about walking. It's about falling and screaming."
—Xantcha, Phyrexian outcast
One pounce, she's hungry—you die quickly. Two, she's teaching her cubs—you're in for a long day.

Peace to all. Peace be all.
—Great Hall floor inscription

"Gix doesn't want a people to rule but puppets to entertain his madness."
—Xantcha, Phyrexian outcast
Titania rewards all those who honor the forest by making them a living part of it.

"When I say it rained, it was not small drops, but a thick, greasy drool pouring from the heavens."
—Urza, journal
Here, rain does not wash the land; it desiccates it.
Hunger is a kind of madness—and here, all madness flourishes.
The viashino believe that the oldest mountains hate everyone equally.
There are places so horrible that even the dead hide their faces.

"That they are saved from death is immaterial. What is important is that they know the source of their benefaction."
—Radiant, archangel

"Here's how ya win. Don't let the other guy hit back first."
—Jula, goblin raider
Everything will find its use in Phyrexia. Eventually.
A foul, metallic stench clogged Urza's senses. It was then he knew his brother was no more.
"If one harm us, strike them in return. So sayeth the bey."

"Time flows like a river. In Tolaria we practice the art of building dams."
—Barrin, master wizard
Serra told them to guard Urza as he healed. Five years they stood.
"Protect our mother in her womb."
You are not prey until a predator knows of your existence.
Treacherous and unpredictable currents around Tolaria earned the nickname "serpent wakes."

"Father of Machines! Your filigree gaze carves us, and the scars dance upon our grateful flesh."
—Phyrexian Scriptures

"Shiv may be surrounded by water, but the mountains go far deeper."
—Fire Eye, viashino bey
Late at night, ululations echo from deep under Shiv, as the wurms sing of times older than humanity.
There are only two rules of tactics: never be without a plan, and never rely on it.

"The humans are useful in their way, but they must be commanded as the builder commands the stone. Be soft with them, and they will become soft."
—Radiant, archangel

"Lifted beyond herself, for that battle Brindri was an angel of light and fury."
—Song of All, canto 524
A fragile cocoon of dreaming will.
"Wear the foe's form to best it in battle. So sayeth the bey."
Both forge and pyre.
A dragon's scale can be carved into a mighty shield, provided you can procure a dragontooth to cut it.
At the academy, "show and tell" too often becomes "run and hide."
The viashino had learned how to operate the rig through trial and error—mostly error.
Urza dared to attack Phyrexia. Slowly, it retaliated.
"The answer to life should never be death; it should always be more life, wrapped tight around us like precious silks."
The first Yawgmoth priest to harness their power was rewarded with several unique mutilations.
The imps' warbling cries echo through Phyrexia's towers like those of mourning doves in a cathedral.
"Nothin' beat surprise—'cept rock."
The true names of birds are songs woven into their souls.
Does the stone mimic life, or did it once live?
Its spines are prized as writing quills by the priests of Gix.
The viashino knew of the cracked pipes but deliberately left them unmended to bolster the rig's defenses.

"I preferred the harsh tutors—they made mischief all the more fun."
—Teferi, third-level student
After a hundred failed experiments, Urza was stunned to find that common silver passed through the portal undamaged. He immediately designed a golem made of the metal.
It was the dragons who first learned to chase their prey into the vapors before igniting them.
The flow of time was disrupted; like a flooding river it rose from its banks. Tolaria was drowned in an instant that stretched toward infinity.
Although the elves of Argoth always considered them a nuisance, the pixies made fine allies during the war against the machines.
Gix despised the sylvan morass. The gouge that the portal had torn in the forest was the only pleasing sight.

"The most disappointing thing about learning telepathy is finding out how boring people really are."
—Teferi, fourth-level student
When Urza asked the viashino what it did, they answered: "It hums."
The giant was felt a few seconds before he was seen.
When the winds rock the trees, listen for voices in the creaking of the trunks. If you hear your name, you are one of the Goddess's chosen.

"What do a hero and an arrow have in common? In times of war are many more made."
—Elvish riddle
The academy worked with time—until time ran out.
Afterward, Tolaria's winds were like the whispers of lost wizards, calling for life.
The year that the brothers landed on Argoth, the trees produced five times as many seeds as normal.

"If you can't catch them, cut the trees down from beneath them. Force them to fight on our terms."
—Mishra
The best cure for a big ego is a little failure.
It was the explorers' only tether to reality.

"If fear is the only tool you have left, then you'll never control me."
—Xantcha, to Gix

"Great Yawgmoth moves across the seas of shard and bone and rust. We exalt him in life, in death, and in between."
—Phyrexian Scriptures

"Tawnos's blueprints were critical to the creation of my armor. As he once sealed himself in steel, I sealed myself in a walking crypt."
—Urza
When wind marries sky, even the bride's veil sings her praises.
Some roads are paved with bad intentions.
All the pain of the shattered forest contained in a single drop.
Many cultures have legends of a lush, hidden paradise. The elves of Argoth had no need of such stories.
"Give thy ration to thy mount, if the road be long. So sayeth the bey."

"It moved this way, an' that way, an' then before I could stick it, it jumped over my head an' was gone."
—Jula, goblin raider
Few swim in a place of such thirst.
Within the rig settlement, those who have mastered the making of weapons earn highest honor.
The priest cast Xantcha to the ground. "It is defective. We must scrap it."

"Opposite Law is Grace, and Grace must be preserved. If the strands of Grace are unraveled, its design will be lost, and the people with it."
—Song of All, canto 167

"Life's balance is as a star: on one point is Law, and Law must be upheld. If the knots of order are loosened, chaos will spill through."
—Song of All, canto 167
The key did not work on a single lock, yet it opened many doors.
Urza saw the wall and realized that even if he tore every Phyrexian to pieces, they would still resist him.
"You reek of corruption," spat the knight. "Why are you even here?"

"Their weak laws. Their flawed systems. They inhibit the Grand Evolution. In Yawgmoth's name, we shall erase them."
—Oath of the West

To hone swords and dull minds.
—Whetstone inscription
Urza tried to rule the air, but Gaea taught him that she controlled all the elements.

"Shiv hatched from a shell of stone around a yolk of flame."
—Viashino myth

"To fill your mind with knowledge, we must start by emptying it."
—Barrin, master wizard
Entire trees were stripped of their bark and branches by the wurm's writhing path.
Its purr is the sound of iron filings sliding down satin.
Although some of the students quickly grasped the concept, the others could summon only blackboards.

"Believe in the ideal, not the idol."
—Serra

"Phyrexia's purity permits no other."
—Xantcha, Phyrexian outcast
Once you've seen one, you'll understand why spells won't go near them.
Spells will shun you, as will everyone else.

"Sacrilege! A noble ally in life, made nothing more than a glorified kite in death!"
—Arna Kennerüd, skycaptain
These spirits of the air are winsome and wild and cannot be truly contained. Only marginally intelligent, they often substitute whimsy for strategy, delighting in mischief and mayhem.
Al-abara simply laughed and lifted one finger, and the carpet carried her high out of our reach.
Muskets gave the Alaborn army an advantage it had long lacked—air defense.

"I dedicate my body to my country
And my life to my King."
—Alaborn Soldier's Oath
No earthly armor is protection against this sweetness.

Among the first allies Urza gained were the people of Kroog. As a sign of friendship, Urza gave the healers of the city potent amulets; afterwards, thousands journeyed to Kroog in hope of healing, greatly adding to the city's glory.
Through years of study and training, the Blacksmiths of Argive became adept at reassembling the mangled remains of the strange, mechanical creatures abounding in their native land.

"‘O miserable of happy! Is this the end
Of this new glorious world . . . ?'"
—John Milton, Paradise Lost
The first line of defense against Urza and Mishra, the Artifact Blast achieved widespread fame until an unlucky mage discovered it was useless on the devices the brothers had already created.

Busy as a bumblebee, blistered as a goblin.
—Alaborn saying

"Four things that never meet do here unite To shed my blood and to ravage my heart, A radiant brow and tresses that beguile And rosy cheeks and a glittering smile."
—The Arabian Nights, trans. Haddawy
Battle doesn't need a purpose; the battle is its own purpose. You don't ask why a plague spreads or a field burns. Don't ask why I fight.
Tawnos learned quickly from Urza that utter simplicity often led to wondrous, yet subtle utility.

"So great is its power, only the chosen can wield it and live."
—Avram Garrisson, Leader of the Knights of Stromgald
The flash of his lance projects the pure radiance of his honor.
Tawnos won fame as Urza's greatest assistant. After he created these warriors, Urza ended his apprenticeship, promoting him directly to the rank of master.

"Until I came to the Floating Isle, I never had to oil the servants."
—Baki, wizard attendant
Buried under a thin layer of dirt, it was known for centuries as Mount Sardia.
The tiniest cough can be deadlier than the fiercest dragon.
Created to destroy Dominiaria, demons can sometimes be bent to a more focused purpose.
There is much talk about the art of creation. What about the art of destruction?

"The bolts of our ballistae smashed into the monstrous thing, but our hopes died in our chests as its gears continued turning."
—Sevti Mukul, The Fall of Alsoor
Those who believed the city of Kroog would never fall to Mishra's forces severely underestimated the might of his war machines.
We asked Captain Soll what became of the Serafina, but all he said was, "Ships that go down shouldn't come back up."

"All this nonsense made by mages Rusts and crumbles through the ages."
—Aline Corralurn, "Inheritance"

"That Rhino would fetch us a tidy sum, Joven. Perhaps it's time to make it ours."
—Chandler
"Hear that? No? That's a cat warrior."
Viscerid dams may be of living creatures as well as bones and mud.

"The warm rain of grease on my face immediately made it clear I had entered Phyrexia."
—Jarsyl, Diary
It's easy to stand head and shoulders over those with no backbone.
They get along so well with their goats because they're practically goats themselves.
Lead, follow, or run like crazy.

"Goblins bred underground, their numbers hidden from the enemy until it was too late."
—Sarpadian Empires, vol. IV
For years scholars debated whether these were Urza's or Mishra's creations. Recent research suggests they were invented by the brothers' original master, Tocasia, and that both used these devices.
"A blast, an echo . . . then silence."
The good news is it's vegetarian. The bad news is it just doesn't like you.
We had taken refuge in a small cave, thinking the entrance was too narrow for it to follow. To our horror, its gigantic head smashed into the mountainside, ripping itself a new entrance.

"Make people wait for what they want, and you have power over them. This is as true for merchants and militia as it is for cooks and couples."
—Gwendlyn Di Corci

"Where our potions and powders fail, perhaps nature will succeed."
—Reyhan, Samite Alchemist

Some fiendish mage had created a horrifying wall of living flesh, patched together from a jumble of still-recognizable body parts. As we sought to hew our way through it, some unknown power healed the gaping wounds we cut, denying us passage.
Of royal blood amongst the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti Djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.

"It is only fitting that one such as I should die in pursuit of knowledge."
—Vervamon the Elder
While exploring the sacred cave of Koilos with his brother Mishra and their master Tocasia, Urza fell behind in the Hall of Tagsin, where he discovered the remarkable Mightstone.

"A minion given over to Tevesh Szat is a stronger minion gained."
—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer
Though he eventually came to despise Tocasia, Mishra listened well to her lessons on clarity of purpose. Unlike his brother, he focused his mind on a single goal.

"Curse Reveka, and curse her coddled conjurers. Their sorcerers' school shall yet be ours."
—Irini Sengir
The Battle of Tomakul taught Urza not to rely on fickle reinforcements.

"The foot stone is connected to the ankle stone, the ankle stone is connected to the leg stone . . ."
—"Song of the Artificer"
Three little goblins, enjoying their brew. One bumped an ogre, and then there were two.
An early inspiration for Urza, Tocasia's Onulets contained magical essences that could be cannibalized after they stopped functioning.
"Take this item, for instance. How would it destroy us, Relicbane?" —Arcum Dagsson, Soldevi Machinist
These beings embody the essence of true heroes long dead. Summoned from the dreamrealms, they rise to meet their enemies.
Nireya reached through the Gate, sensing the energies trapped beyond.
Occasionally a member of the Institute of Arcane Study acquires a taste for worldly pleasures. Seldom do they have trouble finding employment.
Silent as a serpent, twisted as a lone bog tree, evil as Tojira's heart.
Knives in the sky, cries in the air, and blood on the ground.
Urza was the first to understand that the war would not be lost for lack of power, but for lack of troops.
Tedious research made the Sages of the College of Lat-Nam adept in repairing broken artifacts.
Bravery shines brightest in a pure soul.
To the uninitiated, the Ring of Renewal is merely an oddity. For those fluent in the wielding of magic, however, it is a source of great knowledge.
Even the landscape turned against Sarsour, first rising up and pelting him, then rearranging itself so he could no longer find his way.

The traditional kings of the jungle command a healthy respect in other climates as well. Relying mainly on their stealth and speed, Savannah Lions can take a victim by surprise, even in the endless flat plains of their homeland.
There was more malice in its button eyes than should have been possible in something that had never known life.
Legend has it that Serpents used to be bigger, but how could that be?

The stench in the hovel was overpowering; something loathsome was cooking. Occasionally something surfaced in the thick paste, but my host would casually push it down before I could make out what it was.
Born with wings of light and a sword of faith, this heavenly incarnation embodies both fury and purity.

"Serra, like Feroz, is long since dead. But remember, Daria: her spirit shall survive so long as the Homelands do."
—Taysir

While it's true most Dragons are cruel, the Shivan Dragon seems to take particular glee in the misery of others, often tormenting its victims much like a cat plays with a mouse before delivering the final blow.
Slow and steady wins the race.
While defending their southern borders, both the Wu and Shu kingdoms fought against the barbarians' trained elephants.
When the cat flies and the bird stalks, guard your horses carefully.

"To-night the winds begin to rise . . .
The rooks are blown about the skies . . . ."
—Alfred, Lord Tennyson, In Memoriam
Though Mishra was impressed by the staves Ashnod had created for Zegon's defense, he understood they only hinted at her full potential.
"You idiots! Turn it around! Turn it around!"
Unlike previous conflicts, the war between Urza and Mishra made Dominia itself a casualty of war.
". . . inviting the soul to wander for a spell in abysses of solitude . . . ." —Kate Chopin, The Awakening
Originally considered the work of Urza, this tablet was created by forgers seeking to imitate Urza's masterpieces.

From time, knowledge.
From knowledge, power.
When Urza's war machines became too costly, Tawnos's weaponry replaced them.
Young, yes. Inexperienced, yes. Weak? Don't count on it.
Energy is never lost, only transformed.
Seafarers fear sailing off the world's edge not so much as down its gullet.
When sorely wounded or tired, Urza would often retreat to the workshops of his apprentices. They were greatly amazed at how much better he looked each time he took a sip of water.
Mines became common as cities during the days of the artificers.
Mines became common as cities during the days of the artificers.
Mines became common as cities during the days of the artificers.
Mines became common as cities during the days of the artificers.
Artifact construction requires immense resources.
Artifact construction requires immense resources.
Artifact construction requires immense resources.
Artifact construction requires immense resources.
Urza always put Tocasia's lessons on resource-gathering to effective use.
Urza always put Tocasia's lessons on resource-gathering to effective use.
Urza always put Tocasia's lessons on resource-gathering to effective use.
Urza always put Tocasia's lessons on resource-gathering to effective use.
Good bodyguards are hard to find, mainly because they don't live long.

"Unearthly and invisible fibers emanate from this sphere, entangling all who draw near."
—Arcum Dagsson, Soldevi Machinist

Unpredictable as the sea itself, water elementals shift without warning from tranquility to tempest. Capricious and fickle, they flow restlessly from one shape to another, expressing their moods with their physical forms.
During the brothers' childhood, Tocasia took them to explore the sacred cave of Koilos. There, in the Hall of Tagsin, Mishra discovered the mysterious weakstone.
It's hard to say for certain which end is more dangerous.
Out of the blackness and stench of the engulfing swamp emerged a shimmering figure. Only the splattered armor and ichor-stained sword hinted at the unfathomable evil the knight had just laid waste.

"High in the Karplusans, death is swift and razor-clawed."
—Arna Kennerüd, skycaptain
Two little goblins, out in the sun. Down came a griffin, and then there was one.
It has the run of the swamps, and it knows it.

After Kroog was destroyed while most of its defenders were at his side, Urza vowed that none of his allies would ever need to fear for their own defense again, even while laying siege to a city far from their homes.
They say the Zombie Master controlled these foul creatures even before his own death, but now that he is one of them, nothing can make them betray him.
Treefolk and elves share a common interest in the forests, but really the elves just feel at home with the view from above.
Only wool from the side of the springjack turned most often to the sun can be woven into kithkin battle standards. Jackherds record every movement of their woolly-jacks until shearing.
"I do not heal. Healing means that the pain has already been felt. To stop suffering, one must prevent the world's wounds altogether."
In Lorwyn's brief evenings, the sun pauses at the horizon long enough for a certain species of violet to bloom with the fragrance of mischief.
"See the beauty in death: the clean white bones lying in the fertile soil and the brightly colored moonglove sprouting from the fell earth."
Even if giants bring nothing else on a journey, they bring attention.
"Now everyone knows what you are."
Giants share nothing but their fury.
Deep in a murmuring bosk, where the trees' memories span centuries, the simple banner of green and copper signifies an elder whose rings number more than a faerie's days.
Those who seek to escape her blades succeed only in dying on their stomachs.
The banner symbolizes the goodwill of the Brighthearth. Their emissaries bring the mastery of fire to other races.
The flasks provide ballast, a means of steering, and—with a little luck—a way to deliver ward-spells to cohorts below.
Soul and bones, kithkin are woven into their clans. They fight fiercely and without self-interest.
The choke point was the plan, but devoted camaraderie was always her strategy.
