—Ghut Rak, Gruul guildmage

"The sky isn't falling—it's being thrown at us!"
—Otak, Tin Street shopkeep
Though the old holy wards and roadside shrines have begun to fail, faith in Avacyn still holds true power.
He has nothing left but his resentment.
The tips of her bolts are blunt, but her aim is deadly sharp.
A blazing sun that never sets.
Elmut had slaughtered vampires, slain werewolves, and destroyed hordes of zombies. Sadly, he never got over his fear of spiders.
"Once more into Devil's Breach, soldiers. I want another devil tail for my collection."
It's no coincidence that the oldest trolls are also the angriest.

"There shall be a vast shout and then a vaster silence."
—Oracle en-Vec
"Only the decadent think magic should be pristine and without cost."

"No rest. No mercy. No matter what."
—Memorial inscription
Nobles don wings to reach the sky villas of their peers, exchanging them for more fashionable attire upon arrival.
"If it would end this exile, my life is yours."
Within each empty skull, it seeks ways to preserve its own failing undeath.
"I have seen the future. It does not include you."

"The only perfect world is an empty world, with no one to sin or wage war."
—Tarran, magus of the disk
"Hrrngh! Someday I'm going to hurl this . . . er . . . roll this . . . hrrngh . . . nudge this boulder right down a cliff."
A well-made homunculus grooms the mind of its master, pruning the thoughts that lead to madness. Few loredelvers survive the study of the infinite without one.
A fight put off forever is already won.
The wisdom of the omenreaders is legendary. Creatures travel for miles through icy peril to seek their counsel.
Elementals flourished as Dominaria healed and new forms of life adapted to the land's reinfusion with mana.
The musical sound of its turning triggers the tumblers of revelation.
Her blades slashed across the noble's shadow. He scoffed, then fell over dead.

"Touch no tree, break no branch, and speak only the question you wish answered."
—Von Yomm, elder druid, to her initiates
"At harvest are seeds of next year sown."
Legends say a djinn gave the goblins a gift they could never hope to master.

"It takes but one spark to ignite a parched forest. Our hearts, I fear, are too dry for this new visitor."
—Elek Longbeard

"They who fall singing the battle hymn of Benalia go not unavenged."
—Adom Capashen, Benalish commander

"The seventh symbol, the Mark of Stone, stores the power of ancient Rath."
—Tome of Elemental Mastery

"Life cannot be created and then abandoned. It must be nurtured and fed so that it may express its ripened might."
—Freyalise
Wind time's watch, and watch time unwind.
The Arturan conjurers took the strange, alien fossil and patterned their own twisted creations in its image.
Only those gifted with the eye of Ugin, the spirit dragon, can see his fiery breath.
The blessing adds both protection to the recipient and weightlessness to the stone.
She wished for gold, but not for the strength to carry it.

"Sometimes the grave does not wait for death before relishing its feast of flesh and bones."
—Ezrith, druid of the Dark Hours
Shamans of Kar-Sengir claim that their sun sets because it can no longer bear the gaze of those pain-carved cliffs.

"Take care what you offer the ignus. Food, perhaps. Coins. But nothing flammable!"
—Stovic, village eccentric
Spring is the most beautiful season in the grove, when the new leaves open from their ember-buds in a race of leaping flames.
His roots reach deep, nurtured not by soil and rain, but by millennia of experience.
The great leaves are resilient underfoot. Heavy steps do not bruise them, but release a sweet and spicy scent.

"An ancient, powerful force has overtaken the valley. I sympathize for its former inhabitants, but I rejoice for the land itself."
—Olanti, Muraganda druid
"I am irrelevant. The future I hold in my hands is everything."

"Your thoughts do not interest me nearly as much as the absence thereof."
—Gorghul, augur of skulls
It is a herald of the sun goddess, projected from the hallowed glass whenever her light passes through.
Having conquered the Bastion of Suns, the Ota took its light for their own.
Its skin remains in a flowing, liquid state that keeps its body coated with potent restorative lymph.
He climbs a staircase of falling souls, fighting the continuous pull of the void.
Those gifted with the sight have one eye in the present and the other in the future.
"The spirits of the mythic ones ever circle their beloved keep, forbidding entry to all who come with the heavy tread of hate."
Tidal forces of the blood moon wrench and buckle the land, drawing monoliths of stone and soil toward the flaming orb.
Battered and beaten by years of salt and claw, he never ceased to walk, and to seed. Only now, in this time of rebirth, do his seeds take root.

"They are quick to offer advice, those whose mistakes doomed them to undeath. How can I not listen to the wisdom of failure?"
—Ratadrabik of Urborg
Doyo suspected the boggarts of brewing a plot against his crop, so he scythed away his grain to clear the sightlines.
Some mages forsake their scrolls and libraries to learn at the feet of ancient trees and sacred stones.
It was created by the Iquati as a living memory—one that objects to being forgotten.
To find its center is to find one's own.

"There is no shortcut to work done true and well. The Creators learned this to their sorrow, the first time they made the world."
—Githri the Prisoner
Those who expect betrayal at every turn are seldom disappointed.
Lady Farisa's contempt of tawdry kitsch grew even more infamous after her death.

"Mushroom Queen sits among her spores,
Enjoying life and avoiding chores."
—Ibblian pixie ditty
The land can only hold so much poison before it begins to bite back.

"Artifice has always stood upon nature's shoulders. Let us watch nature take a turn."
—Freyalise
The Ramosian tradition is alive, but its namesake has long since been forgotten.

"It's difficult to heal a rift after it begins wandering about on its own."
—Teferi
"Beings of the rifts are not natural. No longer will these abominations tread upon the body of Gaea."
"Dance, and bring forth the coil! It is an umbilical to Gaea herself, fattening us with the earth's rich bounty."

"The Westfolk wept, and their tears wore winding rivers into the cheek of the world."
—Glem the Lonebard, "Origins of Kholon"
Samite alchemists extracted aromatic traces of healing minerals from the residue of the receding salt dunes.

"A horrible sight, yes, but the sounds . . . Its twanging tendons and grinding gears are almost musical."
—Brudiclad, Telchor engineer
Doom casts its own flickering shadow.
"There is no tactic I enjoy more than ambushing the ambushers."
Vindr stormchasers believe that the same ancient forces that move the winds can also move mortal minds and hearts.
Death is only the beginning of the end.
Hidden within the clicking, chittering swarm is a unique mind, still young, but growing more aware as time passes.
After centuries of labor, its creations outnumber those they were to mimic.

"You'd think that their big glowing eyes would be almost hypnotic to look at. In fact, it's the other way around—they are entranced by nearly everything they see."
—Balecki, Spellwild druid

"Whip the Xs ! Pinch the Os!
What we're building, no one knows!"
Dweldian magi don't enter the Realm of Thrones when they die. Instead their souls are drawn to great works of magic.
The lamps on Wyndmoor Street snuff themselves at midnight and refuse to relight, afraid to illuminate what lies in the darkness.
In the stronghold's dungeons, the shadows hide in the vermin.
Despising his siblings as insults to his line, he finds and devours each in turn.
Their arrows are tipped with basilisk eyes and fletched with cockatrice feathers.
Sometimes it's ostentatious to go unseen.
"Each reality is but the dream of another, and each sleeper a god unknowing."
His marvels of artifice pale in comparison to the developing machinery of his mind.

"I swear the clouds were created just so the drakes would have a place to lurk."
—Kasharri, skyknight

"Hear us, Overmother. Let the strong thrive under your gelatinous hand, and let the weak writhe under your serrated heel."
—Prayer of the devoted
Some nature mages unknowingly took advantage of the temporal energies still swirling on Dominaria. What they mistook for healing magic was in fact the manipulation of time.
"I have an eternity to know the souls who are bound here, to behold their every facet. But moments from now they will be gagged and masked, and they shall be known by none other."
Nothing lives within it, yet there is life.
Born with wings of light and a sword of faith, this heavenly incarnation embodies both fury and purity.
These spirits of the air are winsome and wild and cannot be truly contained. Only marginally intelligent, they often substitute whimsy for strategy, delighting in mischief and mayhem.
Benalia has a complex caste system that changes with the lunar year. No matter what the season, the only caste that cannot be attained by either heredity or money is that of the hero.
Battle doesn't need a purpose; the battle is its own purpose. You don't ask why a plague spreads or a field burns. Don't ask why I fight.

'Twas in the bogs of Cannelbrae
My mate did meet an early grave
'Twas nothing left for us to save
In the peat-filled bogs of Cannelbrae.

The most terrifying thing about the Craw Wurm is probably the horrible crashing sound it makes as it speeds through the forest. This noise is so loud it echoes through the trees and seems to come from all directions at once.
Created to destroy Dominia, Demons can sometimes be bent to a more focused purpose.

"O to be a dragon . . . of silkworm size or immense . . ."
—Marianne Moore, "O to Be a Dragon"
Bones scattered around us joined to form misshapen bodies. We struck at them repeatedly—they fell, but soon formed again, with the same mocking look on their faceless skulls.
Foolishly, Najib retreated to his castle at El-Abar; the next morning he was dead. In just one night, the dwarven forces had reduced the mighty walls to mere rubble.

Earth Elementals have the eternal strength of stone and the endurance of mountains. Primordially connected to the land they inhabit, they take a long-term view of things, scorning the impetuous haste of short-lived mortal creatures.
I tell you, there was so many arrows flying about you couldn't hardly see the sun. So I says to young Angus, "Well, at least now we're fighting in the shade!"

Fire Elementals are ruthless infernos, annihilating and consuming their foes in a frenzied holocaust. Crackling and blazing, they sear swift, terrible paths, leaving the land charred and scorched in their wake.

"And topples round the dreary west
A looming bastion fringed with fire."
—Alfred, Lord Tennyson, "In Memoriam"

"There are some qualities—some incorporate things,/ That have a double life, which thus is made/ A type of twin entity which springs/ From matter and light, evinced in solid and shade."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "Silence"
Rather than sheltering her young, the female Fungusaur often injures her own offspring, thereby ensuring their rapid growth.
While it possesses potent venom, the Giant Spider often chooses not to paralyze its victims. Perhaps the creature enjoys the gentle rocking motion caused by its captives' struggles to escape its web.
"From up here we can drop rocks and arrows and more rocks!" "Uh, yeah boss, but how do we get down?"
To become king of the Goblins, one must assassinate the previous king. Thus, only the most foolish seek positions of leadership.

"While most overworlders fortunately don't realize this, Gargoyles can be most delicious, providing you have the appropriate tools to carve them."
—The Underworld Cookbook by Asmoranomardicadaistinaculdacar

The Ogre philosopher Gnerdel believed the purpose of life was to live as high on the food chain as possible. She refused to eat vegetarians, and preferred to live entirely on creatures that preyed on sentient beings.

Don't try to outrun one of Dominia's Grizzlies; it'll catch you, knock you down, and eat you. Of course, you could run up a tree. In that case you'll get a nice view before it knocks the tree down and eats you.
Fortunately, Hill Giants have large blind spots in which a human can easily hide. Unfortunately, these blind spots are beneath the bottoms of their feet.

The Minotaurs of the Hurloon Mountains are known for their love of battle. They are also known for their hymns to the dead, sung for friend and foe alike. These hymns can last for days, filling the mountain valleys with their low, haunting sounds.

"...There was no trace/ Of aught on that illumined face..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Phantom"
Generations of genetic weeding have given rise to the deviously cowardly Ironclaw clan. To say that Orcs in general are vicious, depraved, and ignoble does not do justice to the Ironclaw.

The mating habits of Treefolk, particularly the stalwart Ironroot Treefolk, are truly absurd. Molasses comes to mind. It's amazing the species can survive at all given such protracted periods of mate selection, conjugation, and gestation.

"Some of the other guys dared me to touch it, but I knew it weren't no ordinary hunk o' rock."
—Norin the Wary
We had taken refuge in a small cave, thinking the entrance was too narrow for it to follow. To our horror, its gigantic head smashed into the mountainside, ripping itself a new entrance.
After years of training, the Druid becomes one with nature, drawing power from the land and returning it when needed.

Some fiendish mage had created a horrifying wall of living flesh, patched together from a jumble of still-recognizable body parts. As we sought to hew our way through it, some unknown power healed the gaping wounds we cut, denying us passage.
Whenever the Llanowar Elves gather the fruits of their forest, they leave one plant of each type untouched, considering that nature's portion.
A master of tactics, the Lord of Atlantis makes his people bold in battle merely by arriving to lead them.
Of royal blood among the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti Djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.

Most human scholars believe that Merfolk are the survivors of sunken Atlantis, humans adapted to the water. Merfolk, however, believe that humans sprang forth from Merfolk who adapted themselves in order to explore their last frontier.

Before a woman marries in the village of Sursi, she must visit the land of the Mesa Pegasus. Legend has it that if the woman is pure of heart and her love is true, a Mesa Pegasus will appear, blessing her family with long life and good fortune.

The intricate dynamics of Rundvelt Goblin affairs are often confused with anarchy. The chaos, however, is the chaos of a thundercloud, and direction will sporadically and violently appear. Pashalik Mons and his raiders are the thunderhead that leads in the storm.
The Nightmare arises from its lair in the swamps. As the poisoned land spreads, so does the Nightmare's rage and terrifying strength.

"Look to the north; there you will find aid and comfort."
—The Book of Tal

"The foot stone is connected to the ankle stone, the ankle stone is connected to the leg stone . . ."
—Song of the Artificer
In a rare display of ingenuity, the Orcs invented an incredibly destructive weapon. Most Orcish artillerists are those who dared criticize its effectiveness.

"‘Do you know, I always thought Unicorns were fabulous monsters, too? I never saw one alive before!' ‘Well, now that we have seen each other,' said the Unicorn, ‘if you'll believe in me, I'll believe in you.'"
—Lewis Carroll
These beings embody the essence of true heroes long dead. Summoned from the dreamrealms, they rise to meet their enemies.

"While, like a ghastly rapid river,
Through the pale door,
A hideous throng rush out forever,
And laugh—but smile no more."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "The Haunted Palace"

"Should you a Rat to madness tease
Why ev'n a Rat may plague you..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Recantation"
Occasionally a member of the Institute of Arcane Study acquires a taste for worldly pleasures. Seldom do they have trouble finding employment.

We encountered a valley topped with immense boulders and eerie rock formations. Suddenly one of these boulders toppled from its perch and sprouted gargantuan wings, casting a shadow of darkness and sending us fleeing in terror.
Trained in the arts of stealth, the royal assassins choose their victims carefully, relying on timing and precision rather than brute force.
Healers ultimately acquire the divine gifts of spiritual and physical wholeness. The most devout are also granted the ability to pass physical wholeness on to others.

The traditional kings of the jungle command a healthy respect in other climates as well. Relying mainly on their stealth and speed, Savannah Lions can take a victim by surprise, even in the endless flat plains of their homeland.

"They groaned, they stirred, they all uprose,/ Nor spake, nor moved their eyes;/ It had been strange, even in a dream,/
To have seen those dead men rise."/
—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"
The only sound was the gentle clicking of the Faeries' wings. Then those intruders who were still standing turned and fled. One thing was certain: they didn't think the Scryb were very funny anymore.
Legend has it that Serpents used to be bigger, but how could that be?

The stench in the hovel was overpowering; something loathsome was cooking. Occasionally something surfaced in the thick paste, but my host would casually push it down before I could make out what it was.
Born with wings of light and a sword of faith, this heavenly incarnation embodies both fury and purity.
Moving without sound, swift figures pass through branches and undergrowth completely unhindered. One with the trees around them, the Dryads of Shanodin Forest are seen only when they wish to be.

While it's true most Dragons are cruel, the Shivan Dragon seems to take particular glee in the misery of others, often tormenting its victims much like a cat plays with a mouse before delivering the final blow.
What goes up, must come down.
Moss-covered statues littered the area, a macabre monument to the Basilisk's power.
Though many think of Wolves as solitary predators, they are actually extremely social animals. During a hunt they often call to each other, which can be quite unsettling for their prey.
None know if this Giant is the result of aberrant magics, Siamese twins, or a mentalist's schizophrenia.

"Oi oi oi, me gotta hurt in 'ere
Oi oi oi, me smell a ting is near,
Gonna bosh 'n gonna nosh 'n da
hurt'll disappear."
—Traditional
Some say magic was first practiced by women, who have always felt strong ties to the land.
Good bodyguards are hard to find, mainly because they don't live long.
"This 'standing windstorm' can hold us off indefinitely? Ridiculous!" Saying nothing, she put a pinch of salt on the table. With a bang she clapped her hands, and the salt disappeared, blown away.
The Wall of Bone is said to be an aspect of the Great Wall in Hel, where the bones of all sinners wait for Ragnarok, when Hela will call them forth for the final battle.

"What else, when chaos draws all forces inward to shape a single leaf."
—Conrad Aiken
Conjured from the bowels of hell, the fiery wall forms an impassable barrier, searing the soul of any creature attempting to pass through its terrible bursts of flame.

"And through the drifts the snowy cliffs/ Did send a dismal sheen:/ Nor shapes of men nor beasts we ken—/ The ice was all between."/
—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"

The Earth herself lends her strength to these walls of living stone, which possess the stability of ancient mountains. These mighty bulwarks thwart ground-based troops, providing welcome relief for weary warriors who defend the land.

Just as the evil ones approached to slay Justina, she cast a great spell, imbuing her weapons with her own life force. Thus she fulfilled the prophecy: "In the death of your savior will you find salvation."
A deafening roar arose as the fury of an enormous vertical river supplanted our serenity. Eddies turned into whirling geysers, leveling everything in their path.
Everybody knows that to ward off trouble, you knock on wood. But usually it's better to make a wall out of the wood and let trouble do the knocking.
I didn't think Mammoths could ever hold a candle to a well-trained battle horse. Then one day I turned my back on a drunken soldier. His blow never landed; Mi'cha flung the brute over ten meters.

Unpredictable as the sea itself, Water Elementals shift without warning from tranquility to tempest. Capricious and fickle, they flow restlessly from one shape to another, expressing their moods with their physical forms.
Out of the blackness and stench of the engulfing swamp emerged a shimmering figure. Only the splattered armor and ichor-stained sword hinted at the unfathomable evil the knight had just laid waste.

"About, about in reel and rout
The death-fires danced at night;
The water, like a witch's oils,
Burnt green, and blue and white."
—Samuel Coleridge, "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner"
They say the Zombie Master controlled these foul creatures even before his own death, but now that he is one of them, nothing can make them betray him.

"Show them to Razia and then to the Azorius sky marshals. We could create a fine bidding war—enough to fund the final stages of Project Kraj."
—Momir Vig
Such is the power of Rakdos that even his shadow takes on a cruel life of its own.
In her single metasphere are bound the records of every Ætheric transaction since the time of Azor.
With a steady diet of lawbreakers, Azorius griffins inevitably develop a resistance to the contraband magic that taints much of their prey.

"As peace should be—gentle yet unstoppable."
—Augustin IV
Azorius military tactics, like their legal tactics, capitalize on delay and nullification.
The maze-like design embodies the core of Azorius law—strict structure designed to test wills and stall change.

"Look beyond, to the vascular awareness that all life is a map to greater knowledge."
—Momir Vig, Biomancy, vol. I
"Before the first stone was laid or the first elf-child born, the power of the nephilim was gathering. Let that power be spread by my hands."
The Rakdos are unique in designing torture equipment they can operate while "suffering" alongside their victims.
Flesh can be tempered by spellcraft and forged ever stronger by the hammers of foes.
To the Rakdos, the fun is in the shakedown. The loot is usually discarded.

"Ooh, shiny! Let's pull off the chain and take her with us."
—Ukl, Gruul raider, last words

"I like a little entertainment with my dinner."
—Rakdos
Her enemy's strength is her own.

"We thought the clouds had moved from the night sky. Then the night sky moved, and the horizon grew wings."
—Josuri
Snaking remnants of nature directed by a body of thought and progress, the oracles embody all that is Simic.

"No doubt the arbiters would put you away, after all the documents are signed. But I will have justice now!"
—Alovnek, Boros guildmage

"Though highly effective at reshaping flesh, these specially bred cytoplasts leave the subject reeking of omnibian mucus."
—Simic research notes
There came a rush, a sudden fire in the mind. Then the two saw only the sooty fog of madness, heard only the crackling of their last thoughts burning away.
They knock 'em dead, with or without the punch line.
A thousand phobias sopped from the city and wrung from Rix Maadi as one.
Like a vulture's scalp, the face of a drekavac is oily and hairless. The filth and disease of its carrion diet slip off its blood-slick skin.
Guilds often exterminate those who saw or knew too much. Some vindictive souls retain their knowledge, using it in the afterlife to crush the guilded and the vile bargain that gives them power.
The vats are self-contained worlds, bubbling and churning with unnatural speed, boiling down eons of change into moments.

"Of course it will grow beyond control—it was designed to choose its own evolution."
—Momir Vig

"The forward flame-kin are popping. We have incoming!"
—Svar, Boros signaler
A flame-kin is always formidable, but feeding its fire with a sorcerous gift grants it the power to devastate armies.

"This undemanding vegetation takes root in a mote of dust but grows incredibly quickly."
—Simic research notes
Confront her, and feel the hooves of her steed. Ignore her, and feel the sting of her arrow.
Where wasted life cries out to be reborn.
Despite its diminutive name, Gnat Alley is the longest street in Ravnica. Mile after twisting mile, it threads its way among the broader, safer thoroughfares like a parasite.
Lyzolda's pet rats eat better than the average citizen. In fact, they can usually be found eating the average citizen.
The Arbiter is a conduit of justice, a will so disciplined that it dispenses justice without ego or remorse.

The magic of the Guildpact gives aegis to the spirits pressed into its service. Upon entering the afterlife, they find new focus and are charged with defending the Guildpact against those who would see it broken.
"This aura threatens the sanctity of your soul. Wrenching it free won't be easy on either of us. If you're ready, we'll begin."
The Haazda shield is broad, protecting both the free and the guilded.

"I must speak with Momir Vig about creating a water-spouting watchdog."
—Mathvan, Prahv scrollwarden

"A quick step beyond oblivion lies a place so full of thoughts that it leaves no room for your own."
—Quyzl, chronarch prodigy

"An indrik's howl has destructive power much subtler than that of its crushing foot. The sound is mundane, but inaudible vibrations scatter and sunder magical contrivances."
—Simic research notes
Few puppets are so willing.
Dressed to kill.
"Start knockin' heads, boys, and don't stop 'til the ragamuffyn sings!"

"The best experiments are those whose successes replicate themselves."
—Yolov, Simic bioengineer
His work determines who is remembered and who feeds the worms.
Sacrificial rites take place before an audience of cheering cultists, each begging to be the next on stage.

"All dead move to the hollow rhythm of necromancy."
—Savra
The stones hark back to an age before civilization, when the living earth blessed all who trod its untamed wilds.

"Send a runner to Tin Street, and tell 'em the delivery has been . . . uh . . . held up."
—Bonmod, caravan rear guard
When it takes forever to learn all the rules, no time is left for breaking them.
Some sky steeds break from the thundering herd to ride free on the open winds.

"I call them ‘Poke' and ‘Prod.'"
—Chagrach, Rakdos cursemage

"Please tell me I'm hallucinating. I'd rather be crazy than here."
—Gorev Hadszak, Wojek investigator
"All ends in obliteration—love in hatred, life in death, and light in empty darkness."

"The unnatural pressures of life in this city are best withstood by lifeforms that adapt with unnatural swiftness."
—Momir Vig
While the soldier dreams, the eyes stand watch.
A popular game among ogres is to see how many revolutions a head can make before it pops off.

"This creature has hyperevolved chameleonic abilities. It no longer mimics its surroundings, instead forcing them to take on its form."
—Simic research notes
With one commanding word, the spell was put down and a fine collected for its casting.
The Rakdos make sure their victims remember their pain—or at least give up a little bit of their sanity in order to forget.
Built on the very ground where the Ten signed the Guildpact, the tower is a monument to the past and a reminder of who holds power in the present.
Prahv, where much work is done to make sure nothing is accomplished.
Properly honored dead gain the peace of the grave and freedom from the call of the Ghost Quarter.

"Meat and eggs. We eat!"
—Borborygmos
"You will do the thinking for the both of us!"

"Rage, my servants. Our ancient power is renewed in blood."
—Rakdos
They cut the stitches and give her sips of her brew. Then they sew her up again, and she's back to stirring.

"Stay indoors, away from what seeps over the thresholds. This is the Demon's work, and only ill can come of it."
—Belko, owner of Titan's Keg tavern
"Great minds bleed alike."

"Our thrulls dissolve from the inside out in a matter of days. Shoddy work, but they're a scream while they last."
—Uzric, Rakdos guildmage
Made of bone and boiled in blood, a Rakdos signet is not considered finished until it has been used as a murder weapon.
An ogre's poisonous stench is like fine Kashkaval cheese to the noses lowest to the ground.
Most auramancers would have let the spikes hover just above the skin. Having the spikes rip through the skin from beneath was a touch added by Rakdos himself.
Even miles away, if you put your ear to the sewer vents, you can hear the screams and the tempestuous laughter.

"A basilisk's gaze is effective, but disposing of physical remains is a tiresome task. It's far more discrete to dissolve one's victim entirely."
—Szadek

"If it breathes, it will burn."
—Rakdos pyromancers' creed
Simic initiates begin their training as experimental subjects. Failures are flushed to the undersewers.

"Infused with autochthon blood for size and hellion cells for speed, the ragworm is perfect for clearing the undergardens of both rats and vagrants."
—Yolov, Simic bioengineer

For the Simic Combine, its sigil serves not as an emblem of honor but as a trademark. Its familiar image on any biological commodity attests to superb craftsmanship, ingenious innovation, and higher cost.

"We've bred out the shortcomings of the species' natural form and replaced them with assets of our own design."
—Momir Vig
Once tasted, the flavor of skullmead lingers in the throat, a secret brand of guilt for those who partake in forbidden pleasures.
A Rakdos party is a flop if anyone lives to talk about it.
In death, as in life, they protect the Grand Arbiter from exposure to contrary points of view.
Every culture has its unlucky numbers. In a city where you're either alone, in a crowd, or being stabbed in the back, two is the worst number of all.
A hydra tender's problem isn't having enough defenses but enough pots.
Something roams the killing places, sniffing the guilt of the slayers, stalking them on iron paws.
"Life is fleeting, and so is death. Only the oath is eternal."

"Mizzium may be impervious to fire, but obviously certain other things can . . . modify its form."
—Ivos Koba, indrik handler
"It takes more than swift feet and dark shadows to slip by me unnoticed."

"This world may not know peace, but in my presence you will know quiet."
—Augustin IV
The taste of blood breaks down what little self-control the Rakdos possess.
The most successful of Simic creations is cytoplasm, a living, symbiotic substance that feeds off genetic rhythms and strengthens its host in return.
He unmakes the world in his own image.
Reluctant to meet face to face, the leaders of the ten guilds prefer to do official business through a go-between immune to bribes and threats.
Held aloft by metabolized magic, trygons are ravenous for sources of mystic fuel.
They're dying left and right.

"The victim bears the marks of the ‘Ktozok Impaler'. . . but he was executed years ago!"
—Gorev Hadszak, Wojek investigator
He wages war wherever the wind carries him.
"As my father taught, ‘Training will raise your shield to the blow, but courage fills the gaps the shield leaves open.'"

"Nature's exceptions remind us not to think in absolutes. Just as the orchid blossoms on blackened stone, so does the gift of mana occasionally manifest in the undead."
—Bougrat, druid of the Cult of Yore
Fruits of magic, roots in science.
"I could see in the other mage's eyes that he'd thought of it too. Then it became a race to exploit the knowledge first."

"It is technically an ooze, but its lifespan measures only seconds. In that short time, its appetite for magic is extraordinary."
—Simic research notes
Its pulsating cry shatters bonds of iron, granite, and servitude.
Razia, archangel of war, demands total commitment.

"Finally, a good use for an Azorius courthouse."
—Ghut Rak, Gruul guildmage

"It wags its tail when it's happy. It wags its tail when it's angry. Nope, there's no good time to be around a whiptail."
—Rugar, Leaguehall Infirmary patient

"Some images are so powerful that one glance burns them into your mind forever. Come, let us gaze on nothingness."
—Szadek
Rakdos festivals almost leave enough rubble in their wake to hide the bodies.
Lieutenant Kos has never met a group of recruits he could not inspire or a mob he could not quell.
The trainer awoke to begin the journey from the wurm's tail to its head. The sun was setting when she arrived.

"Riftcutters are suicidal anarchists, waving those lightning axes around so much that the walls are as likely to fall as their foes."
—Heruj, Selesnya initiate
"Truth shines even in darkness. Those who march on the side of truth walk always in righteous light."
Although the door is flimsy and the lock pathetically small, Josuri's family never fears the night outside.
Long ago, birds of paradise littered the skies. Thanks to the city's sprawl, most now exist as pets of society's elite.

"Through the haze of battle I saw the glint of sun on golden mane, the sheen of glory clad in mail, and I dropped my sword and wept at the idiocy of war."
—Dravin, Gruul deserter
Vendors hung cords heavy with roots and laid out boxes of salted meat, unaware of the fiery disaster swiftly approaching.
The Golgari support a vast army because death never ends its soldiers' service.

"Look at this goblin, once wild, untamed, and full of idiocy. The Boros have given him the skill of a soldier and focused his heart with a single cause."
—Razia

"Have you ever held a Boros signet? There's a weight to it that belies its size—a weight of strength and of pride."
—Agrus Kos
When the Boros Legion attacks, swiftblades enter the fray first. They pick off the archers and mages, softening the enemy front before the flame-kin and giants go in.
Ravnica is a seamless urban tapestry, each city bleeding into the next. In abandoned corners, however, nature has begun to reclaim what it once owned.

"Let the pyres of the unbelievers light our way."
—Razia
"The guilds each believe its way is right, but their ways only bring blood to Ravnica's streets and tears to Ravnica's families."
They chase tirelessly after the bone-carts that speed along the streets of the Plague Quarter.
So-called "old wood" is rare in deforested Ravnica. Statues carved from it are said to house the last of the ancient nature spirits.
Swift, strong, and selfless, the centaurs are the shields of the Conclave.

"About the sphinx, I have mixed feelings. Their wisdom I crave, but their secrecy I can't tolerate."
—Szadek
Izzet mages often acquire their magic reagents from dubious sources, so the potency of their spells is never predictable.
"We are many, yet one. We are separate in body, yet speak with a single voice. Join us in our chorus."
"These alleys are not safe. Come, I can guide you back to the market square."

"Justice is toothless without punishment. Righteousness cannot succeed without the suffering of the guilty."
—Razia
There's an experience worse than blindness—it's the certainty that your vision is perfect and the horror that there's no world around you to see.
It wants to remain a mystery, banishing the curious in favor of less inquisitive company.
Nothing stops industry in Ravnica—certainly not the safety of its workers.
"Four parts molten bronze, yes . . . one part frozen mercury, yes, yes . . . but then what?"
Equenauts are the seeds of the Conclave, scattered on the four winds, searching for new places to take root.
"It is fitting that we meet in the first hour of light, for we are called by the Conclave to pierce a threat of darkness."
Dimir rank and file never see nor hear their guildmaster. All orders are given through mysterious necrosages who appear from the shadows, tersely toss out a command, and then melt into the darkness.
The words came to the sorcerer's lips but refused to budge any further.
Simic mages create redundant backups of their experiments to reduce the consequences of catastrophe.
The Orzhov started using hawks as messengers in order to bypass the many toll roads and bridges that dot Ravnica. Soon the service became one of their most profitable businesses.
The spoiled, gluttonous halls of the Orzhov teem with gaudy, needless wealth. Even their security measures are made for beauty first, efficiency second.
Greatness, at any cost.

"The soil here is rich with the rotting dead, and the sun's fingers barely penetrate the dark canopy. Plant our brethren here. This shall be our sanctuary."
—Savra
Into the light the good are welcomed, and with the light the evil are banished.
Other guilds demand tolls from those who travel their territories, but not House Dimir. It takes its share secretly, one coin purse at a time.
"Fear not. Your life will not go unlived."
An emblem of a secret guild, the Dimir insignia is seen only by its own members—and the doomed.

"We thought we found the victim's clothes lumped in the street. As it turned out, it was the victim, insides sucked out—just a sack of skin and robes."
—Agrus Kos
Justice flies swiftly on angry wings.
There is no shelter from this storm, its rain of fists, or the thunderous cackles of bloodlust.
He combs the streets looking for the lost light, the discarded enigmas of the city.

"Falconry? A fine sport I suppose, if you're attracted to the frailty of birds."
—Trivaz, Izzet mage
The tendrils of sorcery find easy purchase on the soft underbelly of dreams.

"I have seen much from the back of my dromad, most of it terribly wrong. The more I see, the more I am convinced of the rightness of my path."
—Heruj, Selesnya initiate

"The Golgari expand, yes, but I refuse to call their tainted creations ‘growth.'"
—Veszka, Selesnya evangel

"I awoke to the face of beauty, my body fully healed. In that moment I knew my destiny was the Conclave's to shape."
—Rogad, Selesnya initiate
In a space where there is no room, in a structure that was never built, meets the guild that doesn't exist.
Cast out of the Conclave generations ago, these elves found a home in the corrupted districts of the Golgari.
The spires of Ravnica are no different from the tall trees of other planes. The elves navigate and protect them just the same.
When the dead are laid to rest in Ravnica, it's usually just a nap.

"Though used as a piercing weapon, the tusk is more akin to a stinger, spreading pain instantly throughout the body of its victim. This specimen deserves further study."
—Simic research notes
"How truly vast this city must be, that I have traveled so far and seen so much, yet never once found the place where the buildings fail."
Everyone knows that violence at the Festival brings the worst of luck, so for at least one day a year arms are laid down in favor of brimming goblets.
The Boros legionnaire saw a noble sacrifice, the Rakdos thug a blazing suicide, and the Izzet alchemist an experiment gone awry.
Saprolings add the three and the four to the "one-two punch."

"A single item acting as lantern and lance? Now that's military efficiency."
—Brev Grezar, Boros lieutenant
Boros soldiers are like a cache of bombs ready to explode, and the flame-kin light their fuses.
The view from above is an inspiration to the newly winged.

"A system to direct the flow of Ravnica's entire water supply? Thinking a bit small, aren't we?"
—Trivaz, Izzet mage
Æther can turn a footprint into a blueprint.
The upside to not thinking about the consequences is that you'll always surprise those who do.

"Ditri, I leave this checkpoint in your capable teeth."
—Kitov, nightguard patrol
Even the dead give way to the mineral gaze of the gorgon.

"Ma said we should offer up blini-cakes and salt to the good ones, but I get that chill up my spine and just shut the door."
—Otak, Tin Street shopkeep
The righteous light of Selesnya is channeled through the devout, striking out to blind the nonbelievers.
Izzet artificers have learned to steer their beautiful constructs clear of Boros warhammers—and the opera house.

"I am confident that if anyone actually penetrates our facades, even the most perceptive would still be fundamentally unprepared for the truth of House Dimir."
—Szadek
Chimney sweeps, explorers of abandoned buildings, spire climbers . . . goblin spelunkers have found countless niches within Ravnica's metropolis.
The Golgari don't bury their dead. They plant them.
Like corpse-worms through a carapace, rotwurms slide through the hollowed bones of the undercity.
Depending on your point of view, the seal represents a proud guardian of the natural cycle or one who has sold her soul to darkness for eternal life.
The glittering strands of its complex web catch everything from a buzzing gnat to a passing bloatdrake.
Each tooth carries enough bacteria to kill a person in a day or two. But then, gharials do have 138 teeth.
Few have seen the inner workings of Ravnica's furnaces, but neighboring districts catch brief glimpses in the horrors that escape the flames.
Man's best fungus.
It stands sentinel to the great City-Tree, home of the Selesnya Conclave.

"Earth to æther, window to wonder, stillness to the sky."
—Glazing incantation

"Oh sure, they buy a lot of ale, but I always find myself needing to rebuild after the giants have paid a visit."
—Belko, owner of Titan's Keg tavern
Sometimes you go to hell, and sometimes hell comes to you.
When killing five just isn't enough.

"Ravnica, like a hedge, must be pruned, leaving only leaves of verdant uniformity."
—Niszka, Selesnya evangel
The knights see a mighty quarry. The dragon sees breakfast, lunch, and dinner.
The lammasu ruled the velds before the city grew. Now they roam Ravnica's skies, but their ancient enemies have not forgotten them.

"The Boros say they want to bring order to Ravnica. Funny then, how well they use chaos."
—Trigori, Azorius senator
All it knows is the difference between friend and food.

"Lost man, dead man, knocking on the door.
Cankerman, soreman, knock no more."
—Ravnican children's rhyme

"The Rakdos know little of technology, but they definitely know how to push buttons."
—Trivaz, Izzet mage
Her ivy locks are a remnant of the wooded wilds now lost to Ravnica forever.
One man's trash is another man's troller.
Her cold wail echoes in the alleys and under-eaves, finding the unfortunate and turning their blood to ice.
"Allow me a moment to catch your breath."
Constructed of leather and irony.
The magic of the Boros patrols the streets even when their soldiers do not.
The Legion looks after its own.
Though less well-known than its army of soldiers, the Boros Legion's mage-priests are as respected by the innocent as they are hated by the ghosts of the guilty.
Lies are sold as often as truths—and used just as effectively.
The gatekeepers are so fastidious that even the winds must wait to pass.
"I have lived long, and I remember how this city once was. If my death serves to bring back the Ravnica in my memory, then so be it."
In the undercity, forgetfulness is often encouraged at the point of a blade.
Tharashk the Bold suddenly wasn't himself. Or anyone else, for that matter.
When he reaches for his key ring, you should be running for the exit.

"My criticism of the Izzet is that their impulse for learning seems too much like impulse and too little like learning."
—Trigori, Azorius senator
True enlightenment comes not with a new thought, but with understanding of all the old ones.
Some take after their father, Stone, some after their mother, Fire.
At every fifth full moon, the Moon Market convenes to peddle Ravnica's most forbidden wares.

"Touched by moroii"
—Undercity slang meaning "to grow old"
Mortipede pheromones choke the streets with sickly sweetness, luring the rash and unwary into its waiting jaws.
"The Wojek defend the laws. We defend the people."
The shepherds work in secret, seeking out abominations against nature and returning them to earth and dust.
Nullstone absorbs and dampens most forms of magical energy, as well as light, sound, and heat.
The town stands on his ancestors' former burial grounds. Even with the graves long gone, he continues his determined vigil.
Thick of muscle, stout of heart, and possessing a burning love of justice and the battlefield, the Ordruun minotaurs are the foundation of the Boros Legion.
"Let the song of Selesnya be heard above the rhythm of our thundering hordes!"
To bear the shield of the pariah is the highest honor a Boros can receive—and the last.
When House Dimir's secrets are in danger of exposure, the guild takes drastic measures to cover its tracks.
The mask confers both the prowess of a falcon and its loyalty.

"This is the place? This map has got to be wrong . . . ."
—Svania Trul, wayfinder novice, last words

"Look at this creature, so like the Conclave it serves. Cut one head and it grows two. Damage it and it flourishes."
—Veszka, Selesnya evangel
For each creature that arrives in its audience, the sage imparts another piece of ancient wisdom for all to hear.

"Gold can be reearned, goods restored. The moroii steal youth, more precious than either, and once gone, it's gone forever."
—Berta Suszat, civic healer

"All matter, animate or not, rots when exposed to time. We merely speed up the process."
—Ezoc, Golgari rot farmer
Most Ravnicans lead lives of desperate survival. Those who thrive are malleable enough to change with the ever-shifting politics of the guilds.
There's plenty to talk about in the marketplaces of Ravnica, be it the latest feud between guilds or the terrible weather.
Yuri took up the ragged Boros banner, and his brethren, inspired by the act, followed him back into the fight.
Only the chosen ones are spared.
Her sword burns with such brightness that foes avert their eyes and arrows divert their paths.

"The bones of the past will tell their tales—if you know how to speak their language."
—Savra
"Well, at least all of that arm-waving and arcane babbling you did was impressive."
Three hundred years of practice thwarted by an instant of mischief.

"My favorite meal is angel's flesh, slain in agony and iced with black vinegar."
—Aszala of House Dimir
The shadow that fell over the grove was silent yet horribly alive, roiling with millions of tiny minions dedicated to the process of rot.
No heartbeat to hear, no greed to bribe, no fear of death.
It has eight lives' worth of hunger to satisfy.
"Don't worry. I know the drill."
It drifts through the streets as a breeze of collective sighs, wilting the bustle with dreams and heavy eyelids.
"Nature's most raw beauty is the circle: perfect in its continuance, with no break between death and life."
From the seeds of faith, great forests grow.
It has a hundred thousand extinctions to avenge.
They were master fishers, but their seas are now the streets and their catch, the goblins that run pell-mell from the screeching in the sky.

"When I meditate I see the world as it should be. All that does not fit, I remove."
—Alovnek, Boros guildmage

"If you ask me, those root-lovers value mindless dogma over progress."
—Trivaz, Izzet mage
Beneath the beauty of light and seed is the might of Vitu-Ghazi.
Natural disasters in Ravnica are largely nullified by the Izzet. Unnatural disasters, on the other hand, happen all of the time.
"The clamor of the city drowns all voices. But together we can sing a harmony that will resonate from Ravnica's tallest spires to her deepest wells."

"What's their strike range, you ask? Let's put it this way: sagittars aim their bows using maps."
—Otak, Tin Street shopkeep
The symbol of the Conclave is one of unity, with tree supporting sun and sun feeding tree.
"Killing is easy. Just wrap your hand around the haft, and wrap your enemy around the blade."
They hardly have form, dripping through pipe and grate with the slip and stench of flowing sewage.

"Your ignorance is my bliss."
—Szadek
The Rubblefield was once among the wealthiest districts in Ravnica. All it took was a single wurm to reduce it to ruins.

"I do not know which gives me more pride: the legions of soldiers marching in thunderous lockstep, or the cry of the skyknights riding their rocs like jagged lightning overhead."
—Razia
Ravnica's laws protect not its citizens but its industry. Aging equipment is destroyed rather than restored, to bring more money into the factories' coffers.
The irritable drakes are solitary nesters. Even brooding females barely contain the urge to attack their own young.
Pajik was amazed and pleased at his newfound powers. His pet cat Rivin was slightly less enthusiastic.
"The trick isn't setting up the bad trade. It's making each side think it got the better deal."
The first searchlights were given as gifts, symbols of cooperation, to the emissaries present at the signing of the Guildpact.
The Simic created the cells to preserve their experiments. The Azorius put the cells to use on the guilty.
Her touch brings to bare stone what water and sun bring to rich soil.
There is no place in Ravnica for stagnation, no room for lands unfilled and untilled.

"Why limit yourself to mortal law when you can outlive those who enforce it?"
—Czaric, Orzhov prelate
Centuries of wind, rain, and roots compressed into an instant of destruction: such is the power of Selesnya.

"Law soothed his savage heart. Where fury once burned, the enduring flame of order now shines."
—Razia
Sunhome—the stalwart shield, the towering sentinel, the seat of justice.
The most feared of Azorius punishments is to be freed—sent back out into the world, stripped of all magical defenses.

"If only my poxes were as infectious as their zealotry."
—Savra
Their natural curiosity, combined with a knack for trespassing, makes sprites excellent spies.

"Drakes embody the worst of Ravnica: great potential, twisted by selfishness and greed."
—Razia
Mastery is achieved when "telling time" becomes "telling time what to do."
"This feels a little more like home."
"Once the brew gets the brains nice and pickled, they're a lot easier to pick through."

"Choose one to heal, one to harm, and one to grant you the prudence to use them."
—Miotri, auratouched mage

"Hear that? Those notes mean we've arrived at Sunhome! Let our allies' hearts soar and our enemies' hearts shatter at the sound!"
—Klattic, Boros legionnaire
Market hucksters sell molochs for use as watchdogs. Of course, that's all molochs do. Sit around . . . and watch.
"Forget yourself. Forget your city. Forget your homes, your families, the debts and obligations that hold you to this world."
In Otiev's mind, he ruled in favor of the accused. But in his courtroom he was only a spectator, watching his hand deliver the sign of death.

"Officially, there's nothing under that bridge to hunt . . . Unofficially, my torchers are too terrified to go there after nightfall."
—Agrus Kos
A friendly ursapine means a constant supply of sharp spears. An unfriendly one means a constant supply of small holes.

"I crept up on him, quiet as a guttermouse. And then suddenly I found myself facedown in a latrine pit behind Tin Street Market."
—Sirislav, Dimir spy
Their denial reaches far into your future.
"Give me a sword and I'll kill a few enemies. But give me a hammer and a fiery forge, and I'll turn the tide of battle."

"When the bony terminus gets too large, it's shed from the tail in coinciding periods of heightened aggression and hunger."
—Simic research notes
Citizens of Ravnica stick to the main streets. Shortcuts may look tempting, but down each alley, dozens of hungry hands await, and screams do not carry into the busy market throng.
After fear and weakness rot away, that which remains is stronger than its living form.
Many minds, a single madness.
It grows to hate you.
In the autumn, she casts her seeds across the streets below, and come spring, her children rise in service to the Conclave.
An ageless order, the votaries receive the gift of rejuvenation from the temple gardens they guard.
Voyager staffs are sought by those hoping to find an escape from the sprawling glut of Ravnica.

"When something dies, all things benefit. Well okay, just our things."
—Ezoc, Golgari rot farmer

"In a town shaped by the subtle machinations and political intrigue of its guilds, it's reassuring to see a goblin waving his torch and screaming about some nonsense or other."
—Agrus Kos
Only in Ravnica do the wolves watch the flock.

"Be careful what information you ask them to find, for it will likely be the subject of tale time at the alehouse."
—Sirislav, Dimir spy
Each soul he devours adds its hunger to his own.
"A few arrows aren't enough to pierce your faith, soldier. You'll be back on the battlefield by sun's dawn."
"Your brother's crimes are your crimes. You stood by and lent support, so you too must face judgment."
It is the call to arms, the call to fury, the call to blood.

"Its darkened sap penetrates natural fibers and spreads its own genes. Emulation experiments are underway."
—Simic research notes

"Nothing could be more natural than roots sucking nourishment from the dead."
—Savra
A spiteful force exists on Ravnica that binds these ghosts to the land of the living but forbids them to touch it.
Some smiles show cheer; some merely show teeth.
Facets of life, reflections of the soul.

"One timely cry of warning can save nine of surprise."
—Sidar Jabari

Trade to trade, not to keep.
—Suq'Ata motto

"Even the ancient storytellers proclaimed Zhalfir to be dominant over all Jamuraa. Kaervek's invasion shocked us all."
—Hakim, Loreweaver

Zhalfir's destiny rings in tempered steel.
—Armorer Guild maxim

"What you call decay, I call ripening. You'll gain no sustenance from this harvest."
—Kaervek

"Omens lie in this early harvest's fruit."
—Asmira, Holy Avenger

"A vizier's dish, best served drenched in honey and almonds."
—Suq'Ata royal recipe

"The Mwonvuli Jungle has given the darkness teeth for tearing the gift of life from the weak."
—Jolrael

"The trollish game of push-fall inspired this impressive tactic."
—Sidar Jabari

"Wear the falcon's feathers in your hair—
be fast as the falcon, bright as the Sun."
—"Rise on Wings," Zhalfirin song

The best use for a unicorn's horn is to adorn a unicorn.
—Femeref adage

"In all my years I've only met one mage who successfully trapped a djinn—and none who tried and failed."
—Talibah, embermage

A crash of rhinos in my head
—Femeref expression meaning
"a severe head pain"

"Tell me . . . have you ever sung the Song of Blood?"
—Purraj of Urborg

"My shield will bear a shining sun so you will always be with me. / Inlaid with gold, it will shine like glowing embers."
—"Love Song of Night and Day"

I live without food, stand without leg, wound without force, and am harder to fight than to kill. What am I?
—Femeref riddle

"Only fools believe they will face my armies but once."
—Kaervek

"The protection offered comes at a price. How numerous are your kin?"
—Purraj of Urborg
A lie always returns; be careful how you catch it.

"As a child, I slept with a cloth over my face, to hide from the spirits that might pull the air from my lungs."
—Mosi, Femeref weaver

"Defiantly, the young cyclops popped the brushwagg into his mouth. His cheeks suddenly puffed, his eye bulged, and he was forced to agree with his elder."
—Afari, Tales
There is only so much a person may be buried with.
Even the lion envies the lark.

"Any day that I ride my horse up to my ankles in the remains of my enemies is a good day."
—Akin, seasoned askari

"It's filthy work, planting them."
—Kifimbo, Shadow Guildmage

Grieve for the soul in death dishonored.
—Shadow Guild saying

"In the Mwonvuli you must divide your attention between what hangs overhead and what lies underfoot."
—Sidar Jabari
King or herder, the maggots care not.

"Once, a Quirion asked why I was so cautious when the day was clear. I told him of the sky-blue hide of the cerluean wyvern, and he offered me double if I could conjure a strong tailwind!"
—Sisay, Captain of the Weatherlight

"I dance the nothing dance, / Feet in the air, knives in the ground."
—Femeref chant

"Sun follows Moon until she tires, then carries her until she's strong / and runs ahead of him again."
—"Love Song of Night and Day"

"The people wiped the sand from their eyes and cursed—and left the barren land to the hyenas and vipers."
—Afari, Tales

"Life is a resource that should belong only to the strong."
—Shauku, Endbringer

To condemn the innocent you must first condemn yourself.
—Civic Guild maxim

"Useful . . . if you can find it."
—Pashad ibn Asim, Suq'Ata trader

Love is like a rhino, short-sighted and hasty; if it cannot find a way, it will make a way.
—Femeref adage

"Dragonfire forged me a warrior."
—Rashida Scalebane

"Once, a wealthy king commissioned an artificial creature to be crafted from the royal treasury, thinking it a clever ploy to have the jewels guard themselves."
—Azeworai, "The Golem's Wish"

Pass me from soul to soul / soldier to herder, herder to beast, beast to soil / until I am everywhere. / Then pass me those souls.
—Totem inscription (translated)
Thus does nature assert herself.
In front of every great wizard is a doomed apprentice.

"Femeref was guided by the wisdom of the Council of Voices. But in one terrible instant, they were slain, leaving Asmira as the sole voice of leadership."
—Hakim, Loreweaver

"The ceremony ended with a voice from the shadows, a voice with vast, ominous power."
—Kifimbo, Shadow Guildmage

"The foul entities of the Uuserk swamp had never before dared to spread their influence to the very heart of Zhalfir."
—Hakim, Loreweaver

"Mangara is gone. Who among you doubts that I have taken his power?"
—Kaervek

"There are harsher ways to learn the meaning of the word ‘no.'"
—Rashida Scalebane

"If you weren't born with it, you don't need it."
—Grahilah, former trader of Amiqat

"Suq'Ata believe in trade; Femeref, alms; Zhalfirins, steel. Be warned, Kaervek—now we are joined."
—Sidar Jabari

"To the undiscerning eye, justice and vengeance can look the same."
—Rashida Scalebane

Whatever follows life is incurable.
—Zhalfirin aphorism

Dreams' riches are easily spent.
—Suq'Ata adage
Not only the sleeping should fear dreams.

"Fetch the pestridder, Paka—we've got dwarves in the rutabagas!"
—Jamul, Femeref farmer

A dwarf's life belongs as much to the land as to the dwarf.
—Creed of the Stonethrow Clan

"Tonight we'll eat a farewell feast. Cold corn porridge is not enough. / Let's peel papayas, pineapples, and mangoes, drink coconut milk, / and bake bananas."
—"Love Song of Night and Day"

"Big one I,
One big eye.
One-eye see
Two-eye die!"
—Traditional cyclops chant

"My goat was a small price to pay for the chance to see the hunting griffin dive and seize it."
—Pashad ibn Asim, Suq'Ata trader

"Eternal life or your money back."
—Unnamed Suq'Ata merchant, deceased
The fire breathes while the air burns.
A hefty price is no guarantee of quality merchandise.
Life and death are two faces of the same coin.

"If it is weak, either kill it or ignore it. Anything else honors it."
—Kaervek

"I do not teach. I simply reveal."
—Daudi, Femeref tutor
From jungle to sea, from sea to stone, from stone to field, from field to bone. What am I? —Zhalfirin riddle
"Whoa—my tail will never fit through that hole!"

"If I have learned anything as a wizard it is this: never fight your own battles."
—Waffa, sorcerer of Nyomba

". . . and when the farmer awoke the next morning, all the seeds from his field were once again in their sacks."
—Afari, Tales

"They say a Zhalfirin archer can split the eye of a griffin. Nonsense, of course: they have no faith to guide their darts."
—Nuru, Femeref archer

"Faith is my shield, and hope is my armor; I am vulnerable only to myself."
—Asmira, Holy Avenger
"I will return / with lizard skins for your sandals. Paint your eyes black and wait for me." —"Love Song of Night and Day"

"The days before the war were filled with strange portents: scouts and herders spoke of villages reduced to ash, of farmers taken from their fields, and of foul beasts roaming the plains in packs. I know, for I spoke to them all."
—Hakim, Loreweaver

"The night stalkers are such a minor power in Urborg. Their sad eagerness to elevate themselves makes them willing tools in the plundering of little Femeref."
