To train her elves for war, Mayael would drop a sackful of acorns from the tree canopy. Each archer tried to split as many as possible before the acorns hit the forest floor below.

"Whether or not you will bow to me is not open to debate. The question is, will I ever let you rise?"
—Fridius, telemin master
One goes to Tidehollow either to forget or to be forgotten. Either way, the scullers will oblige.

"The road to truth has many branches, and so must the cane with which I walk it."
—Voln the Elder

"With no flesh, there is no pain, no hesitation, no emotion of any kind. He is crafted perfection."
—Tezzeret
The problem with a liquid that can dissolve anything is finding something to carry it in.
Alara is broken no more.
When Asha left Bant, she ensured that the world would have protection and order in her absence.
They lament the doom that is coming to Bant without realizing the part their own leaders have played in it.
Underneath the cities of Esper are cycles of life unseen by those who feed them.
An avatar he sculpts of wisdom and strength.
Seeds from Jund don't drift gently on the wind. They get up and stampede.

"They think they're winning. But they're just lining up to be dinner."
—Rakka Mar
Some who scouted new lands chose to stay.
There are no "weak" creatures on Jund. Even the smallest can strike a deadly blow.
Jund's thallids tried to disguise their deliciousness by covering themselves in spines harvested from the tukatongue tree.
The goblins went to sleep in Jund and awoke in Grixis. They'd never seen a zombie before. They would never see one again.

"Send it back to its own strange world so we can avoid another inglorious combat with these wicked beings."
—Captain Valek of Jhess
Plowbeasts of Naya escaped their harnesses in droves, content to snack on the conveniently cultivated fields of Eos and Valeron.
After years of honing her philosophy in debate with stubborn rhoxes, Niella was ready to convert any heathen.
As the outsiders invaded Bant, soldiers who once saw sigils as the highest marks of glory began to see the scars of battle as tokens of equal worth.
With their life energy suppressed under their etherium enhancements, thieves from Esper found it surprisingly easy to explore the ruins of Grixis.
The Seekers of Carmot searched across the unknown lands for the mystical red stone that could reforge Esper in ethereal perfection.
"I'll fight two at once, and then lick their guts from my blades."
"This air feels so heavy and thick. There are no winds to speak of. I fear the knowledge that comes from a place like this."
As Grixis collided with the rest of Alara, the worlds began to hear the hateful whispers of the forgotten dead.

"How can we outrun the sky?"
—Hadran, sunseeder of Naya
The lives of elves are long, but their memories are longer. Even after death, they do not desert their homes.
Tired of waiting for a dragon to eat them, some hardy goblins struck out to become meals for the unknown.

"Leotau that were born wild make the best mounts. It's like riding a thunderstorm."
—Rafiq of the Many
Every horizon hides a new possibility.

"The meek inherit nothing."
—Sedris, the Traitor King
The demon's yoke is part leash, part noose.
The ripe smell of life drifted into Grixis. The dead caught the scent and with reckless hunger followed it back into Jund.
When the task spilled over into undeath, he stopped calling it his life's work.
Life's circle has become inverted in Grixis. The same energy is endlessly recycled and becomes more stagnant with each pass.
Bant's armies are primarily composed of members of the Mortar caste, loyal commoners who haven't yet earned a sigil.
It lurks just under the surface, using the algae-choked tar pits of Jund as both home and hunting blind.
Rigorous faith and belief are rewarded on occasion, and richly so.

"Even in single combat, I am never alone."
—Rafiq of the Many
Clash of sword and cry of beast fall mute when angels sound the call to prayer.

"We must rely on our own knowledge, not on the dogma of the seekers or the mutterings of the sphinxes."
—Tullus of Palandius
The necropolis at Unx was once a living city, its streets untrodden by death.
The consuming undeath of Grixis terrifies the survivors of Vithia, but its fauna is just as fearsome.
"A night attack will be easy. We'll make an air raid over the Akrasan border. Just get me some flint to light the war torches."
Bant is a world where death and chaos hold no sway.
Bant's hearts are as pure as its air and as bright as its skies.
"Mine is an insatiable god, with appetites as magnificent as the jungle itself."
While the smell of burning flesh is common in Grixis, the odor of smoldering brain matter is a rare treat.
Warriors of the Rip Clan wear their beetle-acid scars proudly, even modifying clothing and armor to better display the trophy.
"To immortality."
Elementals born of Jund are as cruel and unstable as the plane itself.
Naya's celebrants stoke the gargantuans into a rage, loosing a tide of muscle with the precision of an arrow.
Witches of the Split-Eye Coven speak of a future when Grixis will overflow with life energy. For now, they must harvest vis from the living to fuel their dark magics.

"Lightning lives in everything, in living flesh and growing things. It must be set free."
—Rakka Mar
Revealing the truth only deepened Tezzeret's curiosity for the secrets still buried.
Frozen in fear, the goblins stared upward at the circling hunter—and were promptly eaten by its diving mate.
It holds motionless vigil, watching Naya in silence through the screen of the whitecover. When it senses anything amiss, it launches forward with the uncanny sound of torn fog.
On Bant, a sigil is both a prize of honor and a bond of duty. The one who bears it may be called to fulfill that charge at any moment.
"What you are attempting is not against the law. It is, however, extremely foolish."
Viashino hunt in gangs called thrashes. Not all thrashes hunt the freshest game.
"Forget. Only then will there be space for hope between the pain and fear."
Natives of Naya know better than to loiter near the mouth of a cave. Two glowing red eyes and the stench of foul breath are all the warning you're likely to get.
Be worthy of a single blessing, and many more will follow.
A permanent storm rages over the plain of Cloudheath, and drakes ride its currents—two reminders that some elements of Esper will not be controlled.
Etherium does not know sleep. Only magic can teach it the resting state of cold steel.
In ages past, Esper couriers bore messages written on ornate scrolls. The medium has grown more sophisticated, but the principle remains the same.
The Sun-Dappled Court of Valeron stands secure behind a wall of steel-tipped arrows.
Before signing anything on Grixis, always read the fine print.
Naya's trees grow tall and sturdy. Their foliage intertwines to form dewcups, rainwater pools where the elves gather to celebrate life.

"The dragon is a perfect marriage of power and the will to use it."
—Sarkhan Vol
There is always a greater power.

"They say the ruins of Sedraxis were once a shining capital in Vithia. Now it is a blight, a place to be avoided by the living."
—Olcot, Rider of Joffik
"Give me your memories, and you will have release from the suffering they bring you."
From her sunsail tent high above the forest floor, an elf harkener can hear the footfalls of a single creature through the cacophony of Naya's jungle sounds.
Their shots are fired most often as signals—or at those who didn't get the message.
For the necromancer barons, killing and recruitment are one and the same.
"The bones of allies grant wisdom. The bones of enemies grant strength. The bones of dragons grant life eternal."
Some Serul Cove rogues traffic in stolen sigils, which fetch a high price from those who would rather pay for honor than earn it.
"May these deaths be the first of many."

"I find its symmetry pleasing. It rids our world of offensive refuse while disposing of itself."
—Dolomarus, Proctor of the Clean
Goblins journey to the sacrificial peaks in pairs so that the rare survivor might be able to relate the details of the other's grisly demise.
The penultimate step of the ritual involves bathing in a delicious glaze.

"On our thirty-fourth day of digging, we unearthed a chamber that contained the intact remains of several species long extinct from Grixis. One in particular should make a fine siege engine . . . ."
—Last notes of Shungus Nod, fleshcrafter
The undead of Grixis are fueled by their hatred of the living.
Although the Anima herself remains at the Sacellum, her druids roam Naya, collecting mana bonds with every location in the world.
"I feel the vine-rhythm as my friends drive the beast to me. I will not miss my mark."
Before any major undertaking, a Cylian elf seeks the guidance of a visionary to learn the will of the gargantuan ancients.
Her wings are the prayers of the devoted; her sword, the despair of the vile.
She can heal the flesh, or exploit its many weaknesses.

"Thoughts are commodities. Someone will pay a good price for them. Even ones as simplistic as yours . . ."
—Ennor, mentalist
Esper is an expansive canvas painted by precise, controlling hands.

"Speculation is foolish when the tools of certainty are available."
—Cinna, vedalken consul
The greatest masters of the craft abandon tools altogether, shaping metal with hand and mind alone.
"The noble work of our order is to infuse all life on Esper with etherium. Our goal will be reached more rapidly if new life is . . . suppressed."
Rebels and other malcontents forced into the ritual awake lost in Topa's vast savannahs. Those who find their way back return humble and repentant.
There is always a moment of trepidation before opening a message capsule, for fear of the judgment that might be contained within.
The artistry of Etlan's firedancers is more spectacular when behemoths join in.
It shreds its prey as each head fights for the choicest bits.
"We of the Sanctum Arcanum have pondered every word on every page of the Filigree Texts. If you can't say the same, don't bother speaking."
Dragon lords of Jund rule by edicts of flame.
Grixis is a world where the only things found in abundance are death and decay. Corpses, whole or in part, are the standard currency among necromancers and demons.

"It's free to do whatever it wants. I've merely told it what that is."
—Xorin, Architect of Will
Before the zealots of the Ethersworn came to power, Esper illusionists dreamed up creations to mimic a variety of substances.
A goblin raid is a delicate gambit—a blend of stealth, precision, and screaming death.
Every once in a while, when they aren't getting incinerated in lava, crushed under rock slides, or devoured by dragons, goblins experience moments of unmitigated glory in battle.
Goblin lairs sit high in Jund's mountains. This gives the goblins easy access to the sacrificial peaks above and lets them build up a head of steam before attacking prey down below.

"Lay sacrifice to the godsire that it may spare us, but save some for his progeny who also will hunger."
—Syeena, elvish godtoucher
"Gargantuans die not in moments but in moons. There is still time to aid this noble ancient."
Vitals of Grixis who eschew undeath must scrape and scratch to retain their mortality. The result is a breed of inventive mages.

"So many choices. Shall I choose loathing, hate, or malice today?"
—Eliza of the Keep
There is no height above Grixis that is free from the stench of death.

"Only by the bravery of those who put loyalty above glory is our home kept safe."
—Elspeth
"The elves claim the canopy. The nacatl claim the mountains. I suppose you think we ought to stay on the jungle floor?"

"The dragon has no pretense of compassion, no false mask of civilization—just hunger, heat, and need."
—Sarkhan Vol
Centuries of careful practice have elevated the casting of protective spells to an art form. What little offensive magic remains on Bant stands little chance of breaching them.
Viashino thrashes keep iguanars as hunting companions, giving them wounded captives as playthings.
Each mutation causes the incurables to look vastly different from one another. They are left with only one thing in common: their insatiable lust for the slaughter.

"This is why we don't go out in banewasp weather."
—Rannon, Vithian holdout
Bantians believe those who are born into the highest caste and live a life of discipline and virtue can ascend to become angels.
The Jhessian navy makes successful raids on Valeron's coastal towns thanks to their spies planted during peacetime.
She stands ready, always watchful, knowing that weeks of peace and serenity can be overturned by a single distant sail.
"Of your blood I will make my mead, an offering to the thirsty jungle."
Jund pulses with raw energy, waiting for shamans to shape it into useful form.
The sky is the dragon's throne, the seat from which it issues its fiery decrees.
On Naya, ambition and treachery are scarce, hunted nearly to extinction by the awe owed to terrestrial gods.
Weavers' webs wall off swaths of territory more effectively than any portcullis made of iron.
Bloated with venom, it crawls Grixis looking for victims to ooze onto.
He watches over the valley where Progenitus sleeps, culling signs from its steaming breaths.
Once a year, Akrasa holds a joust that draws knights and their leotaus from every nation on Bant. The prize is an Akrasan sigil, but the true reward is the angel's kiss.
The Order of the Skyward Eye does the bidding of an evil force, unwittingly stirring fear and mistrust across Bant in accordance with his plans.
Both guide and guard on open plain.
The strength of Bant's caste system is the unfailing loyalty of its meekest members.
Each of his twenty-two braids is bound with bone and leather from a foe.
It shows not what you are but what you were.

"This is going to hurt a lot, but on the bright side, you'll be dead soon."
—Sedris, the Traitor King
Naya's bounty spills over upon itself. Each leaf and flower struggles against the next with thrashing thorns, acidic pollen, and strangling roots.

"Jund is a wounded world. Beware its searing blood spilling out onto the surface."
—Rakka Mar
Urak froze when he heard it. That was his first mistake. He turned and cast a dramatic ward spell. That was his last.
The cup was a gift from the sphinx Tameron, who hoped that those who drank from it would live long enough to decrypt the sphinxes' wisdom.
"Only a mind unfettered with the concerns of the flesh can see the world as it truly is."
The sacred Anima's eyes are blind to all but the grandest truths.

"The Filigree Texts do not compel you to act in accordance with their precepts. They only specify the consequences should you fail."
—Lodus of the Ethersworn
"By the time I got there, the heart had stopped. Fortunately, I was able to replace it with something better."
Why settle for mere enormity?
Rogue mechanists once rummaged through the wastes of the Tidehollow, constructing unauthorized golems to threaten the hegemony of the sphinxes. The orbs put a stop to that.
To crack a mirror is to provide an opening for the reflection to escape.
Whether gargantuans are the manifested will of Progenitus or simply the result of overabundant resources is moot when a herd of them is thundering at you.
The idols of old are rich in minerals and magic. They are torn apart when nature aims to eat well.
"I have trained in all three schools of magic."
Deep in nature's core lies a potential unsullied by greed or civilization.
Between the thunderous footfalls of Naya's behemoths lie moments of perfect quiet.

"Those may be the squirms of one life ending or of another beginning. Either way, I'd leave it alone."
—Rakka Mar
Whether incorporated into the structure of castles or admired as lone symbols, the obelisks stand for Bant's values of loyalty, honor, and truth.
It is a monument as austere, unyielding, and inscrutable as Esper itself.
Like most features of Grixis, the obelisks that remain from the time of Alara now exist only for dark exploitation.
Volcanic ash-winds batter it, climbing vines overwhelm it, dragonfire roasts it, and yet it still stands as a testament to a forgotten world.
Centuries have passed since the plane shattered, yet the obelisks of each shard faithfully serve their long-forgotten purpose.
A circle of light and a word of confinement.
The goblet was a gift from the sphinx Gorael, who hoped humans and vedalken would eventually destroy each other to acquire it, leaving all of Esper to her own kind.
Jund has little necromancy. Instead, the flesh of its dead gives rise to algal fiends.
The island nation of Jhess is under constant siege from Valeron on the mainland. Riders traverse the coastline, always on the lookout for sails or aven.
Dragons make for spiteful gods.
"There are none alive that I cannot crush. There are none dead that I do not command."

"There is no such thing as scrap metal. All such material can be repaired with the proper bonding agent."
—Quennus, metallurgeon

"Amateurish. Nearsighted. A waste of my time and everyone else's."
—Indra, nullmage of Vectis
He scowls at his imperfect creation, then crushes it to scrap. He salvages the etherium and begins anew.
The surprise of a battle cry can be as deadly as a blade.
Many sigils, one purpose.
Naya teems with gargantuans, titanic monsters to whom both nature and civilization defer.
At his side, humble beasts become weapons more deadly than sharpened steel.
The behemoth roared, and the world was blasted free of empires and tyrants.
Elves believe the hydra-god Progenitus sleeps beneath Naya, feeding on forgotten magics.
"Momentum is a great ally."

Rhox monks are dedicated to spiritual growth and learning, and most bear the sigils of many students. However, they do not gladly suffer fools or those who disagree with their carefully wrought dogma.

"Only those with the strength to seize their destiny deserve to have one."
—Nacatl scratchforms
If you breathe, she will fight you. If you breathe fire, she must fight you.

"Aven bandits can be sly. You've got to fill the sky with boulders—and then seek cover immediately."
—Knight-Captain Wyhorn
On Jund, even the landscape is a deadly hunter. Volcanoes, tar pits, and rock slides seem to prey upon the living.
Her connection to the gargantuans puts her in line to become Anima, a sacred but daunting duty.
As their supplies of etherium dwindled, mechanists sent gargoyles farther and farther afield in search of salvage.
Some believe the spiky crystal called sangrite is concentrated dragon's breath. Others think it's crystallized life energy. The clans care only about the power it unleashes when crushed.
Jund is a world as cruel as those who call it home. Their brutal struggles scar the land even as it carves them in its image, a vicious circle spiraling out of control.
Dragons consider drakes to be mockeries of their perfection, destroying them on sight.

"Soon I will sleep, eyes closing to a world tarnished with flesh, and then wake to a polished vision."
—Sharuum
For wisdom's sake, it was built high to gaze on all things. For glory's sake, it was built high as a testament of power. For strength's sake, it was built high to repel all attacks.
He bids his minions rise from their graves to their knees.

"The future is a snake, devouring your life backwards through time. And when you die, believe me, it doesn't stop feeding."
—Sedris, the Traitor King
Whether mechanical or biological, life finds a way to propagate itself.
To gain audience with the hegemon, one must bring a riddle she has not heard.
Kathari, the sickly aven of Grixis, have learned that the corpses by the shoreline are more trap than treat.
"For unwavering commitment and unflinching strength, the Order of the White Orchid confers its sigil. Rise, knight-captain, and do your duty."
Each sigil marks the recognition of a great deed and signifies a duty owed to the one who granted it.
Undeath doesn't end the kathari's search for carrion; it only removes one corpse from the Dregscape.
Fire burns away both flesh and freedom.
An avatar he sculpts of anger and flame.
An avatar he sculpts of fellowship and light.
An avatar he sculpts of instinct and force.
Few Nayans dare hunt the gargantuans. They're regarded not as animals but as forces of nature, like landslides or typhoons.

"Magic cast through a hand of flesh is just as weak as the flesh itself."
—Lodus of the Ethersworn
"What rises without legs, whispers without a voice, bites without teeth, and dies without having life?"
He calls a riddle through the gaps of cloven clouds, hoping for an answer.
The vast network of predation on Jund has actually caused some strange creatures to adapt to being eaten.

"From the highest towers to the deepest sea, all life must be touched by etherium."
—Lodus of the Ethersworn
Knight-stewards guard the Sun-Dappled Court, a grove of immense, sculptured olive trees that represent Valeron's twelve noble families.
Even the most battle-hardened soldiers pause in her presence for a moment of introspection.
Sunseeders quest for areas of open sky. They train plowbeasts to beat back the dense jungle long enough to cultivate a crop.

"We can't beat the necromancers in numbers or raw power. We must beat them with ingenuity and timing."
—Rannon, Vithian holdout
Agents of the Architects of Will mark their victims as a reminder that their secrets are secret no longer.
Viashino thrashes are led by elders who have survived countless challenges.
The scullers beneath Esper keep strixes as trained pets, and set them loose when a fare refuses to pay.

"Retribution is best delivered by claws and rage, with both magnified."
—Ajani
Monks from Topa wander all of Bant, encouraging the Unbeholden to find their place in society through honorable combat.
At sea, the Jhessian fleet strikes swiftly and decisively. On land, facing the elite cavalry of Valeron, its marines must rely on more cautious strategies.

"Esper, like any work of art, can be truly appreciated only from a distance."
—Tezzeret
Even on Esper, there are those who eschew the use of magic in favor of simpler methods.
Underneath the Dregscape lay the remains of creatures long extinct from Grixis.

"Thrashes of the ancient past still linger in spirit and shadow, desperate to sink their claws into our souls."
—Rakka Mar

"Words are a waste of time. Destruction is a language everyone understands."
—Sarkhan Vol
A dragon's death is almost as feared as its life. Old, dying dragons throw themselves into volcanoes, causing massive upheaval and widespread disaster.
The greatest gift you can give a sea aven is solitude.

"Those talons really dig into your skin, but it's better than being dropped."
—Rafiq of the Many

"Never subtle nor cryptic is the reckoning of the mighty."
—Mayael the Anima
"The Cloud Nacatl sit and think, a bunch of soft paws. We are the Claws of Marisi, stalking, pouncing, drawing blood."
She knows the names and secrets of each of Esper's twenty-three winds.
One of the most ferocious and deadly gargantuans, the thoctar never sees its worshippers, but it often awakens surrounded by gifts and sacrifices.

"It is sacrilege to confine a gargantuan to the grinding of straight lines. I will pray that it remembers who is the master of this land."
—Syeena, elvish godtoucher
These spirits of the air are winsome and wild, and cannot be truly contained. Only marginally intelligent, they often substitute whimsy for strategy, delighting in mischief and mayhem.
Benalia has a complex caste system that changes with the lunar year. No matter what the season, the only caste that cannot be attained by either heredity or money is that of the hero.
Battle doesn't need a purpose; the battle is its own purpose. You don't ask why a plague spreads or a field burns. Don't ask why I fight.

'Twas in the bogs of Cannelbrae
My mate did meet an early grave
'Twas nothing left for us to save
In the peat-filled bogs of Cannelbrae.

The most terrifying thing about the Craw Wurm is probably the horrible crashing sound it makes as it speeds through the forest. This noise is so loud it echoes through the trees and seems to come from all directions at once.
Created to destroy Dominia, Demons can sometimes be bent to a more focused purpose.

"O to be a dragon . . . of silkworm size or immense . . ."
—Marianne Moore, "O to Be a Dragon"
Bones scattered around us joined to form misshapen bodies. We struck at them repeatedly—they fell, but soon formed again, with the same mocking look on their faceless skulls.
Foolishly, Najib retreated to his castle at El-Abar; the next morning he was dead. In just one night, the dwarven forces had reduced the mighty walls to mere rubble.

Earth Elementals have the eternal strength of stone and the endurance of mountains. Primordially connected to the land they inhabit, they take a long-term view of things, scorning the impetuous haste of short-lived mortal creatures.
I tell you, there was so many arrows flying about you couldn't hardly see the sun. So I says to young Angus, "Well, at least now we're fighting in the shade!"

Fire Elementals are ruthless infernos, annihilating and consuming their foes in a frenzied holocaust. Crackling and blazing, they sear swift, terrible paths, leaving the land charred and scorched in their wake.

"And topples round the dreary west
A looming bastion fringed with fire."
—Alfred, Lord Tennyson, "In Memoriam"

"There are some qualities—some incorporate things,/ That have a double life, which thus is made/ A type of twin entity which springs/ From matter and light, evinced in solid and shade."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "Silence"
Rather than sheltering her young, the female Fungusaur often injures her own offspring, thereby ensuring their rapid growth.
While it possesses potent venom, the Giant Spider often chooses not to paralyze its victims. Perhaps the creature enjoys the gentle rocking motion caused by its captives' struggles to escape its web.
"From up here we can drop rocks and arrows and more rocks!" "Uh, yeah boss, but how do we get down?"
To become king of the Goblins, one must assassinate the previous king. Thus, only the most foolish seek positions of leadership.

"While most overworlders fortunately don't realize this, Gargoyles can be most delicious, providing you have the appropriate tools to carve them."
—The Underworld Cookbook, by Asmoranomardicadaistinaculdacar

The Ogre philosopher Gnerdel believed the purpose of life was to live as high on the food chain as possible. She refused to eat vegetarians, and preferred to live entirely on creatures that preyed on sentient beings.

Don't try to outrun one of Dominia's Grizzlies; it'll catch you, knock you down, and eat you. Of course, you could run up a tree. In that case you'll get a nice view before it knocks the tree down and eats you.
Fortunately, Hill Giants have large blind spots in which a human can easily hide. Unfortunately, these blind spots are beneath the bottoms of their feet.

The Minotaurs of the Hurloon Mountains are known for their love of battle. They are also known for their hymns to the dead, sung for friend and foe alike. These hymns can last for days, filling the mountain valleys with their low, haunting sounds.

"...There was no trace/ Of aught on that illumined face..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Phantom"
Generations of genetic weeding have given rise to the deviously cowardly Ironclaw clan. To say that Orcs in general are vicious, depraved, and ignoble does not do justice to the Ironclaw.

The mating habits of Treefolk, particularly the stalwart Ironroot Treefolk, are truly absurd. Molasses comes to mind. It's amazing the species can survive at all given such protracted periods of mate selection, conjugation, and gestation.
"Some of the other guys dared me to touch it, but I knew it weren't no ordinary hunk o' rock." —Norin the Wary
We had taken refuge in a small cave, thinking the entrance was too narrow for it to follow. To our horror, its gigantic head smashed into the mountainside, ripping itself a new entrance.
After years of training, the Druid becomes one with nature, drawing power from the land and returning it when needed.

Some fiendish mage had created a horrifying wall of living flesh, patched together from a jumble of still-recognizable body parts. As we sought to hew our way through it, some unknown power healed the gaping wounds we cut, denying us passage.
Whenever the Llanowar Elves gather the fruits of their forest, they leave one plant of each type untouched, considering that nature's portion.
A master of tactics, the Lord of Atlantis makes his people bold in battle merely by arriving to lead them.
Of royal blood among the spirits of the air, the Mahamoti Djinn rides on the wings of the winds. As dangerous in the gambling hall as he is in battle, he is a master of trickery and misdirection.

Most human scholars believe that Merfolk are the survivors of sunken Atlantis, humans adapted to the water. Merfolk, however, believe that humans sprang forth from Merfolk who adapted themselves in order to explore their last frontier.

Before a woman marries in the village of Sursi, she must visit the land of the Mesa Pegasus. Legend has it that if the woman is pure of heart and her love is true, a Mesa Pegasus will appear, blessing her family with long life and good fortune.

The intricate dynamics of Rundvelt Goblin affairs are often confused with anarchy. The chaos, however, is the chaos of a thundercloud, and direction will sporadically and violently appear. Pashalik Mons and his raiders are the thunderhead that leads in the storm.
The Nightmare arises from its lair in the swamps. As the poisoned land spreads, so does the Nightmare's rage and terrifying strength.

"Look to the north; there you will find aid and comfort."
—The Book of Tal

"The foot stone is connected to the ankle stone, the ankle stone is connected to the leg stone..."
—Song of the Artificer
In a rare display of ingenuity, the Orcs invented an incredibly destructive weapon. Most Orcish artillerists are those who dared criticize its effectiveness.

"‘Do you know, I always thought Unicorns were fabulous monsters, too? I never saw one alive before!' ‘Well, now that we have seen each other,' said the Unicorn, ‘if you'll believe in me, I'll believe in you.'" —Lewis Carroll
These beings embody the essence of true heroes long dead. Summoned from the dreamrealms, they rise to meet their enemies.

"While, like a ghastly rapid river,
Through the pale door,
A hideous throng rush out forever,
And laugh—but smile no more."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "The Haunted Palace"

"Should you a Rat to madness tease
Why ev'n a Rat may plague you..."
—Samuel Coleridge, "Recantation"
Occasionally a member of the Institute of Arcane Study acquires a taste for worldly pleasures. Seldom do they have trouble finding employment.

We encountered a valley topped with immense boulders and eerie rock formations. Suddenly one of these boulders toppled from its perch and sprouted gargantuan wings, casting a shadow of darkness and sending us fleeing in terror.
Trained in the arts of stealth, the royal assassins choose their victims carefully, relying on timing and precision rather than brute force.
Healers ultimately acquire the divine gifts of spiritual and physical wholeness. The most devout are also granted the ability to pass physical wholeness on to others.

—Gustha Ebbasdotter
Kjeldoran royal mage

As elusive as the footprint of a djinn
—Suq'Ata expression

"You know you've angered the gods when the clouds turn against you."
—Sisay, Captain of the Weatherlight

"There's very little that escapes me, Greven. And you will escape very little if you fail."
—Volrath

Love is like a rhino, short-sighted and hasty; if it cannot find a way, it will make a way.
—Femeref adage

Greven il-Vec lifted Vhati off his feet. "The fall will give you time to think on your failure."

—Lim-Dûl, the Necromancer
"Angels are simply extensions of truth upon the fabric of life—and there is far more dark than light." —Baron Sengir

"The nightstalkers are such a minor power in Urborg. Their sad eagerness to elevate themselves makes them willing tools in the plundering of little Femeref."

"I've seen fog so thick you could cut it, but none that could cut me."
—Tahngarth of the Weatherlight

—Ertai, wizard adept
During the giant crabs' mating season, Skyshroud nights are filled with the clatter of their skirmishes.
A full coffin is like a full coffer—both are attractive to thieves.
A hollow dog is never empty. It is filled with thirst for the hunt.
Anyone can get around a cyclops, but few can stand in its way.

"Controlling time ensures you need never look impulsive again."
—Teferi
Hunger is like the sea: deep, endless, and unforgiving.
"Catch!"

One bone broken for every twig snapped underfoot.
—Llanowar penalty for trespassing

Most spiders wait patiently for their prey to arrive. Most spiders aren't forty feet tall.
He raged at the world, at his family, at his life. But mostly he just raged.
Rath forces plants from its surface as one presses whey from cheese.

"Flourishing during the Ice Age, these wurms were the bane of all Kjeldorans. Their great size and ferocity made them the subject of countless nightmares—they embodied the worst of the Ice Age."
—Kjeldor: Ice Civilization

"If only we could so easily leave behind those parts of ourselves that pain us."
—Crovax
Freyalise forbid that any stranger should wander into the striders' territory.

Lightning tethers souls to the world.
—Kor saying

"This monstrosity will do—for now."
—Davvol, Evincar of Rath
The imps' warbling cries echo through Phyrexia's towers like those of mourning doves in a cathedral.
Drakes claim to be dragons—until the dragons show up.
Music scythes the savage beast.

Don't insult a Talruum unless your mount is swift.
—Suq'Ata saying

"The cyclops shrugged off savage blows, but casual insults made him weep."
—Azeworai, "The Cyclops who Couldn't"

"Most wizards consider a thunderbolt to be a proper retort."
—Ertai, wizard adept
The giant was felt a few seconds before he was seen.
Afterward, Tolaria's winds were like the whispers of lost wizards, calling for life.

"When traveling the Great Desert avoid wearing the scales of lizards, for the Viashino rule the sands and look poorly on the skinning of their cousins."
—Zhalfirin Guide to the Desert
Awake and awing in the blink of an eye.

"no home    no heart    no hope"
—Stronghold graffito

"We need not fear the forces of the air; I've yet to see a spider without an appetite."
—Taaveti of Kelsinko, elvish hunter
When the gorilla playfully grabbed the wurm's tail, the wurm doubled back and playfully ate the gorilla's head.
The arbiter Galanda Feudkiller judges Lorwyn's squabbles from a lofty perspective.
There is nowhere on Lorwyn that the Merrow Lanes cannot go.
Though giants are mortal, they live so long and on such a grand scale that many small folk don't believe they ever truly die.
The Stinkdrinker warren's hill of salvaged trinkets is large enough to cut a door in.
Today it flies with the flock. Tomorrow it may wake to find them gone, its body in an unfamiliar form.
The angriest of giants are often the most skillful weaponsmiths. Their grudges fuel endless sessions at the forge, all the while growling ferociously to themselves.

"Boom Boom Boots the size of oxcarts, then an axe like a falling sun. Elves scattered. Trees scattered. Even the hills ran for the hills"
—Clachan Tales
It absorbs the pain of other treefolk, which leaves it bitter, yet addicted to the sensation of agony.
"The changing kind suffers as we do. We must join as one to quench our tyrants!"
Among the solitude-loving giantkind, teamwork is unusual. But he appreciates hearing the occasional "Swing down and to your left."
"If you want to test wisdom, offer it to fools and watch how they tear it up."
Auntie excitedly held up the squalling newborn. "This one looks like Byoog! Maybe he'll tell us what he saw and felt in the beyond."

"Reach in this hole, lose a hand. Reach in that hole, find a sparkly."
—Auntie wisdom
Auntie Flint lent axes to Nibb and Gyik, thinking they'd share their experiences with her. She's still waiting for them to come back.
Boggarts revel in discovering new sensations, from the texture of an otter pellet to the squeak of a dying warren mate.

"Auntie pointed out to the faerie how much mischief a flying boggart could wreak, and a beautiful new friendship was born."
—A tale of Auntie Grub
Thanks to one champion archer, the true borders of Kinsbaile extend an arrow's flight beyond the buildings.
"We are a clachan of smiths. The forge is as comfortable to us as a small fire during a cool winter's evening."

"As far as I can tell, that frog dangling from the stick serves absolutely no purpose whatsoever."
—Gaddock Teeg
Flamekins' fires burn cool until they decide otherwise.
His home clachan's familial spirit bolsters his own, but he will be ready to preside over the town as cenn only after he learns to project that strength to others.

"Clever folk build their homes near cloudcrowns. If a hawk or even just a faerie tries to swoop in, it'll get swatted from here to Cloverdell."
—Calydd, kithkin farmer

"The elves use treefolk to drive us away. It is time to remove their tools."
—Vessifrus, flamekin demagogue

Five-toed grave
—Kithkin phrase meaning
"a giant's footprint"

"My success at navigating the Dark Meanders irritates the Inkfathom school. They consider themselves peerless divers, but I try to remind them that they cannot own commodities like bravery and cunning."
Lorwyn's stones resonate with the place from which they were hewed. Though taken far, still they call to their home when silence is upon the land.
"Each year that passes rings you inwardly with memory and might. Wield your heart, and the world will tremble."
At night, the faeries steal dreamstuff for their queen. At daybreak, countless creatures wake weak and hollow.
Merrows consider themselves the keepers of Lorwyn's past—and consider it their duty to edit when necessary.
When all is taken away, all are equal.
"How do the vinebred feel? Fah! We do not ask the puppet how it feels when the puppeteer bids it dance."
"No matter how adept our artistic skill, our effigies can never hope to capture the vibrant beauty of a living elf. Perhaps that is truly why we mourn."
The hardest lesson for any elf to learn is humility. It takes a giant to teach that.
The faultless and immaculate castes form the lower tiers of elvish society, with the exquisite caste above them. At the pinnacle is the perfect, a consummate blend of aristocrat and predator.
From mite to mighty.
Fallowsages debate whether the whiskergill is native to the Dark Meanders or merely dreamstuff made real.
Among the boggarts, there is only one real rule: all new treasures and experiences must be shared. Those who hoard their gifts commit the one truly unforgivable sin.

"Those without beauty are Lorwyn's greatest tumor. The winnowers have an unpleasant duty, but a necessary one."
—Eidren, perfect of Lys Alana

Calm as a wisent's watch
—Elvish expression meaning "safe"
Boggarts get so excited when they find something new to smash that they really don't notice who gets underfoot.
Beneath the fae's constant pranks runs a subtler undercurrent of mockery: the influence of Oona, their hidden queen.

Memories of ages past are said to swim the minds of lounging fallowsages.
Because of their capricious nature, faeries can serve as living lenses for disruptive magic.

"What does a mountain fear of a fly? Giants are barely aware of us, let alone afraid."
—Gaddock Teeg
Pretty, valuable, and delicious—a boggart thief's trifecta.
One whiff of the sweet, pungent scent leads to euphoria—or to an early grave.

"My ears say it hisses. My fingers say it burns."
—Auntie Wort

—Vessifrus, flamekin demagogue
When he hits people, they stay hit.
Some flamekin warriors explore the art of coherence, an ancient discipline that harnesses the chaos of fire and focuses it with pinpoint precision.
Leave it to a boggart to come up with a projectile as disgusting as it is deadly.
The scent of rot and vinegar fills the marsh, inviting boggarts from every warren to reunite and feast.

"Petals within petals within petals, tadpole. The truth lurks below an opulence of illusion."
—Neerdiv, fallowsage
So great is his wisdom and spirit that many who have met him say that they stood before a giant of a man and talked to the wisest of the four winds.
In desolate places, changelings may take the shape of fancies, or memories, or fears.
The only feeling greater than hurling something a mile is crushing something else with it that was really, really irritating you.
Dawn's Light, greatest palace of Gilt-Leaf Wood, is built on tiers of wood and power.
Desmera blinded her seers so that her beauty would be the last image burned in their memories. The act only deepened their insight.
Victims spirited through a faerie ring find themselves stranded miles away.
The dreams of giants are as long as time and as deep as the earth. Thus they are prized by the dream-harvesting fae.
Kith goats are just for practice. The real prize, of course, is a giant's cloudgoat.

—Deagan, cenn of Burrenton

Although they're protective of all creatures, many treefolk are especially fond of the empathic kithkin.

"If you live on a giant's back, there's only one individual you'll ever need to fear."

Made from whiskergill bones, merrow spinebows can fire bolts through tree trunks.
Elvish battle-magic has evolved two specialties: inflicting wounds that scar, and healing wounds without scarring. Politics determines the recipients of each.

"Better to flare out than to gutter."
—Flamekin expression

"Apply orange leaf to a wound at dawn to clean it, at dusk to prevent the same injury from happening again."

—A tale of Auntie Grub

—Deagan, cenn of Burrenton
Elves of the immaculate class weave flora into living creatures—sometimes to endorse an elite warrior, sometimes to create a breathing work of art.

"Tie a mouse under a bridge, and your cabbages will triple in size."
—Kithkin superstition
Elementals are ideas given form. This one is the idea of "smashitude."

"None appreciate sun and shallows like those who have seen the depths."
—Lianda of the Stonybrook school
A light an army can follow.
Though the currents of the Lanes shift every year, the merrow never lose track of where they are or where they are going.
Even when a giant's tantrum turns the sky into a chaotic gale, the path of the balloonist never falters.
"If a boggart even dares breathe near one of my kin, I'll know. And I'll not be happy."

Her ears are open to even the softest voice.

Eidren's hunts are dangerous affairs. All dread the inevitable recounting of those who died while flushing out his prey.

A giant can brood over a grudge for decades, and woe to those who interrupt him.

Bulgo paused, puzzled. What was that rustling sound, and why did he feel so stiff? And how could his feet be so thirsty?
"I don't know why the little one was so mad. He said to put him down, and I put him down."

One part cunning, one part wise, and many, many parts demented.

"Beauty determines value, and we determine beauty."

Steady and silent as the deep current, the reejerey guides the course of the school.
If you pick a fight with one kithkin, be ready to fight them all.
Unaware of Lorwyn's diversity, it sees only itself, reflected a thousand times over.

It hoards Lorwyn's rare sorrows.
The oil sloshes against his skull as he nears his destination: the Frogtosser Games and the lighting of the Flaming Boggart.
Just as a changeling's influence can have dramatic effects, so too can its sudden withdrawal.
A savage hunter with a prince's bearing.
Smik learned the elvish dance quickly enough. The most difficult, yet most important step was to stay out of Nath's sight until called to perform.

Like being trapped in a perpetual sneeze, faerie-dust poisoning is both exhilarating and agonizing.

For disfigured elves, there are few choices beyond death or nettlevine.

"May you shade three generations of seedlings."

One good mimic deserves another.
Changelings can alter shape based on what the beings around them desire most.
Once each year, the sun's rays reach the hidden chamber of Velis Vel, and the changelings congregate from afar to bathe in the ever-shifting light.

Though they lack true flesh and bone of their own, changelings imitate either with equal ease.

—Illulia, flamekin soulstoke

It takes a huntmaster's eye to discern the contours of mythical prey.

—A tale of Auntie Grub
Mined from a cave in the Dark Meanders, it shines brightest when no one is looking.

Paradoxically, to tilt the massive jug for a sip, you'd need the energy of the giant's tonic.

In his presence, an ordinary grove becomes a bastion to turn spells and break armies.

For every tree who falls, there are countless sprouts waiting to rise.
Below the great river, a bustling hub channels the flow of merrow trade.
"What do they need all this stuff for? They're dead. We're alive. Simple enough."

—Fiala, Gilt-Leaf winnower

Changeling magic grants unusual wishes.
"Thoughtweft binds us together as one, part of an intricate pattern that would unravel if even one thread came loose."

In a world of bright, cloudless skies, she is the dark storm on the horizon.
Faeries hang beings that interest them as ornaments in the sky, each clique competing to outshine the prize of the last.

"Healing is a matter of time, but it is sometimes also a matter of opportunity."
—D'Avenant proverb

"After these words the magician drew a ring off his finger, and put it on one of Aladdin's, saying: 'It is a talisman against all evil, so long as you obey me.'" —The Arabian Nights, Junior Classics trans.

—The Arabian Nights, Junior Classics trans.
Quick and agile, Amrou Kithkin can usually escape from even the most fearsome opponents.
Among the first allies Urza gained were the people of Kroog. As a sign of friendship, Urza gave the healers of the city potent amulets; afterwards, thousands journeyed to Kroog in hope of healing.

—Maeveen O'Donagh, Memoirs of a Soldier
This invention shows why Ashnod was feared by her troops as well as her foes.
By the time Mishra was defeated, no mage was foolish enough to rely heavily on walls.
Benalia has a complex caste system that changes with the lunar year. No matter what the season, the only caste that cannot be attained by either heredity or money is that of the Hero.

Four things that never meet do here unite
To shed my blood and to ravage my heart,
A radiant brow and tresses that beguile
And rosy cheeks and a glittering smile."
—The Arabian Nights, trans. Haddawy
Battle doesn't need a purpose; the battle is its own purpose. You don't ask why a plague spreads or a field burns. Don't ask why I fight.

My mate did meet an early grave
'Twas nothing left for us to save
In the peat-filled bogs of Cannelbrae.
"They're not your friends; they despise you. I'm the only one you can count on. Trust me."
Fire is never a gentle master.

"It had a mouth like that of a great beast, and gnashed its teeth as it strained to reach us. I am thankful it possessed no means of locomotion."
—Vervamon the Elder
"War is no picnic," my father liked to say. But the Ants seemed to disagree.
Tawnos won fame as Urza's greatest assistant. After he created these warriors, Urza ended his apprenticeship, promoting him directly to the rank of master.

Warrior born from a rocky womb.
". . . [S]creams of horror rend th' affrighted skies." —Alexander Pope, The Rape of the Lock

Noted neither for their good looks nor their charm, Manticores can be fearsome allies.  As dinner companions, however, they are best left alone.
The spirits of Argoth grant new life to those who repent the folly of enslaving their labors to devices.

"The bolts of our ballistae smashed into the monstrous thing, but our hopes died in our chests as its gears continued turning."
—Sevti Mukul, The Fall of Alsoor
Glory surged through her and radiance surrounded her. All things were possible with the blessing of the Divine.

"O to be a dragon . . . of silkworm size or immense . . ." —Marianne Moore, "O to Be a Dragon"

"And the unclean spirits went out, and entered the swine: and the herd ran violently . . . ."
—Mark 5:13

Sometimes it's best to let sleeping dragons lie.

"Sometimes it is better to be swift of foot than strong of swordarm."
—Elven proverb

"What do you have that I cannot obtain?"
—Mairsil, called the Pretender

Fire Elementals are ruthless infernos, annihilating and consuming their foes in a frenzied holocaust. Crackling and blazing, they sear swift, terrible paths, leaving the land charred and scorched in their wake.

"And topples round the dreary west
A looming bastion fringed with fire."
—Alfred, Lord Tennyson, "In Memoriam"

"Must not all things at the last be swallowed up in death?"
—Plato

"A dash of cool water does wonders to clear a cluttered battlefield."
—Vibekke Ragnild, Witches and War

"There are some qualities, some incorporate things, / That have a double life, which thus is made / A type of twin entity which springs / From matter and light, evinced in solid and shade."
—Edgar Allan Poe, "Silence"

". . . [A]nd gives to airy nothing

—William Shakespeare, A Midsummer-Night's Dream

"That phantom prow split the storm as lightning cast its long shadow on the battlefield below."
—Mireille Gaetane, The Valeriad
While it possesses potent venom, the Giant Spider often chooses not to paralyze its victims. Perhaps the creature enjoys the gentle rocking motion caused by its captives' struggles to escape its web.

"O! it is excellent
