A farewell to arms . . . and feet . . . and legs . . . .
In their twisted logic, to empty the shadow world is to escape it.

"All Dauthi are jackals, regardless of breed."
—Lyna, Soltari emissary
Life has always been a dance. It is only fitting that death sing the tune.

"When I cut down my angel I only started my fall."
—Crovax

"Volrath is not the only one who can shape this world to serve him."
—Eladamri, Lord of Leaves
Their fury scatters enemies like a pile of dry leaves.
From nothing came teeth.
In Rath, there are only so many souls to go around.
"In Barrin's name!" cried Lyna as Hanna's sword passed through her, "Ertai sends word that the portal is open—but not for long!"

"Was that it?"
—Ertai, wizard adept
If dragons excel at anything more than vanity, it is greed.

"Consider the fable of the greedy herder. As her flock grew, so did her weariness; she slept, and the sheep wandered off."
—Karn, silver golem
A stroke of luck can smite an army.
"My ship . . . ," Sisay mumbled. "Intact," Gerrard reassured her, "which is more than I can say for you, my friend." Sisay laughed despite the pain.
Furnace air crackles with magmatic cackles.
Mogglings caught in a misdeed often blame the grollub. Even though the creature is usually innocent, no taskmaster can resist an excuse to beat it.

"I will flay the skin from your flesh and the flesh from your bones and scrape your bones dry. And still you will not have suffered enough."
—Greven il-Vec, to Gerrard
In war, as in society, position is everything.
There's little more demeaning than getting your butt kicked by a bunch of bunnies.
Hunger is like the sea: deep, endless, and unforgiving.
The true treasure no thief can touch.
Living below a flowstone foundry produces a disproportionate number of fire mages among the il.
The wizard had it all—until she tried to use it.
Only by sacrificing any semblance of defense could Gerrard best Greven.

"My medicine bag and I have treated countless wounds and illnesses. But never have I seen so many made so sick for so long. We will never eat Squee's cooking again."
—Orim, journal
Hues of recollection flicker like facets of a gem.
In the depths of Rootwater, salvage and sewage differ only in texture.

Lyna turned to the figure beside her. "They're gone. What now?"
"As ever," said Urza, "we wait."
The mirozels are the only stars in Rath's opaque skies.
"Stay."
Any mogg will tell you there's nothing more nauseating than the smell of cute.

"My enemies' death yields threefold benefit: removal, reuse, and research."
—Volrath

Give away everything so others have nothing.
—Brooch inscription
Ogre shamans must be bright enough to learn their invocations and dim enough to use them.
The last thing to go through the mogg's mind was its teeth.
"Our belief shall be the lance that pierces Volrath's heart."

"If we cannot live proudly, we die so!"
—Eladamri, Lord of Leaves

Three are the paths of the soul:
One out—roam across the plain,
One back—dwell with tribe and tent,
One in—turn an enemy's hate.
Its respiration is your expiration.

" . . . And the third little boar built his house out of rootwalla plates . . . ."
—Skyshroud children's story
Hunger growls, never purrs.
Man versus nature is not a fair fight.
"Who you callin' ‘shorty'?"
Is there any other kind?
Volrath has bred them to fear only him. Are they charging into battle, or merely fleeing his wrath?
Build something and the baboons will tear it down. Leave the pieces lying and they will scatter them.
There is no such thing as a regiment of ogres.
The wise pay as much attention to what they throw away as to what they keep.
War favors the informed.

"I am confined by sleep and defined by nightmare."
—Crovax

"It is the art of convincing someone to live."
—Orim, Samite healer
"Does this make me look fat?"
Subduing and skinning an alligator is the first rite of maturity adolescent merfolk must pass.

"Read the roots    tell the tale
Future forms    in waving weeds
Higher than truth   is hope."
—Rootwater Saga
Most creatures grow out of their baby teeth, but sabertooth wyverns grow into theirs.

"Fear rules those weak enough to accept it."
—Greven il-Vec
Some schools aren't worth getting into.

"History is a potent weapon."
—Karn, silver golem
The flowstone seemed for a moment to assume Greven's rage—it lunged like a wild beast at the Weatherlight.
Shackles of gold are still shackles.
They bear weightier burdens than the shields they carry.

"It'll get us to the portal, but I can't guarantee what it'll do to the ship."
—Hanna, Weatherlight navigator

"Civilization is a conspiracy to disguise the mutilation of nature."
—Skyshroud elite creed
Heartwood brings peace in great symphonies where dryads conduct the trees through every note.
Music scythes the savage beast.

Count carefully the souls and see that none are lost.
—Vec teaching

"Everything the wise woman learned she wrote in a book, and when the pages were black with ink, she took white ink and began again."
—Karn, silver golem
A snap of fingers, a snap of teeth.
A sphere pushes equally in all directions.
The less you have, the harder you fight for it.
They drift in and out of shadow and ever on toward madness.

"Volrath stole everything there was of me."
—Takara
"Just take a little off the top."

"What separates junk from treasure is imagination."
—Hanna, Weatherlight navigator
Karn and Hanna stood over the recovered Legacy artifacts like loving parents over sleeping children.
The hounds' barks are a horrifying chorus of screams, moans, and whispers.

"no home    no heart    no hope"
—Stronghold graffito
Their favorite food? Wind dancers.
Secure in the embrace of wood, they want no part of Eladamri's war.

"Great chains shall free our warriors."
—Oracle en-Vec
Life's circle has become inverted in Grixis. The same energy is endlessly recycled and becomes more stagnant with each pass.

"Wind is forceful, yet ephemeral. It can knock a dragon out of the sky, yet pass through the smallest crack unhindered."
—Jestus Dreya, Of Elements and Eternity
It lurks just under the surface, using the algae-choked tar pits of Jund as both home and hunting blind.

"The emergence of the Eldrazi isn't necessarily a bad thing, as long as you've already lived a fulfilling and complete life without regrets."
—Javad Nasrin, Ondu relic hunter

"When the fifth sun rose, Mirrodin saw its first true dawn."
—Inscribed on the skin of Thrun, the last troll
With or without witnesses, the suns continued their prismatic dance.

"Kill the queen first, or we'll be fighting her drones forever. It is not in a queen's nature to have enough servants."
—Borzard, exterminator captain
A great mirage, a dream of wings and silver.
Bladehold houses a rogues' gallery filled with the living "statues" of the worst enemies of the Auriok.
After his hands had crumbled away, leaving only wickedly sharp points, he decided his only purpose was war.
For Sarkhan Vol, the dragon is the purest expression of life's savage splendor.

"My battle cry reaches ears far keener than yours."
—Saidah, Joraga hunter
In Lorwyn's brief evenings, the sun pauses at the horizon long enough for a certain species of violet to bloom with the fragrance of mischief.
"The changing kind suffers as we do. We must join as one to quench our tyrants!"

"We thank the souleaters for inscribing our souls with subservience, to reinforce the sacred order."
—Drones' hymn of gratitude

"Ogres taunt the dragons by moving into their territory, but even the hellkites find them too much trouble to hunt."
—Marza, mountain scout
"Just think how strong I'll be if my arms don't tear off!"
Some humans willingly offered up their blood, hoping it would grant the vampire families the strength to stave off the Eldrazi.
Witches of the Split-Eye Coven speak of a future when Grixis will overflow with life energy. For now, they must harvest vis from the living to fuel their dark magics.
When the Boros Legion attacks, swiftblades enter the fray first. They pick off the archers and mages, softening the enemy front before the flame-kin and giants go in.
Blood, bone, and sinew are magnified, as is the rage that drives them. The brain, however, remains unchanged—a little bean, swinging by a strand in a cavernous, raving head.
Instead of creating a tool that would be damaged by heat, the Thran built one that was charged by it.

"They say only the good die young. Obviously, you are one of the exceptions."
—Delrobah, cleric of Ivora Gate

"The sky teems with just as much life as the forest or the deep seas."
—Hadi Kasten, Calla Dale naturalist

"We will fight as they do: our flesh protected behind metal."
—Tae Aquil, Viridian weaponsmith
Mages of Esper measure their wealth and status by the number of servants in their retinues.

"Forswear the flesh and you will truly see."
—Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur
The Simic use the claws as scalpels, while the Rakdos use them for tattooing and torture. The Gruul use them to pick their teeth after lunching on the rest of the carcass.
Greatness, at any cost.
Heavier than it looks, tricky to wield, guaranteed to last.
Structures built from darksteel yield to neither assault nor age.

"Let the deception of the gods yield to the pure light of day."
—Brimaz, king of Oreskos

"You serve Phyrexia. Your pieces would better serve Phyrexia elsewhere."
—Azax-Azog, the Demon Thane

"The Golgari expand, yes, but I refuse to call their tainted creations ‘growth.'"

Each temple is a door to a horrible future.
The Izzet learn something from every lesson they teach.

Now etched only with the scars of phyresis.
"We coat ourselves in steel every day. What is etherium but the next logical step?"

"I use maps to find out where explorers have already been. Then I go the other way."
—Javad Nasrin, Ondu relic hunter

Jund feasts on the unprepared.

"Your downfall was not your ignorance, your weakness, or your hubris, but your warm blood."

"Where metal is tainted and wood is scarce, we are best armed by faith."
—Tavalus, acolyte of Korlis

"Unsafe Terrain Ahead—Turn Back"
—Sign near the former location of Pyrtagh Cairn
In desolate places, changelings may take the shape of fancies, or memories, or fears.
A rock between your eyes hurts. A burning rock between your eyes ruins your whole day.
War paint made from kolya fruit heightens senses and lessens fear. Unfortunately, fear is usually what keeps you alive.
Some of the eleven minotaur clans of Mirtiin are expert crafters and learned philosophers. Others just like to hit stuff.
Even the small wounds let hope bleed out.
Phyrexian smog clouds choked the skies, threatening creatures who couldn't comprehend the menace below.

"Down here, we have a more pointed version of the scriptures."
—Urabrask's enforcer
Hobgoblins are best left alone. They sharpen their farm implements far more than is necessary for their work in the fields.
Even the oldest treefolk was but an acorn when Lorwyn's first mysteries were born.
Hurkyl's research at the College of Lat-Nam wasn't enough to stop the two brothers, but for centuries thereafter her spellcraft taught artificers restraint.

"Every sword drawn to defend is an angelic blade, guided to justice by an angelic hand."
—Auriok proverb

"See how gratefully this world accepts our blessings."
—Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur
A light an army can follow.

"The results of our ninth inoculation were the same. The specimen was, of course, euthanized before the contagion could spread."
—Vedalken research notes
No more shall the righteous cower before evil.

"Duty and law are the foundation on which civilization stands. They must not fall, for when they do, they take everything with them."

"Don't laugh. It works."
Stinking of rot, it leaps between gravestones in search of its next meal.

—Phyrexian Scriptures

"Unless you like the idea of becoming some goblin's lunch, get up and move!"

Death is a generous author, always willing to grant a stirring final chapter.
After lightning struck the cliffs, the ore became iron, the iron became steel, and the steel became greaves. The lightning never left.

"I've journeyed across Dominaria. Phyrexians are everywhere. Plague is everywhere. There's no place left to hide."
An audience of one with the malice of thousands.

—Phyrexian progress notes

"The third stage of the illness: muscle aches and persistent cough."
—Phyrexian progress notes

"The first stage of the illness: rash and nausea."
—Phyrexian progress notes

Phyrexia wastes nothing. Its food chain is a spiraling cycle.

It doesn't think. It doesn't feel.
It doesn't laugh or cry.
All it does from dusk till dawn
Is make the soldiers die.
—Onean children's rhyme
They exist to cease.

"The final stage of the illness: delirium, convulsions, and death."
—Phyrexian progress notes

"The secrets of Phyrexia are expensive. You will pay in brass and bone, steel and sinew."

"Great peril demands formidable weaponry."
—Urza

"Gix doesn't want a people to rule but puppets to entertain his madness."
—Xantcha, Phyrexian outcast

"Father of Machines! Your filigree gaze carves us, and the scars dance upon our grateful flesh."

Darkness doesn't always send its minions to do its dirty work.

"Fire is the universal language."
—Jhoira, master artificer

Such cloaks are in high demand both by assassins and by those who fear them.
Even a fragment of a powerstone contains within it not just energy, but space—vast dimensions trapped in fragile crystal.
'Tis better to give than to receive.
Experiments intended to create the perfect holiday emissary resulted in a substance harder than darksteel and a fraction as merry.
"Thanks! You shouldn't have."

Arriving home, he suddenly longed for the bloodsoaked battlefields behind him.
WARNING: Shake gently. Contents may cause choking, hypothermia, and/or planar invasion.
Just hope yours isn't full of coal golems.

"They don't move, do they?"
"Only for the wrong sort of people."
"Are we the wrong sort of people?"

"Mystic shadow, bending near me, /
Who art thou? / Whence come ye?"
—Stephen Crane,
"Mystic shadow, bending near me"

These spirits of the air are winsome and wild and cannot be truly contained. Only marginally intelligent, they often substitute whimsy for strategy, delighting in mischief and mayhem.

". . . [T]he magician drew a ring off his finger . . . , saying: 'It is a talisman against all evil, so long as you obey me.'"

Junior Classics trans.

"When one's word is law, one's whim is equally binding."

The jagged teeth, the burning eyes,

"What I want, I take."
—Gustha Ebbasdotter,
Kjeldoran royal mage

"Four things that never meet do here unite To shed my blood and to ravage my heart,

And rosy cheeks and a glittering smile."
—The Arabian Nights, trans. Haddawy

"Out there, there are spirits, but here, there is wine."
—Blessing for the bounty of Kjeld

"Don't look at it! Maybe it'll go away!"
—Ib Halfheart, goblin tactician

Their stench was vile and strong enough, but not nearly as powerful as their hunger.

My mate did meet an early grave;
'Twas nothing left for us to save
In the peat-filled bogs of Cannelbrae.
"O! call back yesterday, bid time return." —William Shakespeare, King Richard the Second

"I reeled from the blow, and then suddenly, I knew exactly what to do. Within moments, victory was mine."
—Gustha Ebbasdotter
Kjeldoran royal mage
"They're not your friends; they despise you. I'm the only one you can count on. Trust me."

"Now that's a fashion statement."

At the door.
Run away quick

—Traditional children's rhyme

"Ashes and dust; dust and ashes.

More than one mage has been driven insane by the sound of the millstone relentlessly grinding away.
An end to reason, an end to order. Forget all that has been.

The intricate dynamics of Rundvelt goblin affairs are often confused with anarchy. The chaos, however, is the chaos of a thundercloud, and direction will sporadically and violently appear. Pashalik Mons and his raiders are the thunderhead that leads in the storm.

When Raganorn unsealed the catacombs, he found more than the dead and their treasures.

In a rare display of ingenuity, the orcs invented an incredibly destructive weapon. Most orcish artillerists are those who dared criticize its effectiveness.
There's a chance to win every battle.
There is no natural disaster quite like orcish farming.
A blazing light to drive out the shadows.
A shield of light admits no shadow.
It's bigger than it thinks.

"It has been my honor to improve on Thran's original design. Perhaps history will remember me in some small part for my work."

—Maeveen O'Donagh,
Memoirs of a Soldier

"Should you a Rat to madness tease

"A mysterious people indeed. Their origins are as secret as their traditions."

"My sorrow: to dream of simple times, and wake in mine . . . ."

"Just the thing for those pesky water mages."

trans. Haddawy

wurms were the bane of all Kjeldorans. Their great size and ferocity made them the subject of countless nightmares—they embodied the worst of the Ice Age."

Then—shuts the Door—"

"The Soul selects her own Society"

"I regret feeding Kaervek's hunger for power—far better to live with animals innocent of such ambitions."

Balduvian chieftain

Mouths and wings beyond numbering, but a single mind to guide them.

Moss-covered statues littered the area, a macabre monument to the basilisk's terrible power.

"Come one, come all! this rock shall fly From its firm base as soon as I."

—Elven phrase meaning
"plagued by guilt"

"How terrible to wander wishing only to escape oneself."

" . . . When the trees bow down their heads, / The wind is passing by."
—Christina Rossetti,
"Who Has Seen the Wind?"

—Ella Wheeler Wilcox, "Winds of Fate"

—Aline Corralurn, "Late Thaw"

—William Shakespeare, King Henry V

—Jaya Ballard, task mage

"When one wolf calls, others follow.

Although greatly prized among falconers, the zephyr falcon is capricious and not easily tamed.

Among Godo's hordes, "beware of falling rocks" came to mean "akki live nearby."
No matter where you find them, goblins love rocks.
The lava-proof shells of akki evolved over centuries, as akki pranks almost always got seriously out of hand.

—Observations of the Kami War

"Lies and deceit do yield results, but legitimate authority is the ultimate form of control."
—Meloku the Clouded Mirror

—Lady Azami, letter to Sensei Hisoka
"I do not miss Jukai Forest. It is not my home. My home is Kamigawa, its people my family. Wherever I set my pack and rest my head, I am home."

"Today I asked Master Dosan what the ogre mages did with the humans they sacrificed. He gave me a hard look and said to think no more on the matter."

When the Honden of Life's Web was destroyed, its attendants swarmed Kamigawa to ensure mortal defeat.

"Virtue is an inner light that can prevail in every soul."
When the Honden of Infinite Rage shattered, its attendants swarmed Kamigawa to sow mortal destruction.

—Teachings of Eight-and-a-Half-Tails

Destroyed in one of the first battles of the Kami War, the town of Reito still grieved.
Dosan sat in repose for many hours. He made no motion, no sound at all. And as he sat, nature revealed itself to him.

To the sorrow of all, its fire was turned toward those who worshipped it.

To the sorrow of all, its winds found sin in the hearts of those who once learned from its wisdom.

When the Honden of Cleansing Fire was abandoned, its attendants swarmed Kamigawa to erode mortal will.
